SUMMARY: Negotiators between the White House and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy's team briefly paused talks on Friday. There's a little more than a week before the country runs out of money to pay its bills.

SUMMARY: Human actions have caused "significant declines" in the amount of water stored in 53% of the planet's largest lakes and reservoirs. Climate change and overconsumption are the primary drivers.

SUMMARY: The Mississippi 17-year-old is not participating in her high school graduation ceremony because school officials told her to dress like a boy and a federal judge did not block the officials' decision.

TITLE: Martin Amis, British author of era-defining novels, dies at 73
SUMMARY: The influential novelist and nonfiction writer died in Florida of esophageal cancer. His novels, such as Money, The Information and London Fields,

SUMMARY: The Bob Baffert-trained horse won the second leg of the Triple Crown at the Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore, where a string of recent horse deaths have clouded this year's races.

SUMMARY: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Sunday that Bakhmut was "only in our hearts," hours after Russia's defense ministry reported that their forces had seized the city in eastern Ukraine.

SUMMARY: At least twelve people were killed and dozens more injured when stampeding soccer fans pushed through one of the access gates at a quarterfinal match in the Salvadoran league Saturday.

TITLE: Here's what could happen in markets if the U.S. defaults. Hint: It won't be pretty
SUMMARY: Investors are still hopeful that lawmakers will clinch a deal to raise or suspend the debt ceiling. That's because failure to do so could have devastating consequences in markets.

TITLE: Japan's atomic bomb survivors hope G-7 firms up support for nuclear disarmament
SUMMARY: As President Biden and Group of Seven leaders gathered in Hiroshima, people in Japan wanted the setting to act as a powerful symbol for consensus toward banning nuclear arms.

TITLE: The next show you watch could be filmed in Mexico City
SUMMARY: American and European companies are increasingly having their commercials, shows and films shot in Mexico, taking advantage of lower costs and experienced Mexican crews.

SUMMARY: Companies are building carbon dioxide pipelines as a possible climate solution. But after a pipeline rupture sent dozens to the hospital in a Mississippi town, there are questions about their safety.

SUMMARY: Russia has claimed victory in the invasion's longest battle, but Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said the fight for Bakhmut was not over. "We are not throwing people (away) to die," he said.

TITLE: An Indiana man is dead after a grenade found in a grandfather's belongings exploded
SUMMARY: The man's two children â a 14-year-old boy and an 18-year-old woman â were wounded by shrapnel and transported to a nearby hospital.

TITLE: Daniel Penny says he felt no shame after the NYC subway death of Jordan Neely
SUMMARY: Daniel Penny broke his silence this weekend â insisting that the confrontation between him and Neely "had nothing to do with race," and he was "not a white supremacist."

TITLE: Saudi astronauts, including nation's 1st woman, catch a SpaceX flight to space station
SUMMARY: Saudi Arabia's first astronauts in decades rocketed toward the International Space Station on a chartered multimillion-dollar flight. The crew will spend just over a week there before returning home.

SUMMARY: As the West endures a megadrought, rising levels of arsenic â a known carcinogen â in the water supply of Colorado's San Luis Valley offer clues to what the future may hold.

SUMMARY: With abortion increasingly restricted in many states, Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.), hopes to persuade Republicans to back insurance coverage for over-the-counter birth control.

TITLE: The Supreme Court and 'The Shadow Docket'
SUMMARY: A relative rarity until the Trump administration, in just four years, his Trump Justice Department asked the court for emergency relief an astounding 41 times.

TITLE: The latest workers calling for a better quality of life: airline pilots
SUMMARY: In ongoing contract negotiations, pilots at major airlines are pushing for changes in scheduling, to allow for more time at home and fewer missed birthdays and other celebrations.

TITLE: Target is recalling nearly 5 million candles that can cause burns and lacerations
SUMMARY: The recall affects the store's Threshold Glass Jar Candles in multiple sizes. Target received 137 reports of the candle jar cracking and breaking during use, including six injuries.

TITLE: Biden and McCarthy gear up for the next round of debt ceiling talks
SUMMARY: The two leaders are having an in-person meeting Monday after a "productive" phone call on Sunday about the debt ceiling. The U.S. could run out of money to pay its bills as early as June 1.

SUMMARY: Unless Congress acts to raise the federal debt limit, the U.S. government could run short of cash to pay its bills as early as June 1. Seniors, veterans, government workers and others would suffer.

SUMMARY: The school began receiving backlash after it announced David Zaslav would be this year's commencement speaker a day after the Writers Guild of America went on strike.

TITLE: Kurt Cobain's broken guitar sells for nearly $600,000
SUMMARY: The Nirvana frontman was known for smashing guitars during performances and in the studio. This one includes messages to his old friend, Mark Lanegan of the Screaming Trees.

SUMMARY: More women who say they were put in danger by Texas' abortion bans are joining a lawsuit that seek to force the state to clarify medical exceptions in the laws.

SUMMARY: Catch up on key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Ireland will require cancer warnings and calorie counts on alcoholic beverage labels
SUMMARY: Under the new rules taking effect in three years, labels will also have to warn drinkers of the risks to pregnancy, the beverage's calorie content and the number of grams of alcohol it contains.

TITLE: TikTok sues Montana over its new law banning the app
SUMMARY: TikTok says Montana does not have the authority to weigh in on national security issues and that the law deprives American TikTok users of their free speech rights.

TITLE: After a TikTok user rehabbed a couch from the curb, a bedbug expert urges caution
SUMMARY: If you acquire a piece of second-hand furniture that has bedbugs, even a thorough cleaning and time may not be enough to fully eradicate the <em>Cimex lectularius

SUMMARY: As the U.S. faces the prospect of defaulting on its debts, a key question looms: How bad would things actually get if that were to happen?

TITLE: She holds the NASA record for time spent in space. This week she headed back
SUMMARY: Before this week, Peggy Whitson had spent a cumulative 665 days in space over her career, giving her the NASA record. She's not done yet.

TITLE: Japanese Americans object to proposed wind farm at WWII incarceration site
SUMMARY: A proposed wind farm in Idaho that would be one of the U.S.'s largest is being opposed because it's close to a historic site â a former incarceration camp for Japanese Americans during World War II.

TITLE: Lawsuits claim gunmaker can be held liable in the Uvalde school massacre
SUMMARY: Two lawsuits filed by families of Uvalde victims against gunmaker Daniel Defense will be a key test of an unsettled legal theory.

TITLE: A new nasal spray to reverse fentanyl and other opioid overdoses gets FDA approval
SUMMARY: Opvee is similar to naloxone, the life-saving drug that has been used for decades to quickly counter overdoses of heroin, fentanyl and prescription painkillers.

TITLE: Fake viral images of an explosion at the Pentagon were probably created by AI
SUMMARY: Authorities quickly confirmed that no explosion had taken place but the faked images spread on Twitter for a short time. The incident briefly sent the stock market lower.

TITLE: Insurance firms need more climate change information. Scientists say they can help
SUMMARY: Floods, wildfires, heat waves and hurricanes cause billions of dollars of property damage each year. Can federal climate scientists help the insurance industry keep up?

TITLE: An autopsy cites neglect for man's death in a bedbug-infested Georgia jail cell
SUMMARY: Public outrage over Lashawn Thompson's death spread after a lawyer for his family released photos of Thompson's face and body covered in insects.

TITLE: Survey: Surprising to some, veterans are less likely to support extremism
SUMMARY: A RAND Corporation survey found that Americans who served in the military support extremist views at rates lower than nonveterans.

TITLE: Want to understand your adolescent? Get to know their brain
SUMMARY: For parents of teenagers, adolescence can be challenging, but to a brain scientist it's a time of breathtaking development. And it's a "window of opportunity" on the way to becoming an adult.

TITLE: Abortion bans drive off doctors and close clinics, putting other health care at risk
SUMMARY: Even the Trump-era surgeon general is concerned about the repercussions for women's health, as doctors say they are reluctant to practice in states that have banned abortion.

TITLE: He visited the U.S. for his daughter's wedding â and left with a $42,000 medical bill
SUMMARY: After emergency surgery, an American expatriate now carries the baggage of a five-figure bill. Costs for medical care in the U.S. can be two to three times the rates in other developed countries.

TITLE: Carmelo Anthony announces he is retiring from the NBA after 19 seasons
SUMMARY: Anthony was selected third overall in the 2003 NBA draft, months after winning a national championship during his only season at Syracuse University. Anthony is also the NBA's No. 9 all-time scorer.

TITLE: A suspect is charged after crashing a truck into barriers near the White House
SUMMARY: U.S. Park Police say a preliminary investigation indicates that 19-year-old Sai Varshith Kandula of Chesterfield, Mo., plowed into the bollards around Lafayette Square on purpose.

TITLE: A dilemma for dozens of countries: Fund your schools and hospitals or pay your debt
SUMMARY: There's a looming debt crisis in many lower income countries. Low interest rates a few years back started the cycle. Then came a series of once in a generation shocks. Is there a solution?

TITLE: People with disabilities aren't often seen in stock photos. The CPSC is changing that
SUMMARY: The Consumer Product Safety Commission took photos of people with disabilities using home safety devices like flashlights and smoke alarms â then put them in the public domain for anyone to use.

TITLE: A Russian court has extended Evan Gershkovich's detention until the end of August
SUMMARY: A Russian court extended the detention of <em>Wall Street Journal

TITLE: A year after Uvalde, lawsuits will test firearms industry's immunity protections
SUMMARY: Federal law protects the firearms industry from many lawsuits, but Uvalde parents are putting the laws to the test by suing a gun manufacturer over the way they market their weapon.

TITLE: A Georgia school district's book bans may have caused a hostile environment, feds say
SUMMARY: Forsyth County Schools didn't spell out its criteria to students, the Department of Education says, leaving the impression that diverse authors and characters were excluded.

TITLE: Trump instructed to obey court rules ahead of Manhattan criminal trial
SUMMARY: At a hearing Tuesday in New York, which former President Donald Trump attended via video conference, Judge Juan Merchan ordered the Trump to obey a protective order or face a possible contempt ruling.

TITLE: E. Jean Carroll aims to expand defamation lawsuit against Trump, seeking $10 million
SUMMARY: Earlier this month, a jury found the former president liable for sexual abusing Carroll at a department store in the mid-1990s. The day after the verdict, Trump again denied the allegations on CNN.

TITLE: Social media can put young people in danger, U.S. surgeon general warns
SUMMARY: Dr. Vivek Murthy says social media makes kids feel worse about themselves, and they can't get off of it. He says "we need safety standards for social media the way we have for cars, for car seats."

TITLE: Report finds Bureau of Indian Affairs is falling short on prison reforms

TITLE: U.S. military veterans generally don't embrace extremism, a new survey shows
SUMMARY: A new survey finds that support for extremist groups is generally lower among military veterans than in the general population.

TITLE: Residents near the volcano outside Mexico City prepare to evacuate
SUMMARY: The volcano, popularly known as "El Popo" in Mexico, is rumbling and spewing ash, as people living in its shadow prepare for a possible evacuation.

TITLE: The latest on negotiations over raising the debt ceiling
SUMMARY: White House and congressional negotiators are no closer to reaching a deal to lift the debt ceiling. Any deal is also likely to upset parts of the Republican and Democratic caucus.

TITLE: Illinois attorney general finds massive cover-up of clergy sexual abuse
SUMMARY: The Illinois attorney general has released a report detailing decades of child sexual abuse by Catholic clergy in the state. It found 451 priests and religious brothers abused nearly 2,000 children.

TITLE: Rick Hoyt, a fixture at the Boston Marathon with his dad, dies at 61

TITLE: NBA star Carmelo Anthony retires after 19 seasons
SUMMARY: After 19 seasons in the NBA, Carmelo Anthony retires as the 9th top scorer in the league's history, and holds 3 Olympic gold medals.

TITLE: Climate change makes Super Typhoon Mawar more dangerous
SUMMARY: The giant storm formed over abnormally warm water in the Pacific. And sea level rise makes storm surge even more dangerous to residents of Guam and the Mariana Islands.

TITLE: A year after Supreme Court's abortion decision, Planned Parenthood announces layoffs

SUMMARY: The exodus of more than 210,000 people from Sudan to Egypt since the war began in April highlights the deep ties that bind the countries â and Egypt's mixed legacy in Sudan.

TITLE: Some cancer drugs are in short supply, putting patients' care at risk. Here's why
SUMMARY: The recent, abrupt shortage of critical cancer drugs is forcing doctors to ration essential medications. It highlights a broken business model in generic drugs.

TITLE: Earth, air, fire, water â and family â are all 'Elemental' for Pixar's Peter Sohn
SUMMARY: In science class, Sohn saw the periodic table as an apartment building. The son of Korean immigrants, he felt the elements were a "beautiful metaphor" for cultures mixing in his New York hometown.

TITLE: How companies can build trust with the LGBTQ+ community â during Pride and beyond
SUMMARY: Target, The North Face, Bud Light and others are facing backlash for pro-LGBTQ+ campaigns. Some have stood fast, others stumbled. Experts say consistency and intentionality are key to true support.

TITLE: Grand jury indicts Daniel Penny in chokehold death of NYC subway rider Jordan Neely
SUMMARY: A man charged with manslaughter for putting an agitated New York City subway rider in a fatal chokehold has been indicted by a grand jury, a step that will allow the criminal case to continue.

TITLE: British star Glenda Jackson has died after a shimmering life on stage and in politics
SUMMARY: Glenda Jackson has died. One of the finest British actresses of her generation, Jackson won Oscar, Emmy, and Tony Awards. Fiercely political, she also served as a member of Parliament for decades.

TITLE: All OB-GYNs need abortion care training. New bill aims to help them get it
SUMMARY: Medical schools in states that have banned abortion can't teach abortion care. Sen. Tammy Baldwin wants to make funds available for students in those states to travel for the training.

TITLE: British star Glenda Jackson has died at age 87
SUMMARY: Jackson was one of the finest British actors of her generation, winning Oscar, Emmy and Tony Awards. Fiercely political, she also served as a member of Parliament for decades.

TITLE: Climate change is causing people to move. They usually stay local, study finds
SUMMARY: Researchers looked at thousands of homeowners who moved out of flood-prone homes. Most stayed within a 20-minute drive, and their new homes were safer from flooding.

TITLE: The Supreme Court leaves Indian Child Welfare Act intact
SUMMARY: The case pit prospective adoptive parents and Texas against the act, a federal law aimed at preventing Native American children from being separated from their extended families and their tribes.

TITLE: Georgia is becoming a hub for electric vehicle production. Just don't mention climate
SUMMARY: Georgia's Republican governor, Brian Kemp, is pledging to make his state the "electric mobility capital" of the country without embracing the climate realities that are helping drive the transition.

TITLE: Abortion care training is banned in some states. A new bill could help OB-GYNs get it
SUMMARY: Medical schools in states that have banned abortion can't teach abortion care. Sen. Tammy Baldwin wants to make funds available for students in those states to travel for the training.

TITLE: Germany will pay more than $1.4 billion next year to survivors of Nazi atrocities
SUMMARY: Nearly $890 million will go toward home care services â an increasingly vital aspect of the reparation effort, as Holocaust victims advance in age.

TITLE: A Florida condo tower's collapse may have begun on its pool deck
SUMMARY: The accident in Surfside, Fla. killed 98 people two years ago. Now a federal team says the condo's concrete columns and pool deck were constructed improperly and didn't meet building codes.

TITLE: Live Nation and Ticketmaster tell Biden they're going to show fees up front
SUMMARY: After President Biden called out "junk fees" in his State of the Union address, ticket vendors said they were willing to do more to disclose hidden fees. Live Nation is the latest to join.

TITLE: Reddit CEO Steve Huffman: 'It's time we grow up and behave like an adult company'
SUMMARY: In his first interview since thousands of so-called subreddits went dark in protest. Huffman said he is not going to reverse his plan to start charging for outside access to Reddit data.

TITLE: A man charged with killing his mother at sea over inheritance dies in jail
SUMMARY: The Vermont man charged with killing his mother off the coast of New England in a scheme to inherit millions of dollars has died in jail while awaiting trial, federal authorities said.

TITLE: Can a playlist of fish music save the world's coral reefs?
SUMMARY: The wondrous findings of a global project to record the sound of ocean habitats threatened by climate change and pollution.

TITLE: FDA advisers back updated COVID shots for fall vaccinations
SUMMARY: A panel of advisers to the Food and Drug Administration have recommended revising the current COVID-19 vaccine so that it specifically targets omicron.

TITLE: She was 200 meters from the peak of Mount Everest, then turned back. Here's why
SUMMARY: Kirstie Ennis has scaled plenty of incredible mountains before. But Mount Everest continues to elude her.

TITLE: 9 more women sue Bill Cosby for alleged sexual assaults decades ago
SUMMARY: The Nevada lawsuit was filed shortly after the state eliminated its deadline for filing state civil sexual assault cases. The women say that Cosby drugged and assaulted them between 1979 and 1992.

TITLE: Pentagon leak suspect Jack Teixeira is indicted by a federal grand jury
SUMMARY: The Air National guardsman is facing six counts of willful retention and transmission of national defense information, according to the Department of Justice.

TITLE: 15 die after a bus full of seniors heading to a casino in Canada collides with truck
SUMMARY: A spokesperson for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said the bus was carrying 25 people and authorities in Manitoba were deploying all their resources to the scene.

TITLE: Pfizer warns of a looming penicillin supply shortage
SUMMARY: The shortage comes as there has been a steady increase in rates of syphilis since 2000. Inventory can start depleting as early as this month, Pfizer said.

TITLE: An American is arrested over the death of a U.S. tourist at a German castle
SUMMARY: An American man has been arrested over the death of one U.S. tourist and an assault on another near Neuschwanstein castle after he allegedly pushed the two women down a steep slope, authorities said.

TITLE: Opioid settlement payouts are now public â and we know how much local governments got
SUMMARY: KFF Health News obtained documents showing the exact dollar amounts â down to the cent â that local governments have been paid in 2022 and 2023 in lawsuit settlements from the opioid crisis.

TITLE: As the U.S. and democracies worldwide face threats, Britain shows how to fight back
SUMMARY: With democracy under siege around the world, the U.K. offers a glimmer of hope. Despite attacks from former Prime Minister Boris Johnson, Britain's institutions resisted.

TITLE: Biden's campaign is getting rolling. Here's what's been happening behind the scenes
SUMMARY: President Biden launched his reelection campaign almost two months ago. But behind the scenes, there's been a lot of work laying the ground for fundraising and organizing at the DNC.

TITLE: Yes, the big news is Trump. Test your knowledge of everything else in NPR's news quiz
SUMMARY: Who won the week? The Tonys? Jack Smith? UPS delivery persons? Generative AI? Joe Biden's dentist? Or YOU ... if you've been paying attention.

TITLE: A father needed to get to his daughter in the ICU. A stranger helped him get there
SUMMARY: When Daniel Willingham's daughter ended up in the ICU, an unsung hero stepped up to help him get there.

TITLE: When Pakistan's politics get tough, Pakistanis respond with memes and humor
SUMMARY: Political humor in Pakistan has evolved over the years to evade censorship and other restrictions. After ex-Prime Minister Imran Khan's arrest in May, the internet exploded with memes and jokes.

TITLE: 'Still alive,' Pope Francis jokes as he leaves a Rome hospital 9 days after surgery
SUMMARY: "The pope is well. He's better than before,'' said Dr. Sergio Alfieri, the surgeon who performed the 86-year-old pontiff's operation on June 7.

TITLE: The U.S. must set up regular engagement with China, Rep. Andy Kim says
SUMMARY: Ahead of Secretary of State Blinken's trip to China, NPR's Leila Fadel talks to Democratic Rep. Andy Kim of New Jersey, a member of the House China committee, about Washington's approach to Beijing.

TITLE: An associate of Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny is sentenced to prison for extremism
SUMMARY: Lilia Chanysheva was sentenced to 7 1/2 years in prison in the latest in a series of lengthy prison terms handed down to Kremlin political opponents. Women are increasingly singled out for repression.

TITLE: Testosterone is probably safe for your heart. But it can't stop 'manopause'
SUMMARY: A new study finds men with low T who used a gel to increase the hormone did not have a higher rate of heart attacks than men on a placebo. But the anti-aging benefits are iffy.

TITLE: Blinken travels to China amid low expectations and global worries of a new cold war
SUMMARY: In a first visit to China by a member of President Biden's Cabinet, the secretary of state will seek "open lines of communication" with Beijing but no diplomatic breakthrough is expected.

TITLE: Biden taps Mandy Cohen â former North Carolina health secretary â to lead CDC
SUMMARY: President Biden's pick for the next director of the CDC is Dr. Mandy Cohen, an internal medicine physician with experience in state and federal government.

TITLE: After indictment, majority want Trump to drop out, but he's getting stronger with GOP
SUMMARY: After a federal indictment and arraignment, Donald Trump sees support among Republicans grow as independents move away from the former president and 2024 candidate.

TITLE: Some see the U.S.-China rivalry as an 'existential struggle.' Rep. Andy Kim disagrees
SUMMARY: Kim, who sits on the House China panel, disagrees with its chair's characterization of the rivalry. He hopes that Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit will mean more regular talks with China.

TITLE: History-making whistleblower Daniel Ellsberg has died at 92
SUMMARY: Ellsberg's release of what were called the "Pentagon Papers" hastened the end of the Vietnam war, prompted a landmark Supreme Court ruling and contributed to the downfall of President Richard Nixon.

TITLE: Are masks for the birds? We field reader queries about this new stage of the pandemic
SUMMARY: The official emergency is over but COVID is still here. And that means ... lots of questions. We asked our readers what's on their mind and then called on experts for advice.

TITLE: He interviewed his daughter on her birthday for 17 years. This is what he learnt
SUMMARY: What does a modern childhood and father-daughter relationship look like? One man documented the journey.

TITLE: DOJ report finds systemic patterns of abuse by the Minneapolis Police Department
SUMMARY: The Justice Department, city and police will begin negotiations to set the terms of a consent decree, which will bring federal oversight to police

TITLE: Cyclist Gino MÃ¤der, 26, dies after a high-speed crash in the Swiss Alps
SUMMARY: After Gino MÃ¤der and another rider crashed, criticisms emerged about the race layout, which put the finish line down a steep descent. The police also say they're investigating the incident.

TITLE: He interviewed his daughter on her birthday for 17 years. This is what he learned
SUMMARY: What does a modern childhood and father-daughter relationship look like? One man documented the journey.

TITLE: From gun violence to great composers: Meet our Student Podcast Challenge finalists
SUMMARY: In its fifth year, our contest received more than 3,300 entries from around the country â and we've narrowed it down to 13 middle school and 13 high school finalists.

TITLE: 40 years ago, Sally Ride became the first American woman in space
SUMMARY: On June 18, 1983, she made history aboard the space shuttle. America's first woman in space had joined NASA after responding to a newspaper ad. "I knew that's what I wanted to do," she said.

TITLE: You don't need a grill to grill, advises award-winning cookbook author
SUMMARY: James Whetlor, author of <em>The DIY BBQ Cookbook,

TITLE: Gas stoves pollute homes with benzene, which is linked to cancer
SUMMARY: Benzene is among the pollutants gas stoves emit into homes, Stanford University researchers show. The toxin is linked to a higher risk of leukemia and other blood cell cancers.

TITLE: A federal judge has blocked much of Indiana's ban on gender-affirming care for minors
SUMMARY: The judge issued an order Friday stopping an Indiana ban on puberty blockers and hormones for transgender minors from taking effect as scheduled July 1.

TITLE: Germany hands over 2 Indigenous masks to Colombia as it reappraises its colonial past
SUMMARY: The wooden "sun masks," which date back to the mid-15th century, were handed over at the presidential palace during a visit to Berlin by Colombian President Gustavo Petro

TITLE: At least 25 have been killed in a suspected rebel attack on a Ugandan school
SUMMARY: In a statement on Saturday, police said that the Allied Democratic Forces carried out the attack in the town of Mpondwe near the Congo border. The ADF opposes the rule of the Ugandan president.

TITLE: Japan expands the definition of rape and raises the age of consent to 16 from 13
SUMMARY: The new legislation redefines rape as nonconsensual sex, removing a requirement showing the victim fought back. The change comes after four years of protests decrying sexual violence in Japan.

TITLE: How Indigenous kids survived 40 days in Colombia's jungle after a plane crash
SUMMARY: Led by their eldest sibling, who is 13, they managed to find food and shelter. All four, including a year-old baby, stayed safe until Colombian special forces and Indigenous guides rescued them.

TITLE: Americans celebrate dads this weekend. Three tell us about being a father in 2023
SUMMARY: Ahead of Father's Day, NPR's <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: These kids revamped their schoolyard. It could be a model to make cities healthier
SUMMARY: Living near parks can boost health and well being. But low-income communities and those of color often have less access than wealthier, white ones. Revamping schoolyards could be a game changer.

TITLE: At least 41 have been killed in a suspected rebel attack on a Ugandan school
SUMMARY: Police said rebels from the Allied Democratic Forces, who have been launching attacks for years from their bases in eastern Congo, carried out the raid on the school in the border town of Mpondwe.

TITLE: Trump has had a lot of lawyers but still longs for his wartime consigliere
SUMMARY: When it comes to former President Donald Trump's legal team, it's easy to get spun in the revolving door. It seems like he's looking for a wartime consigliere â another Roy Cohn.

TITLE: A deadly new street drug caught the U.S. off guard. Experts say it'll happen again
SUMMARY: A dangerous chemical called xylazine is being mixed into fentanyl across the U.S., but who's doing it and why is a mystery. The government still doesn't identify and track new drug threats.

TITLE: Debut novel 'The God of Good Looks' adds to growing canon of Caribbean literature
SUMMARY: A growing number of high-profile novels are coming out of the Caribbean and the Caribbean diaspora. And the region has long been punching above its weight on the international literary scene.

TITLE: Berhalter rehired as U.S. Soccer coach after controversy involving a player's family
SUMMARY: After a worldwide search for a head coach to lead the U.S. soccer team to victory in the 2026 FIFA World Cup, Gregg Berhalter was announced as the person for the role.

TITLE: Donald Triplett, the 1st person diagnosed with autism, dies at 89
SUMMARY: The Mississippi man known as "Case 1" was the first person to be diagnosed with autism. Triplett was the subject of a book and documentary titled In a Different Key and many medical journal articles.

TITLE: The NCAA looks to weed out marijuana from its banned drug list
SUMMARY: An NCAA panel asked the association to treat marijuana like alcohol. The NCAA is expected to make a final decision on the matter in the fall.

TITLE: 16 were injured when a Baltimore bus crashed into 2 cars and an apartment building
SUMMARY: A preliminary investigation showed the bus crashed with a Lexus and a Nissan before coming to rest in a building. Witnesses said the Lexus was speeding and ran a stop light when it struck the bus.

TITLE: Blinken has arrived in Beijing on a mission to cool rising US-China tensions
SUMMARY: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrived in Beijing early Sunday on a high-stakes diplomatic mission to try to cool exploding U.S.-China tensions that have set many around the world on edge.

TITLE: Ukraine war is hurting Africa, South African President Ramaphosa tells Putin
SUMMARY: Russian President Vladimir Putin on Saturday met with a group of leaders of African countries who traveled to Russia on a self-styled "peace mission" the day after they went to Ukraine.

TITLE: A heat wave is hitting the South, from a tornado in West Texas to Florida beaches
SUMMARY: Communities from Houston to New Orleans opened cooling centers to bring relief as steamy hot temperatures settled across a broad swath of the U.S. South on Saturday.

TITLE: Biden says rich must 'pay their share' at first reelection campaign rally
SUMMARY: President Joe Biden delivered an unapologetically economic populist message  during the first rally of his reelection campaign, saying his policies had created jobs and lifted the middle class.

TITLE: Growing without groaning: A brief guide to gardening when you have chronic pain
SUMMARY: Want to plant but afraid of the 'ouch'? Here's advices from a physical therapist for how to get hands-on in the garden, even if you have back pain or other chronic aches.

TITLE: He saw the ghost of his racist grandfather. It helped lead to meaningful healing
SUMMARY: John Blake's story is about growing up as a Black kid in West Baltimore in the 1980s, learning painful secrets about his white mother and, as he recalls, a ghost.

TITLE: For many migrants being bused from New York City to other towns, hostility awaits.
SUMMARY: Local non-profits say they are stretched too thin to take on extra cases and some community leaders have said more migrants are not welcome.

TITLE: Voting rights advocates welcomed a Supreme Court win. But the fight isn't over
SUMMARY: An unexpected U.S. Supreme Court ruling has upheld a key section of the Voting Rights Act. But many voting rights advocates and legal scholars are bracing for new efforts to dismantle the law.

TITLE: Antony Blinken has started meetings in Beijing, aiming to cool US-China tensions
SUMMARY: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrived in Beijing early Sunday on a high-stakes diplomatic mission to try to cool exploding U.S.-China tensions that have set many around the world on edge.

TITLE: Listen to cherished lullabies â from Brahms to Backstreet Boys â sung by our readers
SUMMARY: In response to our callout, you shared (and crooned) bedtime musical selections that work magic. (Well, except for the mom who tried an Enya song and whose kid begged, "Stop singing!")

TITLE: Collapsed I-95 in Philadelphia will open within the next 2 weeks, governor says
SUMMARY: State officials have been scrambling to reopen the span of the interstate that collapsed last weekend. On a typical day, that span would have seen about 160,000 vehicles pass through.

TITLE: 1 person was killed and 19 others were wounded in a shooting outside of Chicago
SUMMARY: Police in Willowbrook, Ill., responded to gunfire coming from an area with "a large gathering of people" shortly after midnight on Sunday. Officials said multiple people were rushed to area hospitals.

TITLE: At least 23 shot, 1 fatally, during a Juneteenth celebration near Chicago
SUMMARY: Police in Willowbrook, Ill., responded to gunfire coming from a Juneteenth celebration shortly after midnight on Sunday. Officials said multiple people were rushed to area hospitals.

TITLE: And the award goes to AI ft. humans: the Grammys outline new rules for AI use
SUMMARY: The Recording Academy, the organization behind the Grammy Awards, rolled out new rules around AI ahead of next year's show â as the technology rapidly advances.

TITLE: The FAA is investigating the latest close-call after Minneapolis runway incident
SUMMARY: An American Airlines plane was ordered to cancel its landing after a Delta plane that had been cleared for take-off was still on the runway. The FAA is investigating how close the planes got.

TITLE: Swiss voters support climate bill as scientists warn about melting glaciers
SUMMARY: The referendum to introduce new climate measures was sparked by a campaign by scientists and environmentalists to save Switzerland's iconic glaciers, which are melting away at an alarming rate.

TITLE: Juneteenth, the newest federal holiday, is gaining awareness
SUMMARY: Monday marks the Juneteenth holiday â a date commemorating the fall of slavery in the United States. While it's a new federal holiday, it's been celebrated since the 1860s.

TITLE: For Democrats trying to retake Virginia legislature, fiery primaries are first hurdle
SUMMARY: It's nearly been two years since Virginia Democrats lost the governor's office and the House to the GOP. Before attempting a comeback this fall, they must first survive Tuesday's expensive primaries.

TITLE: Deadly West Bank firefight leaves at least 3 Palestinians dead, dozens more injured
SUMMARY: The violence marked a rare use of Israeli airpower in the territory. During the clashes, Palestinian militants detonated a roadside bomb next to an Israeli military vehicle.

TITLE: Multiple mass shootings across the U.S. leave at least 6 dead on holiday weekend
SUMMARY: The shootings stretching from coast to coast follow a surge in homicides and other violence over the past several years that experts say accelerated during the coronavirus pandemic.

TITLE: Antony Blinken meets China's Xi in a bid to ease soaring U.S.-China tensions
SUMMARY: In footage released by China's state broadcaster, Xi is heard to say "The two sides have agreed to follow through on the common understandings President Biden and I have reached in Bali."

TITLE: Huntington's spreads like 'fire in the brain.' Scientists say they've found the spark
SUMMARY: Diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's spread through the brain like a forest fire. A new study suggests how the fire starts.

TITLE: A 3-hour phone call that brought her to tears: Impostor scams cost Americans billions
SUMMARY: Imposter scams are top U.S. fraud now: Con artists are using new technology to get real time information plus voice cloning and caller ID spoofing to make it even harder to tell truth from fiction.

TITLE: A new satellite could help clean up the air in America's most polluted neighborhoods
SUMMARY: A new satellite will take continuous measurements of dangerous air pollution in the U.S. That has scientists, and residents, warily optimistic about undoing decades of environmental injustice.

TITLE: Defense arguments to begin in youth climate trial in Montana
SUMMARY: The only youth climate change lawsuit to make it all the way to trial is underway in Montana.

TITLE: "Profound differences" remain between U.S. and China, Secretary Blinken says
SUMMARY: As U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken wraps up two days of diplomatic talks in Beijing, he said the two world powers must maintain communication despite "profound" differences.

TITLE: How Secretary Blinken is tackling the China relationship (and others in the region)
SUMMARY: Much of the Biden administration's approach to the world focuses on the U.S. competition with China.

TITLE: A search is underway for Titanic touring submersible missing in the Atlantic Ocean
SUMMARY: A submersible capable of taking tourists over 2 miles underwater to view the Titanic wreckage up close has gone missing.

TITLE: A search is underway for a missing submersible that brings tourists to the Titanic
SUMMARY: A submersible capable of taking tourists over 2 miles underwater to view the Titanic wreckage up close has gone missing.

TITLE: "Profound differences" remain between U.S. and China, Blinken tells NPR
SUMMARY: As U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken wraps up two days of diplomatic talks in Beijing, he said the two world powers must maintain communication despite "profound" differences.

TITLE: A 3-hour phone call that brought her to tears: Imposter scams cost Americans billions
SUMMARY: Imposter scams are top U.S. fraud now: Con artists are using new technology to get real time information plus voice cloning and caller ID spoofing to make it even harder to tell truth from fiction.

TITLE: "Profound differences" remain between U.S. and China, Secretary Blinken tells NPR
SUMMARY: As U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken wraps up two days of diplomatic talks in Beijing, he said the two world powers must maintain communication despite "profound" differences.

TITLE: Defense arguments are set to open in a landmark climate case brought by Montana youth
SUMMARY: The only youth climate change lawsuit to make it all the way to trial is underway in Montana.

TITLE: Multiple mass shootings leave dead and injured across the U.S. during holiday weekend
SUMMARY: The shootings stretching from coast to coast follow a surge in homicides and other violence over the past several years that experts say accelerated during the coronavirus pandemic.

TITLE: Power outages continue across the southern U.S. as a heat wave grips Texas
SUMMARY: More than 300,000 customers in the southern U.S. remained without power Monday as the bulk of outages were in Oklahoma, where heavy weekend storms carried winds as strong as 80 mph around Tulsa.

TITLE: Republican primary spending projected to approach or surpass $1 billion
SUMMARY: With a big field, a former president, well-heeled politicians and two billionaires running, this is likely to be the most money ever spent to win the GOP presidential nomination.

TITLE: How Ukraine created an 'Army of Drones' to take on Russia
SUMMARY: We hear a lot about the big-ticket weapons the West is shipping to Ukraine. But Ukraine is also fighting effectively with a weapon it can buy off-the-shelf and is small enough to hold in one hand.

TITLE: He once had motor skill challenges. Now he's the world's fastest Rubik's cube solver
SUMMARY: What puzzles most people â like solving a Rubik's cube â makes sense to Max Park. And the world of speedcubing has helped the autistic 21-year-old crack the code on what might come easy to others.

TITLE: Some states are restricting abortion. Others are spending millions to fund it
SUMMARY: Nearly a year after the U.S. Supreme Court allowed abortion bans around the country to take effect, some cities and states are pushing in the other direction, a new report finds.

TITLE: With visit to China, Blinken clears a diplomatic path, but it's unclear where it goes
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Antony Blinken's trip shows the Biden administration is keen to reignite diplomacy and inject stability to its dealings with China, but whether it was a success remains to be seen.

TITLE: Here's the latest on the missing Titanic sub and the race to rescue those inside
SUMMARY: The Titan, a 21-foot submersible, was diving with four passengers and one pilot towards the wreck of the Titanic. But it disappeared 105 minutes after submerging and hasn't been heard from since.

TITLE: Hunter Biden pleads guilty in tax case; also charged in gun case
SUMMARY: The U.S. Attorney in Delaware has been leading an investigation into Hunter Biden's tax and business dealings.

TITLE: From Beijing to London, Blinken pushes for Ukraine peace deal and recovery
SUMMARY: America's top diplomat heads from China to the U.K. where Ukraine's post-war recovery tops the agenda

TITLE: 'Tiny sub, big ocean': Why the Titanic submersible search is so challenging
SUMMARY: Retired U.S. Navy submarine Capt. David Marquet says crews would need to locate the vessel then bring it to the surface to unlatch it. He puts the odds of passengers' survival at "about 1%."

TITLE: Andrew Tate is indicted on human trafficking and rape charges in Romania
SUMMARY: The controversial social media celebrity is accused of using a "loverboy" ploy to gain control over women who were then forced to make pornography, according to prosecutors.

TITLE: Hunter Biden agrees to plead guilty in tax case and avoid prosecution on gun charge
SUMMARY: The president's son agreed to plead guilty to two misdemeanor tax offenses. He's also charged with a felony firearm offense, for which he agreed to enter a pretrial diversion agreement.

TITLE: A Palestinian attacker kills at least 4 people at a West Bank gas station
SUMMARY: A surge in violence this year has killed 128 Palestinians and 24 people on the Israeli side so far, according to a tally by The Associated Press.

TITLE: Deep sea rescues have a mixed track record. The Pisces III is one that succeeded
SUMMARY: An international mission rescued both occupants of a sunken submersible off the coast of Ireland in 1973 with just 12 minutes to spare. The men had spent three days in darkness and silence.

TITLE: A pair of rare cotton-top tamarin monkeys were just born at Walt Disney World
SUMMARY: The white-haired species is critically endangered due to habitat loss and the illegal pet trade, according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

TITLE: Tropical Storm Bret is making its way toward various eastern Caribbean islands
SUMMARY: As of 11 a.m. Atlantic Standard Time on Tuesday, no watches or warnings were in effect for Tropical Storm Bret. However, they could begin rolling in for the Lesser Antilles islands in the evening.

TITLE: Mother-daughter relationships are fraught. Jenny Xie explores how
SUMMARY: Jenny Xie's new novel dives into how "strange, infuriating and precious" mothers can be to their daughters.

TITLE: A former passenger details what it's like inside the missing Titan submersible
SUMMARY: The missing submersible is equipped with several mechanisms that can bring it back to the surface during an emergency, according to a former passenger.

TITLE: First in the nation gender-affirming care ban struck down in Arkansas
SUMMARY: A federal judge has struck down Arkansas' 2021 ban on gender-affirming care for transgender youth calling it unconstitutional and saying the state's experts were motivated by ideology, not science.

TITLE: Here's the latest on the missing Titan submersible and the race to rescue passengers
SUMMARY: The Titan, a minivan-size submersible, was carrying five people to the Titanic's watery grave when it lost contact. The vessel has enough oxygen to keep its passengers alive for about 40 more hours.

TITLE: Dozens of women die in a grisly riot in Honduran prison the president blames on gangs
SUMMARY: Twenty-six of the 41 known victims were burned to death and the remainder shot or stabbed at the prison in Tamara, about 30 miles northwest of the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa, police said.

TITLE: Summer solstice brings druids, pagans and thousands of curious people to Stonehenge
SUMMARY: A seemingly curious alliance of druids, pagans, hippies, local residents and tourists gathered around Stonehenge and greeted sunrise on Wednesday, which is the longest day in the Northern Hemisphere.

TITLE: How many miles do you have to travel to get abortion care? One professor maps it
SUMMARY: An economics professor at Middlebury College and her undergrad research assistants have been tracking access to abortion care since 2009. These maps show the dramatic changes in the past decade.

TITLE: OceanGate wants to change deep-sea tourism, but its missing sub highlights the risks
SUMMARY: OceanGate's expeditions to the Titanic were meant to herald a new era for deep-sea tourism, but the company's missing submersible has instead underscored the danger these journeys can bring.

TITLE: Election workers are facing threats and harassment as they brace for 2024
SUMMARY: Election workers across 22 different states told NPR they've received threats or felt unsafe doing their jobs, and many are worried for what the 2024 presidential election will bring.

TITLE: Trump's advantages are huge in the 2024 GOP primary right now
SUMMARY: President Biden meanwhile has seen his approval rating stabilize and is well liked among Democrats, though he faces challenges with independents and younger voters.

TITLE: A dying patient inspired this doctor to change careers
SUMMARY: Physician Abraham Verghese reflects on a defining moment in 1985, when one of his terminally ill patients reminded him to follow his dreams.

TITLE: Church of England clergy asks for a pay raise for the first time in history
SUMMARY: The United Kingdom has been struggling with a cost-of-living crisis since 2021. Clergy members are asking for a 9.5% pay hike that would begin in April 2024.

TITLE: Majority of Americans say it was wrong for the Supreme Court to overturn Roe
SUMMARY: A year after the court did away with the right to an abortion, 57% say they oppose the decision, an NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll finds. They're also in favor of continuing affirmative action programs.

TITLE: Greek court orders smuggling suspects held pending trial over migrant ship disaster
SUMMARY: The Egyptian suspects face charges that include participation in a criminal organization, manslaughter and causing a shipwreck.

TITLE: Search intensifies for the missing submersible as underwater noises are detected
SUMMARY: Rescue teams seeking the submersible housing five tourists that had planned to visit the wrecked Titanic said "noises" had been detected close to where the sub ended contact with its mother ship.

TITLE: Student podcasters share the dark realities of middle school in America
SUMMARY: School shootings, social media, beauty standards. 13-year-olds Erika Young and Norah Weiner delve into what middle school looks like today in their award-winning podcast.

TITLE: Their prize catch was set to bring in $3.5 million. Then the fish was disqualified
SUMMARY: The boat's crew isn't accused of any wrongdong. Their catch in the Big Rock Blue Marlin Tournament in North Carolina was disqualified because it was mutilated â bitten by a shark or another animal.

TITLE: A dying patient inspired this doctor to follow his dream to become a writer

SUMMARY: Dan Solomon's YA novel <em>The Fight for Midnight

SUMMARY: While not a new concept, Garrett Neiman makes distinct contributions to the conversation; as a rich white man, he has insider's access to that population â and doesn't shy away from self-indictment.

SUMMARY: 17-year-old Georgianna McKenny is the high school grand prize winner in NPR's fifth annual Student Podcast Challenge.

SUMMARY: It's the 80th anniversary of a little-known battle â by Black U.S. soldiers against segregation in the military. They were convicted of mutiny. Villagers in England want them exonerated.

TITLE: Germany's Green Party wants people to use heat pumps to save energy. Some are balking
SUMMARY: Some German homeowners are worried they'll have to foot the bill for their country's climate targets by replacing their gas boilers with cleaner â but more expensive â heat pumps.

SUMMARY: A year ago the Yellowstone River had its biggest flood in centuries. What that means for its world famous trout fishery is just now becoming clear.

SUMMARY: NPR's A Martinez talks to Will Kohnen, chairman of the Marine Technology Society's Submarine Group, about concerns that were raised about the development of the now-missing Titan submersible.

TITLE: U.S. reading and math scores drop to lowest level in decades
SUMMARY: Newly released data from national test scores in reading and math show a worrisome picture of student learning loss since the pandemic.

SUMMARY: Federal regulators say Amazon uses manipulative techniques to enroll shoppers into Prime memberships that are purposefully hard to cancel.

TITLE: Justice Alito refutes ProPublica report that he took a luxury trip with billionaire
SUMMARY: Justice Samuel Alito says he didn't have to disclose a 2008 luxury trip to Alaska, or the flight on a private jet of hedge fund billionaire Paul Singer who had several cases before the high court.

TITLE: Experts raised safety concerns about OceanGate years before its Titanic sub vanished
SUMMARY: Experts from within and outside OceanGate worried about the safety and development of the Titan as far back as 2018, years before its inaugural dive. One tells NPR its disappearance isn't a surprise.

TITLE: 'Excessive' weather events mark summer solstice in the U.S.
SUMMARY: The longest day of the year comes as the Southern U.S. endures record heat. Other regions are seeing persistent heavy rains, raising flood risks.

TITLE: A front-line city in Yemen is desperate for change after nearly a decade of civil war
SUMMARY: Nearly a decade of civil war has destroyed millions of Yemeni lives, but perhaps nowhere has it been felt more than in the neighborhoods in Taiz that are closest to the fighting.

TITLE: Monarch butterflies' white spots may help them fly farther, scientists say
SUMMARY: Monarch butterflies with more white spots on their mostly orange-and-black wings are more successful at long-distance migration. Some scientists think the spots may affect airflow around their wings.

TITLE: 'No kill' meat, grown from animal cells, is now approved for sale in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Two U.S. food companies  have received the go-ahead to sell chicken grown from cultivated animal cells in a production facility. It's the first time meat grown this way will be sold in the U.S.

TITLE: Justice Alito refutes ProPublica report he should have disclosed luxury trip
SUMMARY: Justice Samuel Alito says he didn't have to disclose a 2008 luxury trip to Alaska, or the flight on a private jet of hedge fund billionaire Paul Singer who had several cases before the high court.

TITLE: Paris police look for the cause of an explosion and fire that injured 24 people
SUMMARY: The explosion rocked a building, igniting a fire that sent smoke soaring over monuments and prompting an evacuation. Police were investigating suspicions that a gas leak caused the blast.

SUMMARY: Under the settlement with immigration authorities, the four women can apply for asylum. They also no longer face thousands in fines imposed by the former Trump administration.

TITLE: Pentagon leak suspect Jack Teixeira pleads not guilty to federal charges
SUMMARY: If convicted of the six charges against him, 21-year-old Jack Teixeira could face up to 10 years in prison for each charge.

SUMMARY: The Nuclear Ship Savannah offers a snapshot of a nuclear future that never quite came to pass.

SUMMARY: Yevgeny Prigozhin, owner of the Wagner private military contractor, made his most direct challenge to the Kremlin yet on Friday, calling for a rebellion aimed at ousting Russia's defense minister.

SUMMARY: Yevgeny Prigozhin, owner of the Wagner private military contractor, made his most direct challenge to the Kremlin yet on Friday, calling for a rebellion aimed at ousting Russia's defense minister.

SUMMARY: Each year in northern Pennsylvania, hundreds of stargazers attend gatherings under increasingly rare dark skies to look for faint galaxies, star clusters and nebulae.

SUMMARY: For years, Japanese leaders have tried to halt the country's falling birthrate. They might find lessons in the city of Akashi, whose population has been growing.

SUMMARY: With states empowered to regulate abortion, doctors say they're trapped by vague laws that criminalize care. And ongoing court battles make it hard to keep up with the procedure's legal status.

SUMMARY: The head of the private military force, Yevgeny Prigozhin, was formally charged with "inciting an armed revolt" by Russia's Federal Security Bureau overnight Saturday.

SUMMARY: Ablaye Ndiaye, who has Down syndrome, carried the torch at opening ceremony. It was, he says, "a great moment." But the reality for people with intellectual disabilities in Senegal is a challenge.

TITLE: A train carrying hazardous materials plunges into Yellowstone River after bridge fails

TITLE: He walked away from his evangelical roots to escape feeling suffocated
SUMMARY: The evangelical movement was Jon Ward's church, his family, his community, his music, and his identity. And then he broke away.

TITLE: He lost $340,000 to a crypto scam. Such cases are on the rise
SUMMARY: He thought he was investing in cryptocurrency. In fact, he was being swindled out of his life savings. There has been a 900% increase in such cases since the pandemic began, federal regulators say.

TITLE: Cyberattacks on hospitals 'should be considered a regional disaster,' researchers find

SUMMARY: El NiÃ±o is warming up the water in the Pacific Ocean. That extra heat affects the whole planet, and has helped drive record-breaking hot weather.

SUMMARY: The National Security Council declassified information about what it called an attempted "false flag operation" by Russia as global food supply is threatened.

SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump faces a number of criminal charges in two cases â but that may not be all, as he faces scrutiny in other probes. This all comes as Trump is running for president.

SUMMARY: Everybody knows someone â maybe it's you â who got COVID but never got sick or who thinks they never got COVID at all. A new study found one possible reason, involving a certain gene and common colds.

SUMMARY: The spy chief also told NPR's Mary Louise Kelly that discontent in Russia has created a "once-in-a-generation" opportunity to recruit Russians to spy on behalf of the U.S.

SUMMARY: Funny Cide was an unknown racehorse from New York state in 2003 when he came out of nowhere to win the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness. He died this week at the age of 23.

SUMMARY: While adding to its barrage of missile launches in recent months, North Korea remained publicly silent for a fifth day on the fate of an American soldier who ran into the country earlier in the week.

SUMMARY: As of Saturday morning, parts of Nova Scotia had already accumulated nearly six inches of rain. In some areas, rain fell over an inch per hour. Four people, including two children, are missing.

SUMMARY: A wildfire burning on the Greek island of Rhodes for a fifth day has forced authorities to order an evacuation of sites including seaside resorts that are full of tourists.

SUMMARY: Multiple organ failure, heart attack and kidney failure are the primary ways people die in extreme heat. Read on to find out how to stay safe in the heat wave.
