SUMMARY: A tentative agreement between UPS and the Teamsters has averted a potential strike at the company. The deal will secure pay raises for part-time workers.

TITLE: Bronny James, LeBron's oldest son, suffered cardiac arrest during practice
SUMMARY: The incoming freshman at the University of Southern California was at basketball practice Monday when he suffered a cardiac arrest, according to multiple media reports.

TITLE: A former pastor is charged with murdering an 8-year-old girl nearly 50 years ago
SUMMARY: David Zandstra, 83, has been charged with criminal homicide, first-degree murder and other crimes. Investigators say he admitted to killing Gretchen Harrington in 1975.

TITLE: Ammon Bundy ordered to pay $50 million. But will the hospital ever see the money?
SUMMARY: A jury as ordered Ammon Bundy and an associate to pay more than $50 million in damages to Idaho's largest hospital after armed protests last year led to a security lockdown.

TITLE: A political gap in excess deaths widened after COVID-19 vaccines arrived, study says
SUMMARY: After vaccines became widely available in 2021, "the excess death rate among Republican voters was 43% higher than the excess death rate among Democratic voters," Yale researchers say.

TITLE: TikTok's new text post format is similar to, but not the same as, Threads and Twitter
SUMMARY: The new publishing option, which was announced Monday, will allow content creators to combine written content with music, stickers and hashtags.

TITLE: Biden's dog, Commander, has been biting Secret Service agents
SUMMARY: The conservative group Judicial Watch obtained Secret Service emails complaining about Commander being aggressive. One bite sent an agent to the hospital.

TITLE: Speaker McCarthy says the House may launch an impeachment inquiry of President Biden
SUMMARY: The House speaker says Republicans may launch an impeachment inquiry into President Biden. House GOP members have been investigating allegations of financial misconduct related to his son, Hunter.

TITLE: Marine veteran Trevor Reed was wounded fighting in Ukraine
SUMMARY: The U.S. Marine veteran was freed from Russian prison in a prisoner swap last year. Now he has sustained an injury while fighting in Ukraine, the State Department said.

TITLE: McCarthy says info about Biden family 'rises to level of an impeachment inquiry'
SUMMARY: The House speaker says Republicans may launch an impeachment inquiry into President Biden. House GOP members have been investigating allegations of financial misconduct related to his son, Hunter.

TITLE: Phoenix melts in a record streak of days over 110 degrees. And it's not over yet
SUMMARY: Tuesday marks 26 consecutive days in Phoenix, Az. with a temperature over 110 degrees, and it doesn't look like it will let up any time soon.

TITLE: Bronny James, LeBron's son, suffered cardiac arrest during practice
SUMMARY: The incoming freshman at the University of Southern California was at basketball practice Monday when he suffered a cardiac arrest, a family spokesperson said in a statement.

TITLE: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis is uninjured after being involved in a car crash
SUMMARY: The Republican presidential candidate and his campaign team were traveling to an event in Chattanooga, Tenn., when traffic backed up, causing a four-car crash.

TITLE: 3 found dead at North Carolina gas station are identified as Marines stationed nearby
SUMMARY: The three men were found unresponsive Sunday morning in a privately owned car at a Speedway gas station in Hampstead, N.C. Medical authorities pronounced all three dead the same day.

TITLE: Rescue efforts are underway for dozens of whales beached along an Australia coast
SUMMARY: The incident is reminiscent of one in September, in which some 200 pilot whales died after a pod stranded itself on the remote west coast of Tasmania, off Australia's southeastern coast.

TITLE: The U.S. dedicates a new embassy in Tonga in a bid for more influence in the Pacific
SUMMARY: Tonga is just one stop on a tour of the Pacific by Secretary of State Antony Blinken this week. He is the latest in a parade of US diplomats to visit Oceania in the last year.

TITLE: This CDC data shows where rates of heat-related illness are highest
SUMMARY: Emergency rooms report when patients visit with health problems caused by heat. Find out when and where rates of illness are spiking, and explore trends over the last five years.

TITLE: At the Women's World Cup, the USA faces the Netherlands - a rematch of the 2019 final
SUMMARY: The U.S. defeated the Netherlands in 2019 for its second consecutive World Cup title. Now the two teams are battling in the group stage as the U.S. looks to shake off a sluggish win over Vietnam.

TITLE: Someone could steal your medical records and bill you for their care
SUMMARY: Consumers should know that medical identity theft can happen, whether from a large-scale breach or theft of an individual's data. The result could be thousands of dollars in medical bills.

TITLE: 'This has become a sacred alley.' The face of Emad Shargi imprisoned in Iran
SUMMARY: A mural in Washington, D.C. depicts Americans wrongfully detained abroad and fades with time to represent passing days. Neda Sharghi's brother Emad imprisoned in Iran is one of those faces.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Fed could hike rates; Threads under pressure; get healthy with NEAT
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is expected to announce it's raising interest rates. Voting groups want Threads to tighten its rules ahead of the election. A NEAT way to burn calories without working out.

TITLE: At the Women's World Cup, the USA faces the Netherlands â a rematch of the 2019 final
SUMMARY: The U.S. defeated the Netherlands in 2019 for its second consecutive World Cup title. Now the two teams are battling in the group stage as the U.S. looks to shake off a sluggish win over Vietnam.

TITLE: Republicans' excess death rate spiked after COVID-19 vaccines arrived, a study says
SUMMARY: After vaccines became widely available in 2021, "the excess death rate among Republican voters was 43% higher than the excess death rate among Democratic voters," Yale researchers say.

TITLE: Malaysia's a big draw for China's Belt and Road plans. Finishing them is another story
SUMMARY: The Malaysian East Coast Rail Link is a successful feat so far compared to some other Chinese investments in the country â even if it has blown past deadlines and budgets.

TITLE: NAACP's Ivory Toldson discusses the investigation into Harvard legacy admissions
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks to the NAACP's Ivory Toldson about the Department of Education's civil rights investigation into legacy admissions at Harvard University.

TITLE: Niger's presidential guard has detained President Bazoum, raising fears of a coup
SUMMARY: Soldiers from Niger's presidential guard have blockaded the presidential palace, and regional leaders have condemned the move as an "attempted coup."

TITLE: Rudy Giuliani concedes he made false statements against 2 Georgia election workers
SUMMARY: Giuliani submitted this declaration as part of the ongoing civil lawsuit filed in 2021 by election workers Ruby Freeman and Wandrea "Shaye" Moss. The two women sued Giuliani for defamation.

TITLE: With Florida ocean temperatures topping 100, experts warn of damage to marine life
SUMMARY: The startling 101.1 reading was recorded in Manatee Bay, near the Everglades National Park. The rising ocean temperatures, driven by climate change, are already endangering nearby coral, experts say.

TITLE: 'Gimme a break!' Biden blasts insurance hassles for mental health treatment
SUMMARY: President Joe Biden unveiled a set of new rules for health insurance companies designed to push the industry to cover treatment for mental health problems on par with how it covers medical care.

TITLE: Big carmakers unite to build a charging network and reassure reluctant EV buyers
SUMMARY: A lack of fast chargers for road trips is a major deterrent for would-be electric vehicle purchasers. In response, big automakers are following Tesla's playbook â and teaming up in an unusual way.

TITLE: Actor Kevin Spacey is acquitted in the U.K. on sexual assault charges
SUMMARY: A jury in London acquitted Spacey on Wednesday after 12 hours of deliberations. On hearing the verdict, Spacey wiped away tears and mouthed the words "thank you" to the jury.

TITLE: In Florida's local malaria outbreak, forgotten bite led to surprise hospitalization
SUMMARY: For the first time in two decades, the U.S. has evidence of local transmission of malaria. Most of the cases occurred in Florida's Sarasota County, which has stepped up mosquito suppression efforts.

TITLE: They put food on our tables but live in the shadows. This man is fighting to be seen
SUMMARY: Jose Martinez has picked America's food for decades. With all that experience on different farms, he saw workers lacking labor protections. Now he works to give farmworkers more rights.

TITLE: The FBI is investigating the alleged beating death of a disabled inmate in Virginia
SUMMARY: Charles Givens, an inmate at the Marion Correctional Treatment Center, was allegedly beaten to death by prison officers in 2022. His sister filed a federal lawsuit against the officers in February.

TITLE: Hep C has a secret strategy to evade the immune system. And now we know what it is
SUMMARY: How does the hepatitis C virus keep the immune system at bay? A scientist finds the answer â and it involves a standard technique used by villains.

TITLE: Judge says she's not ready to accept Hunter Biden's plea deal
SUMMARY: Judge Maryellen Noreika demanded that the lawyers from both sides make clear that the deal does not convey broad immunity offered to Biden from prosecution on his business dealings.

TITLE: Autoworker union not giving Biden an easy ride in 2024 as contract talks pick up speed
SUMMARY: The new UAW president says his members are being left out as the industry transitions to electric vehicles so he's applying pressure on the auto companies and the White House to do more for workers.

TITLE: A Texas A&M professor was suspended for allegedly criticizing lieutenant governor
SUMMARY: Joy Alonzo was suspended and investigated after she allegedly criticized Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick at a lecture on the opioid crisis. Free speech advocates call the probe "blatantly inappropriate."

TITLE: McConnell abruptly stops speaking at press conference
SUMMARY: On Capitol Hill, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell abruptly stopped speaking at a press conference with reporters on Wednesday. He was later escorted away but then returned, saying he's "fine."

TITLE: The Fed's hot pause summer gets an ice bath: Interest rates rise again
SUMMARY: After taking a pause last month, the Fed got back to raising interest rates. Many are now saying a "soft-landing" is within our sights

TITLE: Bowe Bergdahl's desertion conviction is voided by the appearance of bias under Trump
SUMMARY: A U.S. judge says the reversal shows "why individuals aspiring for public office and those achieving that objective" shouldn't call for a specific verdict in criminal cases.

TITLE: It's not your imagination. Teams at the Women's World Cup are playing longer games
SUMMARY: Referees have wide discretion to add extra game time due to injuries, substitutions and lengthy celebrations after goals. At this tournament, referees are tacking on a lot more than previous tourneys.

TITLE: Irish singer Sinead O'Connor has died at 56
SUMMARY: O'Connor, who had one of the biggest hits of the early 1990s with her version of "Nothing Compares 2 U," became as well known for her political convictions and the tumult in her life as for her songs.

TITLE: A Mississippi law limits who can help mail-in voters. A federal court struck it down
SUMMARY: Mississippi passed a law restricting who could help voters seeking assistance casting their ballots by mail. A federal judge ruled it limited access to the polls and was therefore not permitted.

TITLE: McConnell says he's 'fine' after abruptly stopping press conference
SUMMARY: On Capitol Hill, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell abruptly stopped speaking at a press conference with reporters on Wednesday. He was later escorted away but then returned, saying he's "fine."

TITLE: Prosecutors want disgraced crypto mogul Bankman-Fried in jail ahead of trial
SUMMARY: Bankman-Fried has been living under house arrest in his parents' home near the Stanford University campus since December. But his communications with reporters have gotten him in hot water.

TITLE: Whales beached in Australia are euthanized after rescue efforts fail
SUMMARY: After a pod of nearly 100 pilot whales beached themselves on Tuesday, more than 50 of them died overnight. Now officials say the remaining 47 will be euthanized.

TITLE: The three key moments in the U.S. tie with the Netherlands at the Women's World Cup
SUMMARY: The top-ranked & two-time defending champion U.S. played to a 1-1 draw with the Netherlands. It was the first tie for the U.S. at the Women's World Cup since 2015 and was a rematch of the 2019 final.

TITLE: Singapore set to execute first woman in nearly 20 years, rights groups say
SUMMARY: The announcement of the scheduled Friday execution of a woman comes as human rights groups say Singapore is out of step with the global trend of more countries moving away from capital punishment.

TITLE: America's farms are desperate for labor. Foreign workers bring relief and controversy
SUMMARY: The number of H-2A visas for seasonal farmworkers issued each year has more than quadrupled over the past decade. The growth has alarmed labor advocates. Farmers don't love the program, either.

TITLE: In Japan, a J-Pop star has come out as gay and his fans cheer
SUMMARY: Shinjiro Atae shared the personal revelation on Wednesday evening with an auditorium filled with thousands in Tokyo.

TITLE: Mattel tried to report financials. All anyone wanted to talk about was 'Barbie'
SUMMARY: Mattel reported financial earnings Wednesday. Impacts from the <em>Barbie

TITLE: Weighted infant sleepwear is meant to help babies rest better. Critics say it's risky
SUMMARY: Parents are increasingly turning to weighted sleepwear to help lull their babies to sleep, but a growing number of doctors and safe sleep advocates warn it comes with risks that shouldn't be ignored.

TITLE: His doctors billed Medicare late. Then he got sent to collections for the $3,000 tab
SUMMARY: Medicare was supposed to cover the entire cost of his procedure. But the anesthesia provider failed to file its claims in a timely manner and billed the patient instead.

TITLE: A doctor leaves a lasting impression on a woman caring for her dying mom
SUMMARY: When her mother was struggling with late-stage cancer, Julia had a conversation with a doctor that made her feel heard.

TITLE: Is Barbie a feminist icon? It's complicated
SUMMARY: The <em>Barbie

TITLE: Meta's Threads needs a policy for election disinformation, voting groups say
SUMMARY: Twelve voting rights organizations tell Meta its new social media site Threads needs a robust plan to ensure election disinformation doesn't go viral during the 2024 elections.

TITLE: They billed Medicare late for his anesthesia. He went to collections for a $3,000 tab
SUMMARY: Medicare was supposed to cover the entire cost of his procedure. But the anesthesia provider failed to file its claims in a timely manner and billed the patient instead.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Hunter Biden plea deal; coup in Niger, remembering Sinead O'Connor
SUMMARY: A judge has put a plea deal in the Hunter Biden case on hold. Niger's military announced a coup. Irish singer Sinead O'Connor has died at 56.

TITLE: Niger's military announces a coup on national television
SUMMARY: The U.S. is calling for the president of Niger to be released after soldiers say they have seized power in a coup in the West African country.

TITLE: U.S. recovered non-human 'biologics' from UFO crash sites, former intel official says
SUMMARY: Lawmakers heard first-hand accounts of craft that are "beyond our current understanding of our technology," and allegations that the U.S. recovered non-human "bio remains."

TITLE: What my $30 hamburger reveals about fees and how companies use them to jack up prices
SUMMARY: New fees are being tacked onto hotel bills, airfare, restaurant checks and pretty much everywhere else. It's another form of inflation and it's costing consumers $65 billion a year.

TITLE: Wait, do you need a visa to go to Europe now? The new ETIAS requirements, explained
SUMMARY: Starting in 2024, American passport holders traveling to 30 European countries will need to receive authorization to travel via the ETIAS, a long-awaited measure designed to prevent terrorism.

TITLE: Biden is rolling out some new actions aimed at protecting people from extreme heat
SUMMARY: On a very hot day in Washington, President Biden is meeting with mayors from cities grappling with the impacts of extreme heat, and announcing some new measures to try to help.

TITLE: Actors take to the internet to show their residual checks, with some in the negative
SUMMARY: The Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers rejected the SAG-AFTRA union's request for a separate type of residual payment that actors would get once their programs hit streaming services.

TITLE: Supreme Court OKs completion of Mountain Valley gas pipeline
SUMMARY: The case involved an emergency challenge to the final stages of development of the 303-mile pipeline, which is to span from northwestern West Virginia to southern Virginia.

TITLE: Here's why Niger's coup matters to the U.S.
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Antony Blinken warns the U.S. partnership with Niger depends on "democratic governance and respect for the rule of law." Niger is vital to U.S. counterterrorism efforts in Africa.

TITLE: Biden rolled out some new measures to respond to extreme heat as temperatures soar
SUMMARY: On a very hot day in Washington, President Biden met with mayors from two cities grappling with extreme heat, and announcing some new measures to try to help workers.

TITLE: Tornado damage to Pfizer factory highlights vulnerabilities of drug supply
SUMMARY: A tornado that ripped through a Pfizer plant in Rocky Mount, N.C., raised worries about shortages of medicines used in hospitals. The drugs include commonly used painkillers and anesthetics.

TITLE: New study shows just how Facebook's algorithm shapes conservative and liberal bubbles
SUMMARY: Research conducted at the height of the 2020 election reveals new details about how Facebook's algorithms handle political content. But it suggests there are no easy fixes to political polarization.

TITLE: 'Into the Bright Sunshine' spotlights the achievements of LBJ VP Hubert Humphrey
SUMMARY: Humphrey is remembered for his defense of an unpopular war in Vietnam, but author Sam Freedman says the former mayor of Minneapolis played a critical role in getting Democrats to embrace civil rights.

TITLE: DOJ launches an investigation into Memphis and the city's police department
SUMMARY: The Justice Department said its investigation will focus on the Memphis Police Department's use of force, its stops and arrests and whether the department engages in discriminatory policing.

TITLE: Why it's so important to figure out when a vital Atlantic Ocean current might collapse
SUMMARY: Scientists know a current in the Atlantic ocean could collapse suddenly as the climate changes. The question of when matters to billions of people around the globe.

TITLE: GM reverses its plans to halt Chevy Bolt EV production
SUMMARY: The popular electric vehicle was released in the 2017 model year and had to be recalled twice due to battery issues. General Motors plans to only make electric vehicles by 2035.

TITLE: After new law, Netanyahu vows to keep attorney general and return felon to office
SUMMARY: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will not interfere in his corruption trial, vowing to keep the country's attorney general in place. But he considers reappointing a convicted cabinet member.

TITLE: Trump charged with additional count in Mar-a-Lago documents case
SUMMARY: A new defendant was also added the indictment against Trump and his aide Walt Nauta. Carlos de Oliveira was added to the obstruction conspiracy charged in the original indictment.

TITLE: LeBron James' son is released from hospital days after suffering a cardiac arrest
SUMMARY: James committed to join the University of Southern California's basketball team in May. He was practicing with the team when he went into cardiac arrest.

TITLE: Dads may want to do more caretaking â but then face barriers, one study finds
SUMMARY: Fathers may want to take on more domestic and child care responsibilities, but gender norms and a lack of social support may discourage them from doing so, a new international study finds.

TITLE: With Russia dominating the Black Sea, Ukraine's navy tries to rebuild
SUMMARY: First, Russia wiped out Ukraine's navy. Now, Russia is blockading Ukraine's critical grain exports. As Ukraine tries to rebuild, NPR's Greg Myre got a ride on one of its few boats.

TITLE: Trump charged with additional counts in Mar-a-Lago documents case
SUMMARY: A new defendant was also added the indictment against Trump and his aide Walt Nauta. Carlos de Oliveira was added to the obstruction conspiracy charged in the original indictment.

TITLE: We promise this week's NPR news quiz isn't ALL about 'Barbie'
SUMMARY: Other things happened this week besides Barbenheimer. There are also questions about Twitter, Hunter Biden, and animals that continue to evade capture.

TITLE: As hazing lawsuits mount against Northwestern, experts hope for a shift in attitudes
SUMMARY: With allegations of hazing within several sports programs at Northwestern University, experts say that other U.S. universities should use this time to change their own cultures.

TITLE: What's a fair price for a prescription drug? Medicare's about to weigh in
SUMMARY: Medicare soon will start something it hasn't done in its 58-year history: Negotiate on drug prices. On Sept. 1, Medicare will target the first 10 drugs for price negotiations.

TITLE: Singapore has executed a woman for the first time in nearly two decades
SUMMARY: Singaporean national Saridewi Djamani, 45, was convicted in 2018 of trafficking over 30 grams of heroin. She is first woman to be hanged since 2004.

TITLE: Ukraine struggles to rebuild a navy destroyed by Russia
SUMMARY: First, Russia wiped out Ukraine's navy. Now, Moscow is blocking critical grain exports. As Ukraine tries to rebuild it's navy, and fight back, NPR's Greg Myre got a ride on one of its few boats.

TITLE: As these farmworkers' children seek a different future, who will pick the crops?
SUMMARY: U.S. farms have faced worker shortages for years. Now compounding the problem: The children of farmworkers are leaving the fields, forcing farm owners to look to other countries for labor.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Government shutdown looms; extreme heat and hospitals; losing a pet
SUMMARY: Congress and the Biden administration have until Sept. 30 to avoid a government shutdown. Hospitals deal with extreme heat. How to cope with losing a pet.

TITLE: Can states' bans on transgender care hold up in court? We break down the arguments
SUMMARY: The 20 gender-affirming care bans states have passed are undergoing intense legal scrutiny and testing federal courts in new ways, setting up battles that may go to the U.S. Supreme Court.

TITLE: House and Senate on a collision course toward a government shutdown (again)
SUMMARY: Some House GOP hard-liners say Speaker Kevin McCarthy shouldn't rule out a shutdown to achieve spending cuts and social policy changes sought by the far right of his party.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Extreme heat and hospitals; Trump faces new charges; summer reads
SUMMARY: Congress and the Biden administration have until Sept. 30 to avoid a government shutdown. Hospitals deal with extreme heat. How to cope with losing a pet.

TITLE: The 75th Emmy Awards show has been postponed
SUMMARY: The ceremony, scheduled for Sept. 18, has been cancelled due to the writers and actors' strikes. This year's nominees include Succession and Ted Lasso.

TITLE: A woman is running for mayor of Uvalde in honor of daughter killed in school shooting
SUMMARY: Kimberly Mata-Rubio says she hopes to reunite the community if elected. The town has been torn on how to move on after 19 children and two teachers were killed in the 2022 shooting at Robb Elementary.

TITLE: Randy Meisner, founding member of the Eagles, dies at 77
SUMMARY: Called "the sweetest man in the music business" by ex-bandmate Don Felder, Meisner joined Don Henley, Glenn Frey and Bernie Leadon in the early '70s to form one of the most popular acts in history.

TITLE: Biden implements sweeping changes to how the military handles sexual assault cases
SUMMARY: The reforms place serious criminal cases under the authority of trained prosecutors. Previously, key decisions had been left up to victims' own commanders.

TITLE: How can kids stay safe if they play outside in extreme heat?
SUMMARY: Little kids are like a "small potato" whose core can heat up faster than an adult's, an expert tells NPR. Here are tips for helping children stay safe in extreme temperatures.

TITLE: She is trying to get the U.S. to take extreme heat more seriously. Here's how
SUMMARY: Extreme heat killed more people in the U.S. last year than hurricanes, floods, lightning or tornadoes. One expert says it doesn't have to be this way.

TITLE: A pediatric neurosurgeon reflects on his intense job, and the post-Roe landscape
SUMMARY: Jay Wellons has operated on kids' brains and spinal cords. He writes about the anguish of losing a patient and the exhilaration of saving a life in <em>All That Moves Us. Originally broadcast July 2022.

TITLE: Here's how you can help kids stay healthy if they play outside in a heat wave
SUMMARY: Little kids are like a "small potato" whose core can heat up faster than an adult's, an expert tells NPR. Here are tips for helping children stay safe in extreme temperatures.

TITLE: Trump still leads the pack in Iowa. But other Republicans are hoping for an opening
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump maintains a double-digit lead over Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis in local polls, but Iowa party leaders say Trump has left an opening for his rivals to gain some ground.

TITLE: GOP support for Trump softens as the former president's legal troubles mount
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump is likely facing a third indictment and maybe a fourth. Fewer Republicans are saying Trump did "nothing wrong," the latest NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll finds.

TITLE: Carlee Russell is charged with kidnapping hoax
SUMMARY: It remains unclear why the 25-year-old Alabama nursing student fabricated a story of a stranded child and why she went missing for two days.

TITLE: The CDC sees signs of a late summer COVID wave
SUMMARY: In July, coronavirus infections, hospitalizations and emergency room visits inched up. Recent summers have seen a bump in COVID-19. This year's rise looks modest so far.

TITLE: The dreams and disappointments of India's Barbie
SUMMARY: The doll is very popular. But an Indian version of a dark-haired, sari-clad Barbie was not a big seller. And one woman has written a poem about what it felt like to grow up unable to afford a Barbie.

TITLE: Trader Joe's recalls its frozen falafel for possibly having rocks in it
SUMMARY: Trader Joe's said its falafel could have rocks in it. It issued recalls recently for two types of cookies it sells for the same reason.

TITLE: Biden administration proposes new fuel economy standards, with higher bar for trucks
SUMMARY: The proposal would increase fuel economy for cars by 2% annually â and twice as fast for trucks and SUVs. The rule would pair with the EPA's ambitious plan to promote electric vehicles.

TITLE: Backup driver of an autonomous Uber pleads guilty to endangerment in pedestrian death
SUMMARY: The backup driver for a self-driving vehicle that killed a pedestrian in suburban Phoenix in 2018 was sentenced to three years of supervised probation.

TITLE: A study estimates 800 great white sharks are swimming off the Cape Cod coast
SUMMARY: Great white shark populations have been difficult to track around Cape Cod due to the species' elusive nature and smaller populations, according to researchers.

TITLE: Biden has a 7th grandchild. But he's never acknowledged her, until now
SUMMARY: President Biden is known for his close relationship with his grandchildren. But he hadn't recognized a 4-year-old daughter of Hunter Biden from his family, until Friday.

TITLE: 'X' logo installed atop Twitter building, spurring San Francisco to investigate
SUMMARY: City officials say replacing letters or symbols on buildings requires a permit for design and safety reasons. The installation is part of Elon Musk's effort to rebrand the social media platform.

TITLE: Soldiers declare Niger general as head of state following coup
SUMMARY: Mutinous soldiers who staged a coup in Niger declared their leader, Gen. Abdourahmane Tchiani, the new head of state on Friday. A spokesman also said that the constitution was suspended.

TITLE: Forecasters say Southwest temperatures to ease some with arrival of monsoon rains
SUMMARY: Forecasters expect that by Monday at the latest, people in metro Phoenix will begin seeing high temperatures under 110 degrees Fahrenheit for the first time in a month.

TITLE: In Peru, discovery of ancient ruins outpaces authorities' ability to care for them
SUMMARY: "Everywhere you dig, you will find something â because Lima was home to great civilizations," says a museum director in the capital. "But it's impossible to save everything in a poor country."

TITLE: Presidential primaries have seen dramatic comebacks. Could DeSantis '24 be next?
SUMMARY: Using the phrase "comeback kid" helped Bill Clinton revive his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination in the 1992 New Hampshire primary. Could Ron DeSantis revive that model?

TITLE: As NYC limits access to migrants and asylum seekers, many are left homeless
SUMMARY: New York City officials say they are overwhelmed by an influx of asylum seekers. Hundreds of immigrants are crowded into at least one detention center.

TITLE: 4 air crew members are missing after an Australian army helicopter ditched off coast
SUMMARY: Officials said the incident happened during joint military exercises with the U.S. A search involving U.S., Canadian and Australian personnel was underway to find the crew who are all Australian men.

TITLE: What recession? It's a summer of splurging, profits and girl power
SUMMARY: Economic data show higher prices and constant warnings of a downturn haven't slowed down American shoppers. The Fed is anxious. Companies are thrilled.

TITLE: Mega Millions jackpot passes $1 billion after no one draws all 6 winning numbers
SUMMARY: The next drawing for the grand prize, which is equal to the fourth-largest Mega Millions jackpot to date, is Tuesday. Just last week, a winning ticket for a $1.08 billion Powerball drawing was sold.

TITLE: After rebranding, X took @x from its original Twitter owner and offered him merch
SUMMARY: Gene X Hwang owned @x on Twitter. Until Elon Musk rebranded the platform and took the handle.

TITLE: A WWII Japanese soldier's 'good luck flag' is returned to his family from U.S. museum
SUMMARY: The flag belonging to Shigeyoshi Mutsuda was returned to his son from a U.S. war museum where it had been on display for 29 years. "It's a miracle," 83-year-old Toshihiro Mutsuda said.

TITLE: Rep. Van Orden gets bipartisan scolding after he cursed at teen Senate pages
SUMMARY: GOP and Democratic lawmakers alike condemned the Wisconsin Republican after he spewed profanities at a group of Senate pages taking photos at the Capitol.

TITLE: Almost nothing has come from all the talk about states banning drag in front of kids
SUMMARY: Across the country, efforts by state Republicans to restrict drag performances in front of kids have fallen short. Bills have been scuttled, blocked, vetoed and more.

TITLE: Katie Ledecky passes Michael Phelps for most individual golds at world championships
SUMMARY: The 26-year-old American won the 800-meter freestyle on Saturday at the world championships to become the first swimmer to win six golds in the same event at worlds.

TITLE: Despite all the talk, no states have active laws banning drag in front of kids
SUMMARY: Across the country, efforts by state Republicans to restrict drag performances in front of kids have fallen short. Bills have been scuttled, blocked, vetoed and more.

TITLE: In a first, the U.S. picks an Indigenous artist for a solo show at the Venice Biennale
SUMMARY: The U.S. State Department selected Jeffrey Gibson to create an installation for the U.S. Pavilion at the prestigious international arts event.

TITLE: 4 dead and 2 injured in separate aircraft accidents in Wisconsin, authorities say
SUMMARY: A Rotorway 162F helicopter and an ELA Eclipse 10 gyrocopter collided at Wittman Regional Airport in Oshkosh, authorities said.

TITLE: An Arkansas judge has blocked a law targetting librarians over 'harmful' books
SUMMARY: Arkansas is temporarily blocked from enforcing a law that would have allowed criminal charges against librarians and booksellers for providing "harmful" materials to minors.

TITLE: A drone attack on Moscow briefly shut the airport and injured one
SUMMARY: Russian authorities say three Ukrainian drones attacked Moscow in the early hours on Sunday, injuring one person and prompting a temporary closure for traffic of one of four airports near the capital.

TITLE: African leaders leave Russia summit without grain deal or path to peace in Ukraine
SUMMARY: African leaders are leaving two days of meetings with Vladimir Putin with little to show for their requests to resume a deal that kept grain flowing from Ukraine and to find a path to end the war.

TITLE: The historic heatwave that has hit the U.S. Southwest is set to cool a little
SUMMARY: A historic heat wave that has gripped the U.S. Southwest throughout July, blasting residents and baking surfaces like brick, is beginning to abate with the late arrival of monsoon rains.

TITLE: A worm that survived 46,000 years in permafrost wows scientists
SUMMARY: A nematode found deep in frozen sediment has proven its ability to survive extreme environments long term. Scientists studying the species say their work could inform the protection of other animals.

TITLE: In broiling cities like New Orleans, the health system faces off against heat stroke
SUMMARY: Like other places, New Orleans has seen record numbers of people falling ill with heat-related conditions. First responders and hospitals race to respond with ice, fluids, and air conditioning.

TITLE: As living memories of the Korean War fade, its consequences become clearer
SUMMARY: As most Korean War vets are well into their 90s, they still struggle with America's perceptions of what has been called "the Forgotten War."

TITLE: Supporters of Niger's coup march, waving Russian flags and denouncing France
SUMMARY: Thousands of supporters of the junta that took over Niger in a coup  this week marched through the streets of the capital waving Russian flags, chanting Vladimir Putin's name, and denouncing France.

TITLE: This Ivy League researcher says spirituality is good for our mental health

TITLE: Opera singer David Daniels pleads guilty in sexual assault trial
SUMMARY: The world-renowned countertenor and his husband were accused of drugging and raping a young singer in 2010.

TITLE: An appeals court blocks Mississippi's permanent ban on voting after certain felonies
SUMMARY: Mississippi is violating the U.S. Constitution by permanently stripping voting rights from people convicted of some felonies, a divided federal appeals court panel ruled. The state plans to appeal.

TITLE: Texas abortion bans lifted temporarily for medical emergencies, judge rules
SUMMARY: A Texas judge is temporarily blocking the state's abortion bans from being enforced against doctors who perform abortions in cases of medical emergencies and fetal anomalies.

TITLE: Noted defense attorney Charles Ogletree dies

TITLE: DOJ asks judge to issue protective order after Trump posts apparent threat of revenge
SUMMARY: The DOJ asked a federal judge overseeing the criminal case against former President Trump to step in after he released a post online that appeared to promise revenge on anyone who goes after him.

SUMMARY: Hundreds of participants have been treated for heat-related ailments since the Jamboree began Wednesday in the coastal town of Buan as South Korea grapples with one of its hottest summers in years.

TITLE: Pakistani police arrest former Prime Minister Imran Khan after court conviction
SUMMARY: Earlier Saturday, a court convicted Khan in an asset concealment case, handing down a prison sentence that could see him barred from politics.

TITLE: Across South Asia, this sweet drink is synonymous with summertime refreshment
SUMMARY: Invented in 1907 to beat the effects of extreme heat, Rooh Afza â a ruby-red, plant-based concentrate â is diluted with water, milk or ice and is a summertime favorite in India, Pakistan and beyond.

TITLE: Trump's defense in 2020 election case could conjure ghost of Nixon once more
SUMMARY: How far could a president go to stay in office if convinced his re-election was crucial to the nation?  What liability would he face? And how much stress can the fragile structure of democracy stand?

TITLE: Should Trump's trial be televised?
SUMMARY: There would need to be an exception to a rule barring cameras and microphones in federal courtrooms to make it happen, but House Democrats and Trump's own lawyer are pushing for a televised trial.

TITLE: Imran Khan, former prime minister of Pakistan, arrested following court conviction

SUMMARY: Friday night's jackpot was already a whopping $1.35 billion, but since there again was no winner the next one could break the $1.537 billion record set in 2018.

TITLE: The FDA approves the first pill specifically intended to treat postpartum depression
SUMMARY: The Food and Drug Administration granted approval of the drug, Zurzuvae, for adults experiencing severe depression related to childbirth or pregnancy. The pill is taken once a day for 14 days.

SUMMARY: The monoclonal antibody drug prevents the lung infection that puts 58,000 to 80,000 young children in the hospital each year.

TITLE: AP psychology class may be available to Florida students after all

TITLE: S. Korea presses on with World Scout Jamboree as heat forces thousands to leave early
SUMMARY: Hundreds of participants have been treated for heat-related ailments since the Jamboree began Wednesday in the coastal town of Buan as South Korea grapples with one of its hottest summers in years.

SUMMARY: The former Arkansas governor and 2024 presidential candidate who is critical of the former president is struggling in the polls. He sees voters not dwelling on Trump but focused on other issues.

SUMMARY: The protective order would limit what information the former president could share publicly about the ongoing criminal case related to the 2020 presidential election.

TITLE: Some states are trying to boost youth voter registration. Here's what they're doing
SUMMARY: More states are adopting policies to increase voter registration, including for young people. Those policies include automatic voter registration and pre-registration before age 18.

TITLE: This writer shares the right (and wrong) ways to honor Indigenous spirituality

SUMMARY: The artist quit music in the early '60s, then later disappeared so completely even her family didn't know where she'd gone. Now, an album of her songs â as she wanted them heard â is coming out.

SUMMARY: An exhibit in New York explores a little-known chapter of World War II.

SUMMARY: Elon Musk said X, formerly known as Twitter, said there is "no limit" on how much the company is willing to pay.

SUMMARY: Ten cars of a Rawalpindi-bound train derailed and some overturned, near the Pakistani town of Nawabshah, trapping many passengers, said a senior railway official.

SUMMARY: Brian Houston was ruled not guilty Thursday of an Australian charge of concealing his father's child sex crimes. He resigned from his church roles after being charged two years ago.

TITLE: 'Suits' just set a streaming record years after it ended. Here's what's going on

TITLE: New York City officially bans TikTok on all government devices
SUMMARY: City employees will begin to lose access to TikTok and its website from all city-owned devices and networks, according to a New York City Hall spokesperson.

TITLE: USC study reveals Hollywood studios are still lagging when it comes to inclusivity
SUMMARY: A new University of Southern California report pinpoints areas that need improvement â as well as a few small wins.

TITLE: Trump lawyers ask to push back federal election subversion trial to April 2026
SUMMARY: The suggested April 2026 date is a counterproposal to the Justice Department's recommendation last week that the trial should begin Jan. 2, 2024.

TITLE: The embattled leader of Maui County's Emergency Management Agency has resigned
SUMMARY: Herman Andaya has faced increasing scrutiny following last week's fires in Lahaina that killed more than 110 people. He's defended his decision not to activate emergency sirens as the town burned.

SUMMARY: Citing errors by police, a Mississippi judge declared a mistrial Thursday in the case of two white men accused of chasing and shooting at a Black FedEx driver who was making a delivery.

TITLE: Trump cancels press conference on election fraud claims, citing attorneys' advice
SUMMARY: No compelling evidence of the wide-scale fraud Trump alleges has emerged in the two-and-a-half years since the election in Georgia or elsewhere, despite Trump's baseless claims.

TITLE: A 4% income tax on millionaires will make lunch free for Massachusetts K-12 students
SUMMARY: Massachusetts voters approved the Fair Share Amendment in November. It places a 4% tax on incomes above $1 million, in addition to the state's standard income tax of 5%.

SUMMARY: As people grapple with more than 100 people who died in the Lahaina fire on Maui, they're still trying to understand the loss of priceless artifacts and their connections to the island's ancient past.

SUMMARY: While the world focuses on the devastation in West Maui and the destruction of the historic community of Lahaina, another wildfire is still burning in the hills some 25 miles away in Kula.

TITLE: Are you a Trump indictment expert by now? Test yourself in this week's news quiz
SUMMARY: Sinister-looking orbs and cosmic question marks haunted the news. There was also a fourth indictment for a certain former president. Were you paying attention?

TITLE: Rural voters shaping the GOP presidential turn against U.S. aid to Ukraine
SUMMARY: Populist politicians and right-wing media have convinced many voters that US aid for Ukraine is a waste of money. Domestic problems should take precedent, they say.

TITLE: How Biden is using Camp David to elevate a summit with Japan and South Korea

SUMMARY: New York's Adirondack Park used to be a political powder keg. Now factions are working to find common ground, while tackling some big problems.

TITLE: Taiwan's companies make the world's electronics. Now they want to make weapons
SUMMARY: As military tensions with China rise, Taiwan's companies are pivoting from civilian manufacturing to defense and weapons.

TITLE: Indoor pollution can make you sick. Here's how to keep your home's air clean
SUMMARY: Poor air quality can drive you indoors, but do you know what you're breathing inside your home? Here's the latest on optimizing ventilation and other air-clearing strategies.

TITLE: A mother raced to save her son from the Maui fires. She couldn't reach him
SUMMARY: When everyone was trying to escape the flames in Lahaina, Luz Vargas ran toward them: Her son was home alone. Days later she found his body. Sunday would have been his 15th birthday.

SUMMARY: The devastating fires on Maui burned more than 2,000 homes and buildings in Lahaina. Many churches have taken in their congregants because they have nowhere to go.

TITLE: The U.S. imports most of its solar panels. A new ruling may make that more expensive
SUMMARY: The Commerce Department says solar panel makers in four Southeast Asian countries are evading U.S. duties on Chinese solar components. The finding could raise costs in the United States.

TITLE: Hilary could be the first tropical storm to hit California in more than 80 years
SUMMARY: Hurricane Hilary will make landfall in Mexico's Baja California  this weekend before weakening to a tropical storm. But torrential rain could cause dangerous flash flooding in Southern California.

SUMMARY: Some far-right websites are circulating addresses supposedly of grand jurors involved in the Fulton County indictment of former President Donald Trump. Their calls for violence are causing alarm.

TITLE: Three 6 Mafia turns $4500 into $45 million with Mystic Stylez
SUMMARY: In 1995, the Memphis hip-hop group Three 6 Mafia took a shoestring DIY approach to recording their debut album, <em>Mystic Stylez.

SUMMARY: In many ways â setting, historical elements, the mix of romance and horror, the use of Spanish â Vampires of El Norte is the spiritual sister of The Hacienda

SUMMARY: In preparing for future fires, Maui doesn't have to look far. States like California have passed wildfire policies to reduce the risk that a community will be destroyed.

SUMMARY: If the guy skeeters can't hear the buzz of females ... no mating, no new generation. The results of a study on mosquito hearing could lead to a different kind of population control tool.

SUMMARY: The International Chess Federation will stop allowing transgender women to participate in women's tournaments. The group said changing genders has a "significant impact" on a player's status.

SUMMARY: South America has seen a quarter million cases this year, as climate change is a boon for the mosquitoes that spread it. A study about how the virus infects cells could help inform future treatments.

SUMMARY: This summer has already been awfully hot in the southern Plains and the Gulf Coast. Now, a large portion of the U.S. will face a prolonged period of dangerous heat.

SUMMARY: In 1995, the Memphis hip-hop group Three 6 Mafia took a shoestring DIY approach to recording their debut album, <em>Mystic Stylez.

SUMMARY: The family-owned Marion County Record stands out for holding local officials accountable. That role is becoming increasingly rare as local newspapers vanish across the county.

SUMMARY: Corporate DEI positions soared after the murder of George Floyd in 2020. Now, due to economic pressure and political pressure from the right, they face an uncertain future.

SUMMARY: Hurricane Hilary continues her march toward Baja California, and people on both sides of the U.S.-Mexico border are getting ready for projected heavy rains and flooding.

SUMMARY: After years of pressure to set the Miami Seaquarium orca free, Lolita was scheduled to spend her final days in her natural habitat sometime next year. On Friday, she died of a "renal condition."

SUMMARY: Hurricane Hilary continues her march to Baja California, and people on both sides of the U.S.-Mexico border are getting ready for projected heavy rains and flooding.

SUMMARY: A wind-driven wildfire in eastern Washington state has destroyed at least 185 structures, closed a major highway and left one person dead, authorities said Saturday.

SUMMARY: Hilary is expected to weaken before it reaches Southern California, but heavy rain associated with the system still poses serious threat of "catastrophic and life-threatening flooding" in the region.

SUMMARY: Hilary is expected to weaken before it reaches Southern California, but heavy rain associated with the system still poses serious threat of "catastrophic and life-threatening flooding" in the region.

SUMMARY: Genesis Owusu has won just about every award he could in his home country of Australia with his debut album. Now with album number two, he's ready to take on America.

SUMMARY: Republicans are looking at a crowded field to challenge President Biden for the 2024 presidential election and most will face off on a Milwaukee stage Wednesday night for the first GOP debate.

SUMMARY: A cable car carrying six children and two adults dangled hundreds of feet above the ground in a remote part of Pakistan after it broke. Rescuers have arrived in helicopters to try to free them.

SUMMARY: Over the past 20 years, Kevin Ford from Las Vegas virtually never took a sick day because his job didn't offer paid sick leave. People across social media chipped in for him to finally afford a break.

TITLE: Anger in Spain after soccer chief kisses a player at Women's World Cup ceremony
SUMMARY: A furor erupted after Luis Rubiales kissed player Jennifer Hermoso at a ceremony. "It was an unacceptable gesture and Mr. Rubiales' apologies are not enough," the acting prime minister said.

TITLE: UPS workers approve 5-year contract, capping contentious negotiations

TITLE: Ethiopia to investigate report of killings of its nationals at the Saudi-Yemen border
SUMMARY: The Ethiopian government said it will investigate a report of killings of hundreds its nationals at the Yemen-Saudi border. A Saudi government official rejected the Human Rights Watch report.

TITLE: Maui's number of people not accounted for after fires rises back above 1,000
SUMMARY: "I know it is confusing, because the numbers do change," FBI Special Agent in Charge Steven Merrill said on Tuesday.

SUMMARY: After a classmate was killed in his hometown of Bakhmut â the longest and bloodiest battle in Russia's war on Ukraine â a rescue worker volunteered to evacuate people from the front lines.

SUMMARY: Over 6,000 octopuses have been found huddling around an extinct volcano deep in the Pacific Ocean near California, and researchers now think they understand why the octopuses find it so cozy.

TITLE: Rudy Giuliani surrenders in Georgia to face election interference charges
SUMMARY: Rudy Giuliani has surrendered in Atlanta to be booked as part of county prosecutors' investigation into efforts to overturn the 2020 election in Georgia. Giuliani faces 13 felony counts.

TITLE: The viral song 'Rich Men North of Richmond' made its way to the RNC debate stage
SUMMARY: The breakout song by an artist who goes by Oliver Anthony laid the groundwork to open the first Republican presidential debate for the 2024 election. But the song has notes of conspiracy theories.

TITLE: North Korea says its 2nd attempt to launch a spy satellite has failed
SUMMARY: The failed launch prompted neighboring Japan to issue brief a "J-alert" ordering some residents to evacuate to safe places as the North Korean rocket flew over its southernmost islands of Okinawa.

TITLE: Trump is likely to finally get a real mug shot. Does it matter?
SUMMARY: The Fulton County sheriff says he'll treat the former president according to the jail's normal practices. That includes taking a booking photo, which could become a famous â or infamous â image.

TITLE: This summer has been a scorcher. DHS wants communities to plan for more of them
SUMMARY: The administration is releasing new suggested guidelines for states and local communities on how to protect against extreme temperatures.

TITLE: How Florida's congressional map could change before the 2024 elections
SUMMARY: Black voters in Florida could regain a congressional district where they make up a sizable share of the population, if voting rights groups prevail in an ongoing legal battle.

TITLE: 5 things to know about Japan's Fukushima water release in the Pacific
SUMMARY: The water comes from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant. Although most scientists agree it does not pose an immediate environmental threat, some are worried about the long-term consequences.

TITLE: 'Miracle house' owner hopes it will serve as a base for rebuilding Lahaina
SUMMARY: "There was a neighbor who sent a note to us and said, 'Oh, you won the lottery,'" Trip Millikin, whose house survived, told NPR. "And I almost wanted to throw up when I got that."

TITLE: New flame retardants found in breast milk years after similar chemicals were banned
SUMMARY: After a class of flame retardants called PBDEs was phased out due to links with developmental health issues, manufacturers started using another, similar group of compounds.

TITLE: Schools could be getting millions more from Medicaid. Why aren't they?
SUMMARY: In 2022, schools recouped $6.6 billion dollars from federal and state Medicaid programs. They could be getting much more.

TITLE: 5 takeaways from the first Republican primary debate
SUMMARY: The first Republican debate of the 2024 election cycle is in the books. Without the frontrunner on stage, each candidate had the opportunity to grab the spotlight, though some had more of an impact.

TITLE: A 'shocking' 911 call and other key takeaways from NPR's ICE detention investigation
SUMMARY: NPR obtained secret government inspection reports, which described "negligent," "barbaric" and "filthy" conditions inside immigration detention facilities. Here's what to know.

TITLE: Iran, Saudi Arabia and Egypt are among 6 nations set to join the BRICS economic bloc
SUMMARY: Iran and Saudi Arabia are among 6 nations invited Thursday to join the BRICS bloc of developing economies. United Arab Emirates, Argentina, Egypt and Ethiopia are also set to join the bloc from 2024.

TITLE: At a time of anti-trans sentiment, a New York lawsuit brings hope for the community
SUMMARY: Makyyla Holland reached a settlement over abuse she says she suffered in New York's Broome County Jail. The settlement requires the jail to adopt a policy that houses inmates based on gender identity.

TITLE: Billy McFarland went to prison for Fyre Fest. Are his plans for a reboot legal?
SUMMARY: The controversial entrepreneur is seeking redemption and some people are ready for him to try. Tickets have sold out. But he still owes $26 million in restitution to the people he fleeced.

TITLE: Up First briefing: GOP debate, Trump to surrender, Russia plane crash mystery
SUMMARY: Republican presidential candidates faced off in the first GOP debate yesterday. Trump is expected to surrender in Georgia today. The leader of Russia's Wagner Group is presumed dead in a plane crash.

TITLE: Worries over seafood safety mount as Japan releases Fukushima water into the Pacific
SUMMARY: Local fishermen and the government of neighboring China are among the critics of Japan's decision to release water from the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant into the Pacific Ocean.

TITLE: FIFA opens disciplinary proceedings against Spain's soccer chief after World Cup kiss
SUMMARY: A union speaking for Jenni Hermoso, the player who was kissed, called for "intervention in the face of sexual harassment or abuse." Spain's soccer federation scheduled an emergency meeting on Friday.

TITLE: Ronan Farrow says Elon Musk has become an 'arbiter' of the war in Ukraine
SUMMARY: The <em>New Yorker

TITLE: What we know â and don't â about the Russian crash that possibly killed Prigozhin
SUMMARY: Yevgeny Prigozhin, leader of the Wagner mercenary group, appeared on the passenger list of a business jet that crashed Wednesday in Russia. Beyond that, little is clear.

TITLE: Trump ally Mark Meadows turns himself in after Georgia election indictment
SUMMARY: Former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows has turned himself in to face charges as part of the case targeting Donald Trump and his allies for attempting to subvert Georgia's 2020 election.

TITLE: The rise of Oliver Anthony and 'Rich Men North of Richmond'
SUMMARY: Audiences may have only just learned about a fast-rising country singer during the Republican debate Wednesday night. But "Rich Men North of Richmond" also has ties to extremist narratives.

TITLE: A go bag is an essential tool during natural disasters. Here's how to build your own.
SUMMARY: Natural disasters can happen anywhere with little to no notice. FEMA and the Red Cross say everybody should have an emergency go bag prepared.

TITLE: T-Mobile is laying off 5,000 employees
SUMMARY: The telecommunications company said it wants to eliminate roles that are too similar to each other and don't align with the company's current priorities.

TITLE: Maui County sues Hawaiian Electric Company for damages from disastrous fires
SUMMARY: The civil suit filed Thursday seeks a jury trial and "punitive and exemplary damages" to recoup costs and loss of revenue from the deadly wildfires.

TITLE: Sandwich chain Subway will be sold to fast-food investor Roark Capital
SUMMARY: Private equity firm Roark specializes in franchised businesses and backs two holding companies that own multiple restaurant chains that include Arby's, Jimmy John's and Cinnabon.

TITLE: Beyond the jabs, Wisconsin voters craved specifics from first GOP primary debate
SUMMARY: Wisconsin voters took in the barbs, slams and jabs at a GOP debate watch party in downtown Milwaukee Wednesday night. But they were left with major policy questions.

TITLE: Judge in Trump trial has a tough sentencing record in Jan. 6 cases
SUMMARY: Judge Tanya Chutkan knows her way around a courtroom after years as a public defender. Now her rulings will be on international display in the Jan. 6 case against the former president.

TITLE: These are 5 ways surging mortgage rates are reshaping the housing market
SUMMARY: The housing market is showing a split: Sales of existing homes were down last month, but sales of newly built houses were up.

TITLE: Where the GOP primary stands, with Trump still front and center
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump skipped the debate and turned himself into Georgia police this week. Still, he's way ahead of his primary opponents and coasting toward the nomination.

TITLE: 'All we want is revenge': How social media fuels gun violence among teens
SUMMARY: Teens share photos or videos of themselves with guns and cash, sometimes calling out rivals, on social media. When posts go viral, fueled by "likes" and comments, the danger is hard to contain.

TITLE: Climate change made it in the GOP debate. Some young Republicans say that's a win
SUMMARY: Climate change is a top issue for young voters across political parties, but most of the Republican presidential candidates avoided the question.

TITLE: Weekly news quiz: From mug shots and debate insults to meme dogs and a giraffe baby
SUMMARY: Trump got booked. An internet dog crossed the Rainbow Bridge. There's a kiss, a moon landing, a breakup and a monster hunt. Have you been paying attention?

TITLE: Millions of children need aid a year after Pakistan's devastating floods, UNICEF says
SUMMARY: Dozens of countries and institutions pledged more than $9 billion to help Pakistan rebuild from last summer's floods. But most of the pledges are for project loans still in the planning stages.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Trump's busy week; extremism in a hit song; 'miracle' Lahaina house
SUMMARY: From counterprogramming for a GOP debate to a booking on charges in Georgia, Trump had a busy week. A hit country song raises extremism red flags. A "miracle house" stands unscathed in Lahaina.

TITLE: 388: The number of people unaccounted for in Maui fire falls by more than half
SUMMARY: The latest revision came after Hawaii Gov. Josh Green said the FBI was working to "un-duplicate" people who were reported missing.

TITLE: For Trump, X marks the spot for his social media return. Why that could really matter
SUMMARY: Trump posted again for the first time in three years since being banned from various social media, taking to X, the platform formerly known as Twitter to post his mugshot.

TITLE: Young professionals are turning to AI to create headshots. But there are catches
SUMMARY: Generative artificial intelligence is helping some young professionals create realistic headshots for a fraction of the price. The results, however, raise questions about how AI is trained.

TITLE: Maui County sues Hawaiian Electric Co. for damages from disastrous fires
SUMMARY: The civil suit filed Thursday seeks a jury trial and "punitive and exemplary damages" to recoup costs and loss of revenue from the deadly wildfires.

TITLE: Fed Chair Jerome Powell warns the fight against inflation is far from over
SUMMARY: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said interest rates could stay elevated for an extended period to bring inflation to the central bank's 2% target.

TITLE: Smoke from Canadian wildfires sent more asthma sufferers to the emergency room
SUMMARY: Centers for Disease Control studies increased asthma-related ER visits by 17% nationwide during 19 of the smokiest days. On the worst air quality day in New York state, those visits spiked 82%.

TITLE: The Kremlin denies causing the plane crash thought to have killed Prigozhin
SUMMARY: The Kremlin is dismissing allegations that Russian President Vladimir Putin was behind the apparent death of Wagner mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin in a plane crash.

TITLE: Lahaina wants closure. Authorities plead for patience
SUMMARY: Search and recovery teams say the work to identify human remains in Lahaina is grueling and complicated by the fact that the fire burned so hot, even just making a positive ID is difficult.

TITLE: In 'Golda,' Helen Mirren portrays the only woman to serve as Israel's prime minister
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep talks to Guy Nattiv, director of the new Golda Meir biopic<em> Golda

TITLE: The Justice Department is suing SpaceX for allegedly not hiring refugees and asylees
SUMMARY: The agency says SpaceX often said in its marketing materials for open jobs they couldn't hire U.S. citizens because of export control laws. But asylees and refugees are protected under those laws.

TITLE: 'Golda' depicts a key moment in Israeli history. Its director sees parallels to today
SUMMARY: The biopic <em>Golda

TITLE: Women's World Cup champs say they won't play for Spain until soccer chief is removed
SUMMARY: Spain's government and FIFA have begun disciplinary proceedings against Luis Rubiales for his non-consensual kiss of player Jenni Hermoso at the tournament final. Rubiales is refusing to resign.

TITLE: Coronavirus FAQs: How worrisome is the new variant? How long do boosters last?
SUMMARY: Readers are curious about the new variant, currently known a BA.2.86. Also: Lots of questions about boosters. Can you get it at the same time as a flu shot? And how long does protection last?

TITLE: Where the GOP primary stands, with Trump still front and center
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump skipped the debate and turned himself into Georgia police this week. Still, he's way ahead of his primary opponents and coasting toward the nomination.

TITLE: Maui officials release 388 names of people unaccounted for in Maui fire
SUMMARY: The names were released after Hawaii Gov. Josh Green said the FBI was working to "un-duplicate" people who were reported missing.

TITLE: SpaceX launches 11th crewed mission as it heads to the International Space Station
SUMMARY: The four members of the Crew-7 mission are set to dock to the International Space Station on Sunday. They'll spend six months on the orbiting outpost conducting science and other experiments.

TITLE: The Freedom Caucus' shutdown threat recalls tactics of past House rebels
SUMMARY: The hardline Republicans want to shift the focus of Congress to their own agenda of opposing, investigating and even impeaching the president or members of his administration.

TITLE: AI is biased. The White House is working with hackers to try to fix that
SUMMARY: The White House is concerned that AI can perpetuate discrimination. So they helped host a red-teaming challenge at the Def Con hacker convention in Las Vegas to help figure out some of the flaws.

SUMMARY: Since the fire residents have gotten multiple calls from realtors offering to buy their land. Activists want a role in planning, to keep developers from pushing out those who call Lahaina home.

SUMMARY: Commerce Secretary GIna Raimondo is set to travel to China at a time when U.S. executives and investors are facing increasing uncertainty and risk doing business there.

TITLE: Armed with traffic cones, protesters are immobilizing driverless cars
SUMMARY: Self-driving cars have flooded San Francisco's streets, and not everyone is happy. Street activists have been using a low-tech solution to incapacitate the vehicles.

TITLE: Spain's soccer chief Luis Rubiales is temporarily suspended after World Cup kiss
SUMMARY: FIFA suspended Rubiales on Saturday while it investigates his conduct at the Women's World Cup medal ceremony. The Spanish Soccer Federation said Rubiales plans to prove his innocence.

TITLE: Longtime 'Price Is Right' host Bob Barker dies at 99
SUMMARY: For 35 years, Barker was a familiar presence in the living rooms of everyone from little old ladies, to kids home sick from school. He used his fame to promote another great passion: animal rights.

TITLE: Islamic State group almost doubled its territory in Mali in under a year, U.N. says
SUMMARY: Islamic State extremists have almost doubled the territory they control in Mali in less than a year, United Nations experts said in a new report.

TITLE: 'Multiple' people killed, including shooter, in Jacksonville dollar store shooting
SUMMARY: A shooter killed multiple people inside a Jacksonville, Fla., Dollar General store on Saturday, the mayor's office confirmed to NPR.

SUMMARY: A gunman opened fire at a Dollar General in Jacksonville, Fla., on Saturday, killing three people before taking his own life. Police described the shooting as a "racially motivated" hate crime.

TITLE: Thousands march to mark the 60th anniversary of MLK's 'I Have a Dream' speech
SUMMARY: Decades after the 1963 March on Washington, thousands again gathered in the nation's capital to declare that Martin Luther King Jr.'s legacy was in jeopardy amid fresh civil rights struggles.

TITLE: 3 people are injured, 1 critically, in a US military aircraft crash in Australia
SUMMARY: Three United States military personnel were taken to a hospital, one with critical injuries, after a U.S. aircraft crashed on a north Australian island Sunday during a  military exercise.

TITLE: Zimbabwe's electoral commission says President Mnangagwa has won a second term
SUMMARY: Zimbabwean President Emmerson Mnangagwa was re-elected for a second and final five-year term on Saturday, in results announced much earlier than expected in another troubled vote in the country.

TITLE: Several injured, 1 critically, in a US military aircraft crash in Australia
SUMMARY: Three United States military personnel were taken to a hospital, one with critical injuries, after a U.S. aircraft crashed on a north Australian island Sunday during a  military exercise.

TITLE: Minnesota returns voting power to thousands. The question is whether they'll use it
SUMMARY: A new law in Minnesota speeds up restoration of voting eligibility to the formerly incarcerated. Now advocates are fanning out to convince people to use those rights.

TITLE: A groundbreaking exhibition on the National Mall shows monuments aren't set in stone
SUMMARY: The first official outdoor exhibition on Washington D.C.'s National Mall showcases six artists whose monuments honor American stories missing from the heart of the country's capitol.

TITLE: 3 US Marines killed, 20 injured in an aircraft crash in Australia, officials say
SUMMARY: A United States Marine Corps aircraft crashed on a north Australian island Sunday, killing three Marines and injuring 20 during a multi-nation training exercise, officials said.

TITLE: Love, war and loss: How one soldier in Ukraine hopes to be made whole again
SUMMARY: An artillery shell should have killed Andrii Smolenskyi in May. Instead, the blast tore off both of his arms above the elbow and destroyed his eyes. Now he's fighting to put his life back together.

SUMMARY: Russia's Investigative Committee has said it has confirmed that Yevgeny Prigozhin, founder and head of the mercenary force Wagner, who led a short-lived armed rebellion, was killed in a plane crash.

TITLE: COMIC: In the '90s I survived summers in Egypt with no AC. How would it feel now?
SUMMARY: In elementary school, NPR's Malaka Gharib visited her dad in Cairo each summer. It was hot, there was no AC â but she coped. In this age of global warming, she wonders: How are Egyptians getting by?

TITLE: Sheriff says the Jacksonville dollar store shooter who killed 3 'hated Black people'
SUMMARY: A man opened fire at a Dollar General store in Jacksonville on Saturday, killing three people before taking his own life. Police described the shooting as a "racially motivated" hate crime.

TITLE: Tropical Storm Idalia could reach hurricane strength before hitting Florida this week
SUMMARY: Forecasters say the storm is expected to intensify as it moves north over the Gulf of Mexico, but it's still unclear how strong it will be and what path it will take.

TITLE: 3 U.S. Marines killed, 20 injured in an aircraft crash in Australia, officials say
SUMMARY: A United States Marine Corps aircraft crashed on a north Australian island Sunday, killing three Marines and injuring 20 during a multi-nation training exercise, officials said.

TITLE: Marine Corps Osprey crash in Australia kills 3 and injures 20, at least 5 critically
SUMMARY: TheV-22 Osprey crashed on a north Australian island Sunday during a multi-nation training exercise, officials said.

TITLE: Russia confirms that Yevgeny Prigozhin was killed in last week's plane crash
SUMMARY: Russia's Investigative Committee said genetic tests confirmed that the head of the mercenary force Wagner, who led a short-lived armed rebellion, and two of the group's leaders were on the plane.

TITLE: Victims identified in the Florida shooting that is being investigated as a hate crime
SUMMARY: Jacksonville sheriff said the gunman left behind "manifestoes" and says the shooting "was racially motivated and he hated Black people."

TITLE: 3 members of Congress make a rare visit to opposition-held northwest Syria
SUMMARY: It's the first known visit to the country by American lawmakers in six years. GOP Reps. French Hill, Ben Cline and Scott Fitzgerald urged the Biden administration to maintain pressure on Bashar Assad.

SUMMARY: Preece went to the hospital on Saturday after his Mustang flipped at least 10 times during the final laps of the NASCAR Cup Series race in Daytona Beach, Fla.

SUMMARY: Biles became the oldest woman to win a national title since USA Gymnastics began organizing the event in 1963. Her eight crowns moved her past Alfred Jochim, who won seven between 1925-33.

TITLE: People mourn victims of the Florida shooting as a hate crime investigation begins
SUMMARY: At an evening vigil near the Dollar General store where the attack occurred, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis was met with boos from the crowd as he stepped to the microphone.

TITLE: Zimbabwe's opposition alleges fraud in vote that extends governing party's rule
SUMMARY: Zimbabwe's main opposition leader on Sunday alleged "blatant and gigantic fraud" in the country's election after President Emmerson Mnangagwa was declared the winner.

TITLE: How scientists engineered a see-through squid with its brain in plain view
SUMMARY: A see-through squid is giving scientists an unprecedented view of the brain and other organs in a living animal.

TITLE: Maui's surf pros paddle out with kids from Lahaina for a healing surf session
SUMMARY: Families displaced by wildfire get a welcome reprieve as a surf session for kids and families gave them a chance for a normal Saturday.

TITLE: Mug shots are usually harmful. For Trump and his supporters, it's a badge of honor
SUMMARY: Typically, mug shots are associated with shame. But for former president Donald Trump and some of his supporters, his mug shot â the first ever of an American president â was something they embraced.

TITLE: Ozempic seems to curb cravings for alcohol. Here's what scientists think is going on
SUMMARY: People taking weight-loss drugs Ozempic and Wegovy report a dampening of the urge to drink. Here's how the drugs curb cravings and what that could mean for helping treat addiction.

TITLE: As classes resume in sweltering heat, many schools lack air conditioning
SUMMARY: Amid sweltering heat waves, classes have resumed in many districts around the country that have outdated heating and cooling systems â or no air conditioning at all.

TITLE: Alcaraz and Djokovic symbolize the transition in tennis as U.S. Open is set to begin
SUMMARY: Observers say the sport for both the men's and women's games is changing, leaving parity and opportunities for new ascending champions.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Trump trial date expected; Jacksonville shooting; Maui surf lessons
SUMMARY: A federal judge will set a date for Trump's election obstruction case. Crowds mourn three Black people killed at a Dollar General in Florida. Pro surfers give kids in Maui a surf lesson.

TITLE: Tropical Storm Idalia: Cars may stop working mid-evacuation due to fuel contamination
SUMMARY: Florida officials reported "potentially widespread" diesel contamination in gasoline in the Tampa area Saturday, raising alarm that car engines and power generators could break as the storm nears.

TITLE: Judge sets March 4, 2024 as Trump trial date in election interference case
SUMMARY: The judge overseeing a criminal case against former President Donald Trump for interfering with the 2020 presidential election has set a trial date of March 4, 2024.

SUMMARY: Forecasters are warning of the possibility of dangerous storm surges caused by Idalia, and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has suggested that some residents in coastal areas may have to evacuate.

TITLE: Why would Trump's supporters vote for Ramasamy instead of the former president?
SUMMARY: NPR's A Martinez talks to GOP strategist Dave Carney about Republican presidential contender Vivek Ramaswamy, who has positioned himself as a younger Donald Trump.
