SUMMARY: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis visited Jacksonville on Sunday to mourn the three victims killed in a racially motivated shooting at a local Dollar General.

TITLE: Latest on Ukraine: Wagner chief Prigozhin died as Russia's war turned 1 1/2
SUMMARY: Catch up on key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: He helped write MLK's 'I Have a Dream' speech. Now he reflects on change in the U.S.
SUMMARY: 60 years after Martin Luther King Jr. gave his famous "I Have a Dream" speech, we hear from one of the men who helped him write it, his friend and attorney Clarence B. Jones.

TITLE: Judge sets March 4, 2024, as Trump trial date in election interference case
SUMMARY: The judge overseeing a criminal case against former President Donald Trump for interfering with the 2020 presidential election has set a trial date of March 4, 2024.

TITLE: 'A Guest in the House' rests on atmosphere, delivering an uncanny, wild ride
SUMMARY: Though inscrutabilities persist in the plot of Emily Carroll's new adult horror graphic novel, the chilling ambiance makes this book one worth visiting.

TITLE: Latest on Ukraine: Wagner chief Prigozhin died as Russia's war turned 18 months
SUMMARY: Catch up on key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Vivek Ramaswamy picked up steam at the GOP debate. How far could he go?
SUMMARY: Ramaswamy has pitched himself as a younger, more extreme version of the former president. While he's gained in the polls, a GOP strategist warns "he'll never surpass Trump by trying to mimic Trump."

TITLE: With hold on confirmations, Pentagon says fate of hundreds of officers in limbo
SUMMARY: Hundreds of nominees for military positions have been stalled as Sen. Tommy Tuberville, R-Ala., protests Pentagon abortion policy. The Pentagon says the total number could swell to 650.

TITLE: Noah Lyles questioned the NBA 'world champions' label. Everyone had thoughts
SUMMARY: When track and field star Noah Lyles questioned why people refer to NBA title winners as "world champions," everyone from Drake to Kevin Durant rushed to have their say.

TITLE: Samuel Wurzelbacher, who became 'Joe the Plumber' after confronting Obama, dies at 49
SUMMARY: Wurzelbacher was thrust into the political spotlight after questioning Barack Obama about his economic policies during the 2008 presidential campaign. He had been battling pancreatic cancer.

TITLE: Alabama requests a date to execute an inmate via nitrogen hypoxia for the first time
SUMMARY: Smith was supposed to be executed in November 2022 by lethal injection, but corrections officers failed to insert an IV properly. The U.S. Supreme Court has authorized nitrogen hypoxia in his case.

TITLE: U.S. fines American Airlines for dozens of long tarmac delays
SUMMARY: The U.S. Department of Transportation said Monday it is the largest such fine against an airline since rules covering long ground delays took effect about a decade ago.

TITLE: It's time to rethink Rudy Giuliani and his claim to discover RICO
SUMMARY: Giuliani has long claimed that he dreamed up the idea of using the federal RICO law to target mafia families when he was a federal prosecutor.

TITLE: This cafe never closed after Lahaina's fires, extending a lifeline of normalcy
SUMMARY: At Java Jazz, locals displaced by the fires can reconnect, share a drink and listen to music. "We felt like, we will continue on with life," the owner says. "We can't just go and throw in the towel."

TITLE: There's a labor shortage in the U.S. Why is it so hard for migrants to legally work?
SUMMARY: The wait time for an asylum-seeker in the U.S. to get a work permit is at least half a year. City governments across the country are pressing the federal government to change that.

TITLE: She paid her husband's hospital bill. A year after his death, they wanted more money
SUMMARY: Eloise Reynolds encountered a perplexing reality in medical billing: Providers can come after patients for more money well after a bill has been paid.

TITLE: Idalia strengthens into a hurricane off Cuba as it churns toward Florida
SUMMARY: Forecasters warn of the possibility of dangerous storm surges caused by Idalia and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has suggested that some residents in coastal areas may have to evacuate.

TITLE: Here are the first 10 drugs that Medicare will target for price cuts
SUMMARY: The government will negotiate new prices for the commonly prescribed drugs, but the cuts won't take effect until 2026. In the meantime, drug makers are fighting the negotiations with lawsuits.

TITLE: Meta says Chinese, Russian influence operations are among the biggest it's taken down
SUMMARY: Facebook's parent company says both operations used fake accounts across social media sites to promote Chinese and Russian interests

TITLE: Up First briefing: Florida evacuations; summer COVID wave; how to beat jet lag
SUMMARY: Florida residents brace for Hurricane Idalia, which is expected to become a hurricane before landfall. COVID cases are rising in the U.S. The NPR international desk's best tips for beating jet lag.

TITLE: Tuberville's hold on military promotions may put 650 officers in limbo by year's end
SUMMARY: Hundreds of nominees for military positions have been stalled as Sen. Tommy Tuberville, R-Ala., protests Pentagon abortion policy, and that total could swell to 650, the Pentagon says.

TITLE: Steve Scalise says he has been diagnosed with a 'very treatable blood cancer'
SUMMARY: House Majority Leader Steve Scalise said he's begun treatment for multiple myeloma. He said he expects to return to Washington to continue work while he undergoes treatment.

TITLE: Florida rushes to make its final preparations before Hurricane Idalia makes landfall
SUMMARY: Forecasters say Idalia will be at least a Category 3 hurricane by the time of its expected landfall on Wednesday. Officials are urging residents to get ready, and have ordered thousands to evacuate.

TITLE: The latest shootings once again raise more questions about campus security
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with campus security expert Steven Healy about how college campuses can balance the need for open access with safety and security.

TITLE: As war losses mount, Ukraine honors a veteran jet fighter pilot who died in collision
SUMMARY: Andrii Pilshchykov, known as "Juice," died in a training flight Friday. He was a veteran of early combat missions during Russia's invasion and later advocated for Western countries to donate F-16s.

TITLE: Miami Mayor Francis Suarez suspends his campaign for president
SUMMARY: The Republican leader in South Florida alluded to his inability to appear in the first GOP debate as part of the catalyst for his decision to leave the race.

TITLE: Can we make college campuses safer? Expert advice after recent shootings
SUMMARY: The Jacksonville gunman drove to a university before opening fire at a nearby store. Days later, UNC Chapel Hill went on lockdown as a faculty member was shot. A campus security expert offers advice.

TITLE: Uganda starts charging people under extreme anti-LGBTQ law, raising execution fears
SUMMARY: Two men in Uganda are the first to be charged with "aggravated homosexuality" under a harsh new law that carries the death penalty. Their cases highlight the threats for LGBTQ+ people in Uganda.

TITLE: Prigozhin is buried in St. Petersburg as Russians mourn the Wagner mercenary chief
SUMMARY: Wagner Group head Yevgeny Prigozhin died in a plane crash last week. Many Russians are mourning â and speculating about the crash.

TITLE: Paul Whelan, an American imprisoned in Russia, appears in a new video
SUMMARY: The video was released by the state-controlled outlet Russia Today. Whelan is shown in a prison uniform standing among other prisoners, operating a sewing machine and eating with others.

TITLE: In red states where marijuana is illegal other hemp products flourish
SUMMARY: A loophole in the farm bill allows for the sale of hemp products that include a form of THC.  North Carolina is one state where stores selling intoxicating hemp products have popped up.

TITLE: How K-pop took over the world â as told by one fan who rode the wave
SUMMARY: In a new podcast, Vivian Yoon dissects her personal stake in K-pop, and how her obscure childhood passion has evolved into a billion-dollar industry.

TITLE: It's big! It's bright! It's a rare blue supermoon! Here's how to check it out
SUMMARY: The Earth's lunar sidekick will appear extra big and bright as it reaches its fullest stage on Wednesday. It's not just the biggest supermoon this year, it's also a rare blue supermoon.

TITLE: The EPA removes federal protections for most of the country's wetlands
SUMMARY: The amended EPA rule is to comply with a Supreme Court ruling this year that narrowed the scope of the Clean Water Act and the agency's power to regulate waterways and wetlands.

TITLE: Idalia strengthens and is now predicted to hit Florida as a Category 4 hurricane
SUMMARY: The National Hurricane Center said Idalia is now forecasted to be at Category 4 strength at landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast on Wednesday, with winds that could reach at least 130 mph.

TITLE: Military officers in Gabon say they have seized power
SUMMARY: A dozen uniformed soldiers appeared on state television and a spokesman said they intended to "dissolve all institutions of the republic."

TITLE: More than 6 months after Turkey's quake, people who lost homes still await new ones
SUMMARY: The Feb. 6 earthquake and its aftershocks left nearly 3 million displaced and in need of shelter. In the hard-hit city of Adiyaman, families wait for promises of new homes to be fulfilled.

TITLE: On Maui, a desperate plea to tourists: please return
SUMMARY: When the deadly wildfires ignited on Maui, tourists were turned away. Three weeks later, business owners are eager for them visit â responsibly.

TITLE: Ex-Proud Boys leader Enrique Tarrio to be sentenced today in Jan. 6 case
SUMMARY: Prosecutors are seeking 33 years for Tarrio. Also set to be sentenced later this week are Tarrio's codefendants: Ethan Nordean, Joseph Biggs, Zachary Rehl and Dominic Pezzola.

TITLE: These young Republicans want the GOP to do more to recruit young voters

SUMMARY: Idalia intensified into a potentially catastrophic Category 4 hurricane Wednesday morning as it approached Florida's Big Bend region with 130 mph winds.

SUMMARY: When the deadly wildfires ignited on Maui, tourists were turned away. Three weeks later, business owners are eager for them visit â responsibly.

SUMMARY: Hurricane Idalia makes landfall. The ex-leader of the Proud Boys will be sentenced today. An unwanted World Cup kiss sparks controversy in Spain.

TITLE: Hurricane Idalia eye comes ashore near Keaton Beach, Fla.

SUMMARY: Prosecutors are seeking 33 years for Tarrio. Also set to be sentenced later this week are Tarrio's codefendants: Ethan Nordean, Joseph Biggs, Zachary Rehl and Dominic Pezzola.

SUMMARY: Finalists for a leading annual literary award were announced Wednesday. The Kirkus Prize awards $50,000 to writers working in the categories of Fiction, Nonfiction, and Young Readers' Literature.

SUMMARY: Judge Beryl Howell's decision means that a trial will commence in this case to decide how much Rudy Giuliani must pay Ruby Freeman and Wandrea "Shaye" Moss.

SUMMARY: Idalia made landfall near Keaton Beach, Fla., as a Category 3 hurricane on Wednesday, gradually weakening as it ripped through the state, into Georgia and across the Carolinas.

SUMMARY: Starfield's story shoots for the stars. How much players like it will have big consequences here on Earth.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Senate returns; Ken Paxton trial; Turkey archeological finds
SUMMARY: The Senate returns after a monthlong recess. Texas' suspended Attorney General Ken Paxton's impeachment trial begins today. Archaeologists in Turkey find massive structures below a Roman-era castle.

TITLE: Burning Man festival attendees, finally free to leave, face 7 hours of traffic
SUMMARY: Organizers had asked attendees to shelter-in-place on Saturday, as torrential rains turned the desert site into a mud pit. A driving ban has since been lifted, but it's taking hours for most to exit.

TITLE: Once the leading alternative to Trump, turnover in the DeSantis team spells trouble
SUMMARY: The governor of Florida, who consistently polls second in the race, has been named by many as the successor to Trump. But he has failed to gain in the polls and personnel issues roil his campaign.

TITLE: Alabama's congressional map is struck down again for diluting Black voters' power
SUMMARY: A federal court struck down Alabama's congressional map for not following an order to comply with the Voting Rights Act. Court-appointed experts are now set to draw a new map for the 2024 elections.

TITLE: Chinese construction workers accused of plowing a hole through the Great Wall
SUMMARY: The pair, who were working on a local construction project, drove an excavator through a portion of the wall. They have been charged with destroying a cultural relic, <em>China Daily

TITLE: Spain's women's soccer coach is fired as fallout grows from unwanted World Cup kiss
SUMMARY: In its dismissal of coach Jorge Vilda, Spain's soccer federation did not mention his connection to now-suspended president Luis Rubiales or his unpopularity among the Women's World Cup-winning team.

TITLE: NPR CEO John Lansing will leave in December, capping a tumultuous year
SUMMARY: President and CEO John Lansing plans to leave NPR nine months before his term is set to expire. His tenure has been defined by the pandemic, a racial reckoning, and economic headwinds.

TITLE: McConnell reportedly not suffering from stroke or seizures, says Capitol doctor
SUMMARY: A new letter from the Capitol's attending physician says the Senate minority leader is not suffering from a seizure disorder, short strokes known as TIA or movement issues like Parkinson's disease.

TITLE: Cuba says it dismantled human trafficking ring recruiting for Russia's war in Ukraine
SUMMARY: Havana says it is dismantling a network that seeks to recruit Cubans as mercenaries to fight in Russia's war against Ukraine.

TITLE: Burning Man festival attendees, finally free to leave, face hours of traffic
SUMMARY: Organizers had asked attendees to shelter in place on Saturday, as torrential rains turned the desert site into a mud pit. A driving ban has since been lifted, but exiting is still a trek.

TITLE: Biden tests negative again for COVID after the first lady tests positive
SUMMARY: The president tested negative again today for the virus the White House said, the day after the first lady tested positive. The White House says he'll wear a mask indoors when he's around others.

TITLE: All defendants in Georgia racketeering case, including Trump, have pleaded not guilty
SUMMARY: The 19 defendants in the case have waived their right to appear at arraignments that had been scheduled for Wednesday. Former White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows filed his plea on Tuesday.

TITLE: A look at the most annoying workplace jargon and why people are bothered so much
SUMMARY: A poll by the company Preply asked white-collar workers to weigh in on the words and terms they're most sick of hearing on the job. "Circling back" and "touching base" are two that made the list.

TITLE: Google turns 25, with an uncertain future as AI looms
SUMMARY: For 25 years, Google has shaped the internet. Now, artificial intelligence threatens to change everything.

TITLE: Ex-Proud Boys leader Enrique Tarrio sentenced to 22 years for Jan. 6 riot role
SUMMARY: Tarrio was one of six Proud Boys leaders to be charged for conspiring to stop the certification of the 2020 presidential election results. Of them, he has received the longest prison sentence to date.

TITLE: Tropical Storm Lee will soon be a major hurricane - with 145 mph winds or more
SUMMARY: The National Hurricane Center says Tropical Storm Lee is forecast to strengthen rapidly into an "extremely dangerous" major hurricane this weekend as it nears the Lesser Antilles and Caribbean.

TITLE: Burning Man attendees say learning to live with the unexpected is part of the program
SUMMARY: Organizers had asked attendees to shelter in place on Saturday, as torrential rains turned the desert site into a mud pit. A driving ban has since been lifted, but exiting is still a trek.

TITLE: 2 Pennsylvania school districts cancel classes after a man escaped from prison
SUMMARY: Danelo Cavalcante was sentenced to life in prison and has been spotted six times since escaping from the Chester County Prison in late August. Police say how he got out is still under investigation.

TITLE: Paxton impeachment trial begins in the Texas Senate
SUMMARY: The suspended Texas AG pleaded not guilty to all charges, which include bribery, corruption, and abuse of office. Here's what happened on the first day of his trial in the TX Senate.

TITLE: A Vietnam veteran helicopter pilot receives the Medal of Honor for a daring rescue
SUMMARY: Capt. Larry Taylor received the award from President Biden for flying into heavy enemy fire to save four members of a reconnaissance team from almost certain death as they were about to be overrun.

TITLE: Tropical Storm Lee will soon be a major hurricane â with 145 mph winds or more
SUMMARY: The National Hurricane Center says Tropical Storm Lee is forecast to strengthen rapidly into an "extremely dangerous" major hurricane this weekend as it nears the Lesser Antilles and Caribbean.

TITLE: Coco Gauff, 19, and Ben Shelton, 20, reach their first U.S. Open semifinals
SUMMARY: Coco Gauff will face No. 10 Karolina Muchova of the Czech Republic on Thursday. The unseeded Ben Shelton will next meet 23-time major champion Novak Djokovic of Serbia.

TITLE: Franne Lee, who designed costumes for 'SNL' and 'Sweeney Todd,' dies at 81
SUMMARY: From SNL's Coneheads to Killer Bees, Broadway's Sweeney Todd and Candide,

TITLE: A heat wave, and lack of air conditioning, disrupt school districts nationwide
SUMMARY: A heat wave along the East Coast and in the Midwest leads to closings, shorter school days.

TITLE: Storing guns away from home could reduce suicides, but there are legal hurdles
SUMMARY: New ideas like "safe storage maps" show gun owners where to put their firearms in safekeeping if a mental health crisis happens. The idea has support, but obstacles are in the way in some states.

TITLE: He came to Maui to find his granddad. He wound up giving out thousands in aid money
SUMMARY: Kian Lutu says it was his duty to volunteer in shelters and dole out donations. It's one example of how Maui's communities and families banded together after last month's wildfires.

TITLE: Ukraine strains to safely operate nuclear power plants while under Russian invasion
SUMMARY: Russia has occupied the massive Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, which sits roughly 50 miles from the front lines. Ukraine's other reactors are also operating in a volatile war zone.

TITLE: The White House wants $44 billion in emergency funding. Here's what that covers
SUMMARY: The White House has asked Congress for emergency funding for Ukraine, disaster recovery, and the border. The package would be tied to a broader deal to keep the government running.

TITLE: A 25-year-old from a small town leads North Carolina's Democratic Party toward 2024
SUMMARY: Anderson Clayton is the youngest â and only Gen Z â state party chair in the country. She wants to help President Biden win over young and rural voters in her state next November.

TITLE: Former NFL players speak out against the league's handling of disability benefits
SUMMARY: While the lawsuit lists 10 players, attorneys representing the former players say the lawsuit represents thousands who have filed for benefits before them.

TITLE: A rare spotless giraffe gets a name to match
SUMMARY: The public has voted and the spotless superstar born at a family-owned zoo in Tennessee has been named Kipekee.

TITLE: The perilous hunt for PPP fraud and the hot tip that wasn't
SUMMARY: The public data on PPP loans contains a lot of suspicious patterns, but it can also send people on wild goose chases

TITLE: Meet the man leading the front-line effort in Ukraine's cyber war with Russia
SUMMARY: Illia Vitiuk is a top Ukrainian intelligence official. For him, the war with Russia is primarily in cyberspace  â and in a rare exclusive interview with NPR, he says its far from over.

TITLE: This summer was the hottest on record across the Northern Hemisphere, the U.N. says
SUMMARY: The world's oceans were the hottest ever recorded, while Antarctica continued to set records for low amounts of sea ice, the World Meteorological Organization said.

TITLE: A new website reports on the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community
SUMMARY: A new website, Shtetl.org, aims to provide an inside view and a critical look at the insular world of ultra-Orthodox Jews.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Blinken in Ukraine; ex-Proud Boys leader sentenced; new COVID data
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Blinken is in Kyiv. Ex-Proud Boys leader Enrique Tarrio is sentenced to 22 years in prison. Vaccines and previous infections can protect you from the new COVID variant.

TITLE: YouTube vlogger Ruby Franke formally charged with 6 felony counts of child abuse
SUMMARY: Ruby Franke, the YouTube mommy blogger behind  the channel 8 Passengers, was arrested last week after her 12-year-old son climbed out a window and ran to a neighbor's house asking for food and water.

TITLE: A cyclone has killed over 20 people in Brazil, with more flooding expected
SUMMARY: The southern Brazilian states of Rio Grande do Sul and neighboring Santa Catarina are reeling after a devastating cyclone killed 27 people and displaced thousands.

TITLE: U.S. imposes sanctions on Sudanese paramilitary leader; boosts humanitarian aid
SUMMARY: The U.S sanctioned Sudanese paramilitary commander Abdelrahim Hamdan Dagalo over human rights abuses, while also announcing over $160 million in humanitarian aid for Sudan.

TITLE: Green groups sue, say farmers are drying up Great Salt Lake
SUMMARY: Environmental groups have filed suit against the state of Utah arguing leaders aren't doing enough to prevent the state's namesake Great Salt Lake from drying up.

TITLE: Prosecutors expect to call over 150 witnesses in Georgia election interference case
SUMMARY: Prosecutors in Fulton County, Ga., say they expect that a trial in their election interference case would last four months, not including jury selection.

TITLE: Mike Pence says Republicans "face a choice" in 2024: populism or conservatism
SUMMARY: The former vice president didn't pull any punches in a headlining event at the New Hampshire Institute of Politics where he argued that conservatism, not populism, is the future of the GOP.

TITLE: 'Holly' is one of Stephen King's most political novels to date
SUMMARY: <em>Holly

TITLE: Alex Murdaugh wants a new trial, accusing the clerk of court of jury tampering
SUMMARY: Defense lawyers for convicted South Carolina lawyer Murdaugh say Clerk of Court Rebecca Hill violated her oath of office as well as their client's constitutional right to an impartial jury.

TITLE: McConnell tries to shift Senate focus from his health to spending
SUMMARY: Reporters repeatedly asked the Senate GOP leader to provide details of what caused two incidents where he froze at events. McConnell instead referred them to a recent letter from his physician.

TITLE: The share of U.S. drug overdose deaths caused by fake prescription pills is growing
SUMMARY: The share of overdose deaths involving counterfeit pills doubled between 2019 and 2021, according to the CDC. Victims were often younger, Hispanic and had misused prescription drugs in the past.

TITLE: Carl Nassib made queer NFL history. Now he's stepping away from the game
SUMMARY: Although he isn't the first NFL player to come out as gay, he is the first to do so while actively playing for a team.

TITLE: Chvrches' Lauren Mayberry goes solo â and we got exclusive backstage access
SUMMARY: At the 9:30 Club in Washington, D.C. on Monday, Lauren Mayberry announced herself as a solo star.

TITLE: The floating border barrier in the Rio Grande must be removed, a federal judge rules
SUMMARY: The judge gave Texas until Sept. 15 to move the barrier to shore and barred the state from placing any additional buoys or other structures in the river. Gov. Greg Abbott plans to appeal the ruling.

TITLE: A special counsel will indict Hunter Biden in gun case this month, DOJ says
SUMMARY: The charges that David Weiss will seek against Hunter Biden were not disclosed directly in the latest filing Wednesday.

TITLE: Mexico decriminalizes abortion, extending Latin American trend of widening access
SUMMARY: The country's Supreme Court ordered that abortion be removed from the federal penal code, ruling that national laws prohibiting the procedure are unconstitutional and violate women's rights.

TITLE: Archeologists in Norway found an arrow that was likely trapped in ice for 4,000 years
SUMMARY: The arrow was found at a site on Mount LauvhÃ¸e that was previously covered in ice. The new discovery adds new "time depth" to the research site.

TITLE: New state abortion numbers show increases in some surprising places
SUMMARY: What happened to abortion numbers since Roe v. Wade fell? The Guttmacher Institute has new state-by-state numbers that show people are traveling for the procedure.

TITLE: Pennsylvania inmate escaped by crab-walking up a prison wall, video shows
SUMMARY: The details of Danelo Cavalcante's escape, including that he got out using the same route another prisoner took in May, were released as police flooded a search zone of increasingly worried residents.

TITLE: Japan launches rocket carrying an X-ray telescope to explore the origins of universe
SUMMARY: The telescope will measure the speed and makeup of what lies between galaxies, information to help study how celestial objects were formed.

TITLE: Not in the Yucatan anymore: Hurricane Idalia flung flamingos across the eastern U.S.
SUMMARY: Flamingos have been found as far north as Ohio after Hurricane Idalia struck Florida last week. But the birds were likely blown in all the way from the Yucatan Peninsula.

TITLE: An Arab astronaut made history in space. Now his country has its sights on Mars
SUMMARY: The United Arab Emirates celebrated after Emirati astronaut Sultan Alneyadi splashed down to Earth following six months in space, a milestone for its growing space program.

TITLE: Here's why you shouldn't be surprised auto workers are asking for a 46% pay raise
SUMMARY: Bold union demands, bolstered by a tight labor market and frustration throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, are paying off in some sectors with significant raises for workers.

TITLE: This butterfly farmer wants to strengthen the Republican Party's hold on Alabama
SUMMARY: Alabama Republican Party Chair John Wahl is the youngest state GOP chair. He wants to increase GOP turnout among Black and young voters amid a larger redistricting battle and a looming election.

TITLE: In a charred moonscape, a band of hopeful workers try to save the Joshua tree
SUMMARY: After flames destroyed 1.3 million Joshua trees in Mojave National Preserve, biologists began replanting seedlings. But many have died, and now another fire has torched more of the iconic succulents.

TITLE: Voting online is very risky. But hundreds of thousands of people are already doing it
SUMMARY: The advice from cybersecurity experts is unanimous: Internet voting is a bad idea. But it's already happening in every federal election. In 2020, more than 300,000 Americans cast ballots online.

TITLE: Biden is off to India and Vietnam. It's part of his push to counter China's influence
SUMMARY: President Biden is using the G20 summit to push for a bigger, better World Bank as an alternative to China's massive lending programs, which have left some low-income countries with massive debt.

TITLE: Sudanese refugees in Chad scramble to survive
SUMMARY: As the refugee crisis in Chad continues to grow, international attention on the situation remains limited in the face of numerous other global humanitarian challenges.

TITLE: As federal workers are ordered back to their offices, pockets of resistance remain
SUMMARY: As employers including the federal government cut back on remote work, employees who never had any intention of working from an office push back and threaten to retire or resign.

TITLE: Philanthropies pledge $500 million to address 'crisis in local news'
SUMMARY: The new coalition of donors, led by the MacArthur Foundation, says one out of every five Americans lives in a "news desert" with little to no reliable local news.

TITLE: Bruce Springsteen cancels a slate of concerts, citing peptic ulcer disease
SUMMARY: For decades, conventional wisdom held that peptic ulcers were caused by stress and unhealthy eating habits. But the vast majority are caused by bacteria.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Sudan's humanitarian crisis; Texas floating border; office jargon
SUMMARY: The U.N. says 400,000 have fled from Sudan to Chad. A judge rules floating border barrier in Texas must be removed. Circling back to the most annoying office jargon.

TITLE: Manhunt is underway for U.K. terror suspect who escaped prison strapped under a truck
SUMMARY: Authorities found straps dangling from a truck that left a prison kitchen early Wednesday. The suspect, last seen wearing a chef's uniform, is an ex-soldier accused of planting fake bombs and spying.

TITLE: What we know about the search for escaped Pennsylvania inmate Danelo Cavalcante
SUMMARY: A manhunt stretches into day 8, and a tower guard has been placed on leave amid an investigation into Danelo Cavalcante's escape. Here's a guide to the latest updates.

TITLE: Why auto workers are asking for a 46% pay raise
SUMMARY: Bold union demands, bolstered by a tight labor market and frustration throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, are paying off in some sectors with significant raises for workers.

TITLE: Superbugs catch a ride on air pollution particles. Is that bad news for people?
SUMMARY: Antibiotic resistant microbes from the soil, from aquaculture, from sewage and from hospitals can hook onto air pollution particles. A new study looks at the implications.

TITLE: Biden wants federal workforce to come to the office more. Some ask why?
SUMMARY: As employers including the federal government cut back on remote work, employees who never had any intention of working from an office push back and threaten to retire or resign.

TITLE: Hurricane Lee is rapidly intensifying, and it's forecast to be a Category 5 storm
SUMMARY: The hurricane isn't currently threatening anyone on land. That's a relief: Lee's maximum sustained winds are now predicted to top 160 mph by this weekend.

TITLE: Climate activists protested at Burning Man. Then the climate itself crashed the party
SUMMARY: Burners were forced to endure hours of torrential rains before tens of thousands bailed on the festival. Scientists warn that such large bursts of showers are a result of a warming planet.

TITLE: Actor Danny Masterson sentenced to 30 years to life in prison for rape
SUMMARY: The "That '70s Show" star was found guilty of two counts of rape in May, in a trial that involved the Church of Scientology.

TITLE: Extreme heat is cutting into recess for kids. Experts say that's a problem
SUMMARY: A heat wave at the start of the school year has educators scrambling to keep kids cool and safe.

TITLE: There are several manhunts underway this week. But don't panic, an expert says
SUMMARY: Authorities in Pennsylvania; Washington, D.C. and London are searching for people who escaped from prison in recent days. Here's why these events are more common than you think â  and what you can do.

TITLE: Federal investigators zero in on deadly condo collapse cause in Surfside, Fla.
SUMMARY: Two years ago, 98 people died with the Champlain Towers South condo building partially collapsed. Federal investigators have been looking into the flaws in the building's pool deck.

TITLE: 'Wednesday's Child' deals in life after loss
SUMMARY: The stories in Yiyun Li's book focus chiefly on people trying to put themselves together after loss, dealing with anguish that takes its time and rises from its dormancy at unexpected moments.

TITLE: After grand jurors were doxed, Georgia prosecutors want Trump trial jurors shielded
SUMMARY: Prosecutors want the identities of future jurors in the Georgia election interference case to be shielded. That's after the grand jurors that indicted Donald Trump had their information posted online.

TITLE: Coast Guard arrests a man trying to run a giant hamster wheel across the Atlantic
SUMMARY: It was the fourth time the Coast Guard has intercepted Reza Baluchi on his attempts to self-propel his homemade vessel to destinations including Bermuda, New York and London.

TITLE: Former Trump adviser Peter Navarro found guilty for defying Jan. 6 committee subpoena
SUMMARY: The former White House adviser was found guilty on two counts of criminal contempt for refusing to cooperate with a subpoena from the House Select Committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack.

TITLE: 'One player is gonna die': Star sounds dire warning as the U.S. Open heats up
SUMMARY: Dozens of athletes competing in the U.S. Open in New York City are suffering through muggy temperatures that are cracking the 90s.

TITLE: A climate protester glued his feet to floor and interrupted the U.S. Open semifinal
SUMMARY: The semifinal match between Coco Gauff and Karolina Muchova was delayed by 50 minutes because of a disruption by environmental activists, one who glued his bare feet to the concrete floor.

TITLE: Hurricane Lee strengthens to a Category 5 storm as it approaches the Caribbean
SUMMARY: Hurricane Lee strengthened to a Category 5 storm late Thursday night, forecasters said, and could present potentially dangerous beach conditions on the U.S. East Coast as early as this Sunday.

TITLE: An ailing American explorer trapped 3,000 feet deep in a Turkish cave awaits rescue
SUMMARY: Experienced caver Mark Dickey, 40, suddenly became ill during an expedition with a handful of others, including three other Americans, in the Morca cave in southern Turkey's Taurus Mountains.

TITLE: Maker of the spicy 'One Chip Challenge' pulls product from store shelves
SUMMARY: The maker of the extremely spicy chip said it is working to recall the product as Massachusetts authorities probe the death of a teen whose family said the challenge was a contributing factor.

TITLE: Nicki Minaj paints hip-hop pink â and changes the game
SUMMARY: The 2010 Nicki Minaj album <em>Pink Friday

TITLE: The Situation Room got a makeover. Here's what it looks like now
SUMMARY: It's a group of secure rooms where the president and his advisers make some of the most difficult national security decisions. After a year-long $50-million overhaul, it has reopened for operations.

TITLE: Bucking his party, Chris Christie makes his case for 2024
SUMMARY: Christie is still a Republican â after all, he's running for that party's presidential nomination. But his views on Ukraine, abortion and other issues put him out of step with many in the party.

TITLE: Why beautiful sadness â in music, in art â evokes a special pleasure
SUMMARY: People seek out art and music that combine sadness and beauty. Scientists and artists say there's good reason why we're drawn to it.

TITLE: Trump returns to South Dakota, recalling a defining moment in his presidency
SUMMARY: Trump is expected to speak at a rally in South Dakota Friday, near Mount Rushmore. It will be the second time as a presidential candidate he makes a stop in the state.

TITLE: Where *hasn't* someone escaped from prison this week? Find out in the weekly quiz
SUMMARY: This week, there was news about the Stone Age and aged Stones. And the aged. And the stoned. It was also a big week for escaped cons. Were you paying attention?

TITLE: Residents of four states are will get more information about flood risk to their homes
SUMMARY: Four states are strengthening rules that require home sellers and landlords to disclose information about whether a home has flooded in the past, or is likely to flood in the future.

SUMMARY: Forecasters say the Category 5 hurricane could see "remarkable rates of intensification." <em>That '70s Show

TITLE: Residents of four states will get more information about flood risk to their homes
SUMMARY: Four states are strengthening rules that require home sellers and landlords to disclose information about whether a home has flooded in the past, or is likely to flood in the future.

TITLE: 'Incredibly powerful' Hurricane Lee will see 180 mph winds, forecasters say
SUMMARY: It took just 24 hours for Lee's maximum sustained winds to rocket from 80 mph to 160 mph. But that was yesterday â now the hurricane is getting even stronger.

TITLE: Intensely powerful Hurricane Lee will slow down over the ocean, forecasters say
SUMMARY: It took just 24 hours for Lee's maximum sustained winds to rocket from 80 mph to 160 mph. Now the hurricane's intensity is fluctuating.

TITLE: Their house miraculously survived the wildfire, but no longer feels like home
SUMMARY: It's unclear when water and power will be restored in Lahaina, but one family is working hard to ready their home for return anyway.

TITLE: Rep. Nancy Pelosi is running for reelection
SUMMARY: The former House speaker announced Friday that she will run for reelection in 2024. She revealed her plans at a breakfast with volunteers in San Francisco and then followed up on X.

TITLE: Georgia panel recommended prosecutors seek charges against 39 people in Trump case
SUMMARY: The special grand jury's report differs from the charges filed by the Fulton County DA, including recommending Sen. Lindsey Graham and former Sens. David Perdue and Kelly Loeffler face indictment.

TITLE: Future of controversial Dakota Access pipeline's river crossing remains unclear
SUMMARY: Federal officials released a draft environmental review of the  pipeline, but said they're waiting for more input before deciding the future of the line's river crossing in North Dakota.

TITLE: California lawmakers ban most hand-count elections, targeting far-right Shasta County
SUMMARY: Most California elections will be forced to use state-approved machines to count ballots under a bill that follows an attempt by right-wing supervisors in one county to hand-count future elections.

TITLE: I love saris â but I have never seen saris like these before
SUMMARY: NPR correspondent Rhitu Chatterjee visited a hit London museum show called "The Offbeat Sari." It showed her how the garment has changed â and made her reflect on what the sari means to her.

TITLE: Justice Alito rejects recusal in major tax case
SUMMARY: His statement came after Sen. Dick Durbin, the chair of the Senate Judiciary Committee, wrote to the chief justice, urging that steps be taken to assure that Alito not take part in the tax case.

TITLE: Germany heads to its 1st FIBA World Cup championship after upsetting Team USA
SUMMARY: Friday's defeat in Manila marked the second consecutive Basketball World Cup loss for the U.S., which won back-to-back championships in 2010 and 2014.

TITLE: Judge rejects Mark Meadows' efforts to move Georgia racketeering case to federal court
SUMMARY: The former White House chief of staff to former President Donald Trump argued he should be tried in federal court. A federal judge disagreed, signaling how other defendants may be tried.

TITLE: Biden administration urges Supreme Court to hear case on major abortion pill
SUMMARY: The Justice Department pressured the Supreme Court on Friday to reconsider the fate of mifepristone in the U.S. The abortion pill may be dramatically limited if the court decides not to review.

TITLE: Appeals court slaps Biden administration for contact with social media companies
SUMMARY: The panel of judges say that the administration's efforts to flag what it considered to be harmful content likely amount to a violation of the First Amendment.

TITLE: A powerful earthquake in Morocco has killed hundreds, government says
SUMMARY: Morocco's Interior Ministry said early Saturday that at least 296 people had died in the provinces near the quake. The ministry wrote that most damage occurred outside of cities and towns.

TITLE: The number of people missing following devastating Maui wildfires has dropped to 66
SUMMARY: The new tally of 66 people still missing represents a significant drop from a week earlier, when authorities said 385 remained unaccounted for. The confirmed death toll remains at 115.

TITLE: The G20 has agreed to make the African Union a permanent member, Indian PM Modi says
SUMMARY: The announcement came at the opening of the G20 summit, one that comes as growing global rifts and the absence of key players threatened to make reaching consensus on the thorniest issues elusive.

TITLE: A powerful earthquake in Morocco has killed more than 600 people, government says
SUMMARY: Morocco's Interior Ministry said Saturday morning that at least 632 people had died, mostly in Marrakech and five provinces near the quake's epicenter. Another 329 people were injured.

TITLE: 7 habits to live a healthier life, inspired by the world's longest-lived communities
SUMMARY: Dan Buettner has spent decades exploring the lifestyles and diets of people in remote places where living to 100 is more common. Here are life-enhancing habits from these "blue zones."

TITLE: Celebrity couples keep breaking up. Why do we care so much?
SUMMARY: Joe Jonas and Sophie Turner are the latest high-profile pair to announce their split in what some have deemed "the year of the celebrity breakup." Experts explain why people get so invested from afar.

TITLE: 'The Fraud' asks questions as it unearths stories that need to be told
SUMMARY: Zadie Smith's latest novel revisiting a piece of history is packed with great writing and shining passages that go from humorous to deeply philosophical. But it is also very long.

TITLE: A powerful earthquake in Morocco has killed more than 800 people, government says
SUMMARY: At least 820 people died, mostly in Marrakech and five provinces near the quake's epicenter, and another 672 people were injured, Morocco's Interior Ministry reported Saturday morning.

TITLE: Pop-up units spring up after Maui fire disaster, giving families a place to call home
SUMMARY: In Hawaii, people who lost their homes to wildfires could soon be living in a pop-up village, with space for around 250 people.

TITLE: Unraveling long COVID: Here's what scientists who study the illness want to find out
SUMMARY: At a recent medical gathering, researchers presented their latest hypotheses about what causes â and what could treat â the lingering disease.

TITLE: 'Star Trek' stars join the picket lines in Hollywood
SUMMARY: Stars of <em>Star Trek

TITLE: Arab American stories interconnect in the new collection, 'Dearborn'
SUMMARY: Author Ghassan Zeineddine's new collection of short stories, <em>Dearborn

TITLE: Police catch a terrorism suspect who escaped from a London prison
SUMMARY: A former soldier who escaped from a London prison while awaiting trial on terrorism charges was captured Saturday after being on the run for four days, police said.

TITLE: Trump visits South Dakota, picking up an endorsement from Gov. Kristi Noem
SUMMARY: Trump has a strong relationship with a state that is often overlooked by presidential candidates. Friday's appearance in South Dakota could be seen as an audition for a potential running mate.

TITLE: A powerful earthquake in Morocco has killed more than 1,000 people
SUMMARY: The magnitude-6.8 quake â the biggest to hit Morocco in 120 years â damaged buildings from villages in the Atlas Mountains to the historic city of Marrakech.

TITLE: The world is still falling short on limiting climate change, according to U.N. report
SUMMARY: The outlook for climate change is better now than a few years ago, but countries have a long way to go to avoid dangerous climate impacts, according to a new report.

TITLE: At the G20, Biden joins forces with India and the Middle East, sidelining China
SUMMARY: President Biden and other world leaders announced a new corridor to link India with the Middle East and Europe. It's one of several initiatives aimed at countering China's Belt and Road Initiative.

TITLE: Morocco earthquake kills more than 1,000
SUMMARY: A powerful earthquake in Morocco has killed more than 1,000 people. Rescue attempts are made more difficult as the quake's epicenter is in the rugged Atlas Mountains.

TITLE: A powerful earthquake in Morocco has killed more than 1,300 people
SUMMARY: Hundreds have also been injured in the 6.8-magnitude earthquake on Friday night devastated homes in villages across the Atlas Mountains, as well as historical sites inside Marrakech city.

TITLE: A powerful earthquake in Morocco has killed more than 2,000 people
SUMMARY: Hundreds have also been injured in the 6.8-magnitude earthquake on Friday night devastated homes in villages across the Atlas Mountains, as well as historical sites inside Marrakech city.

TITLE: Coco Gauff wins the U.S. Open for her first Grand Slam title at age 19
SUMMARY: Gauff surged to her first major championship by coming back to defeat Aryna Sabalenka 2-6, 6-3, 6-2 in the U.S. Open final on Saturday, delighting a raucous crowd that was loud from start to finish.

TITLE: Phoenix has set another heat record by hitting 110 degrees on 54 days this year
SUMMARY: On Saturday, it was the 54th day this year that the official reading at Phoenix Sky Harbor Airport hit 110 degrees, eclipsing the previous record set in 2020. The hot streak could reach 55 days.

TITLE: For a new generation of Marines, 9/11 is history
SUMMARY: For many Americans, 9/11 is now simply a date to mark, much like December 7th and the Pearl Harbor attacks. Even the military war colleges are moving on.

TITLE: The U.S. set the stage for a coup in Chile. It had unintended consequences at home
SUMMARY: When the U.S. role in the 1973 coup in Chile became known, activists took action. So did U.S. lawmakers. This is what happened after the U.S. helped topple a Marxist and aided a right-wing dictator.

TITLE: Electric cars have a road trip problem, even for the secretary of energy
SUMMARY: A road trip I took with Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm confirmed one thing: The U.S. is wrestling with an inadequate charging network (unless you're a Tesla driver).

TITLE: What to know about Florida's 'classic' alternative to the SAT
SUMMARY: Florida's state universities will start accepting an alternative to the SAT exam that's known for its Christian and conservative backing.

TITLE: He's a singer, a cop and the inspiration for a Netflix film about albinism in Africa
SUMMARY: "Can You See Us?" is the story of a boy growing up with albinism in Zambia. His father spurns him, his peers attack him. It's based on the life of John Chiti, who spoke to NPR about his experiences.

TITLE: Pennsylvania police say an escaped killer has stolen a van and shaved his facial hair
SUMMARY: Police say Danelo Cavalcante, 34, was spotted on a doorbell camera in Phoenixville, about a 40-minute drive from where he had previously been seen.

TITLE: Moroccan rescue teams face challenges in reaching earthquake victims in the mountains
SUMMARY: Remote villages in the Atlas Mountains are among the hardest hit by Friday's earthquake that killed more than 2,000. Crews are struggling to reach communities amid aftershocks and damaged roads.

TITLE: Hurricane Lee is forecast to push dangerous surf along the U.S. East Coast
SUMMARY: The powerful Category 3 storm is expected to bring dangerous surf to the U.S. East Coast starting on Sunday. Forecasters said Lee is likely to restrengthen as it moves northwest in the coming days.

TITLE: Hurricane Lee is forecast to push dangerous surf along the East Coast
SUMMARY: The powerful Category 3 storm is expected to restrengthen as it moves northwest in the coming days, but currently poses no threats to people on land, according to the National Hurricane Center.

TITLE: Luis Rubiales says he is resigning as head of Spain's soccer federation
SUMMARY: Luis Rubiales says he is resigning as president of Spain's soccer federation after he kissed a star player on the mouth after the Women's World Cup final.

TITLE: Luis Rubiales resigns as head of Spain's soccer federation
SUMMARY: The embattled president of Spain's soccer federation has left his job. A furor arose after he kissed a star player on the mouth after the Women's World Cup final.

TITLE: Novak Djokovic wins the U.S. Open, taking his 24th Grand Slam title
SUMMARY: Djokovic, a 36-year-old from Serbia, moved one major singles title in front of Serena Williams to become the first player to win 24 in the Open era, which began in 1968.

TITLE: Michigan State suspends coach Mel Tucker after sexual harassment allegations
SUMMARY: Michigan State suspended football coach Mel Tucker without pay after allegations in a report that he sexually harassed activist and rape survivor Brenda Tracy during a phone call last year.

TITLE: End may be in sight for Phoenix's historic heat wave of 110-degree-plus weather
SUMMARY: On Sunday, it was the 55th day this year that the official reading at Phoenix Sky Harbor Airport hit 110 degrees. But the end may finally be in sight for residents of Arizona's largest city.

TITLE: Dozens die from a drone attack on an open market in Sudan as rival troops battle
SUMMARY: More than 55 others were wounded in the attack in Khartoum's May neighborhood, where paramilitary forces battling the military were heavily deployed, the Sudan Doctors' Union said in a statement.

SUMMARY: A growing body of research shows loneliness has profound implications for physical and mental health. Some organizations in Massachusetts are trying to help people connect to lessen those affects.

TITLE: Medical debt nearly pushed this family into homelessness. Millions more are at risk
SUMMARY: Saddled with debt from health care, many Americans are forced into painful tradeoffs.  And some are losing their homes.

TITLE: Why autoworkers' leader is calling for a 4-day work week from Big 3 car makers
SUMMARY: Shawn Fain, the president of the UAW, is calling for a 32-hour work week at 40 hours of pay for autoworkers, an idea that was first embraced by the union's leaders almost a century ago.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Morocco earthquake; new COVID boosters; a primer on prenups
SUMMARY: More than 2,000 are dead after a 6.8 magnitude quake struck near Marrakech on Friday. The FDA could approve new COVID boosters any day now. What to know if you're considering signing a prenup.

TITLE: Why a 4-day work week is on the table for auto workers
SUMMARY: Shawn Fain, the president of the UAW, is calling for a 32-hour work week at 40 hours of pay for autoworkers, an idea that was first embraced by the union's leaders almost a century ago.

SUMMARY: Plenty of Americans consider themselves to be unaffiliated from any religious institution. Yet for some, including Perry Bacon, the pull to a community like a church remains strong.

TITLE: The Kremlin confirms Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un will meet this week
SUMMARY: U.S. officials announced last week that the two leaders would meet in Vladivostok, as Russian President Putin seeks more arms to supply his war in Ukraine. Russia confirmed the summit on Monday.

SUMMARY: For Hostess, the deal with the peanut-butter-and-jelly conglomerate is a sweet win after not one, but two bankruptcies.

TITLE: Latest on Ukraine: Kim Jong Un to meet with Putin; G20 statement; Blinken visits Kyiv
SUMMARY: Catch up on key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

SUMMARY: More than 550 items from the late Greg Jein are heading to auction, from Nichelle Nichols' iconic knee-high boots and red tunic as Lt. Uhura to a hairpiece for William Shatner's Captain Kirk.

TITLE: Drew Barrymore to restart her talk show amid strikes, drawing heated criticism
SUMMARY: Drew Barrymore has announced she is bringing back her talk show amid the ongoing Hollywood strikes, sparking condemnation among fellow actors and calls for the show to be picketed.

TITLE: Russia's Vladimir Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un will meet this week
SUMMARY: U.S. officials announced last week that the two leaders would meet in Vladivostok, as Russian President Putin seeks more arms to supply his war in Ukraine.

TITLE: American researcher stuck deep in a Turkish cave is rescued after falling ill
SUMMARY: Mark Dickey, who was on an expedition to map the country's third deepest cave, became seriously ill more than a week ago. Rescuers retrieved him from nearly 1,000 meters below the cave's entrance.

TITLE: What we know about Kim Jong Un's train â a slow-moving bulletproof fortress
SUMMARY: On Monday, a dark green train with yellow trim was spotted at the border where Russia, China and North Korea meet. It runs with one passenger in mind: the leader of North Korea, Kim Jong Un.

TITLE: How to see a newly-discovered green comet this week, before it vanishes for 400 years
SUMMARY: A newly-discovered green comet is zipping by Earth and is now visible for the first time since before Galileo invented his telescope.

TITLE: Owner reunited with her dog that roamed the Atlanta airport for 3 weeks
SUMMARY: Maia the dog escaped from her carrier last month while being loaded onto a plane at the busiest airport in the world. An online community banded together to reunite her with her owner.

TITLE: How to see a newly discovered green comet this week, before it vanishes for 400 years
SUMMARY: A newly discovered green comet is zipping by Earth and is now visible for the first time since before Galileo invented his telescope.

TITLE: Flooding creates a disaster zone in Libya from Storm Daniel
SUMMARY: The confirmed death toll from the weekend flooding did not include Derna, which was inaccessible, and many of the thousands missing there were believed carried away by waters after two dams burst.

TITLE: New COVID vaccines get FDA approval
SUMMARY: Vaccines for a fall immunization drive against COVID-19 just got the green light from the Food and Drug Administration. The agency says the vaccines can protect people, as hospitalizations tick up.

TITLE: These kids used to get the bill for their own foster care. Now that's changing
SUMMARY: States routinely took the benefits checks of children in foster care who were orphans or disabled. After an NPR/Marshall Project investigation, there's reform.

TITLE: Memphis Police pressured to change culture after high-profile killings and beatings
SUMMARY: After the beating death of Tyre Nichols by five Memphis police officers in January and other abuses that have come to light, the police department is under mounting pressure to change its culture.

TITLE: United States takes on Google in biggest tech monopoly trial of 21st century
SUMMARY: The biggest antitrust trial in nearly 25 years kicks off on Tuesday as the Justice Department makes its case that Google is an illegal monopoly.

TITLE: Australia weighs cat curfews and neutering requirements to rein in feral felines
SUMMARY: Tanya Plibersek, Australia's Minister for the Environment and Water, declared "war" on feral cats officials say harm other species and carry disease. Critics say the feline threat is overblown.

TITLE: Nobel-winning Philippine journalist Maria Ressa is acquitted in tax evasion case
SUMMARY: Maria Ressa said the charges against her were politically motivated as Rappler was critical of Duterte's brutal crackdown on illegal drugs that left thousands of mostly petty drug suspects dead.

SUMMARY: The U.S. antitrust case against Google begins today. Kim Jong Un is expected to meet with Vladimir Putin in Russia. See green comet Nishimura this week before it vanishes for 400 years.

TITLE: These tech giants are at the White House today to talk about the risks of AI
SUMMARY: The White House is working with big tech companies to agree to testing and reporting measures to reduce AI risks. These voluntary measures are a precursor to regulation.

TITLE: They logged on to watch the famous fat brown bears. They saved a hiker's life instead
SUMMARY: Viewers of the Katmai National Park bear cameras caught more excitement than they may have hoped for last Tuesday when a hiker wandered into view, mouthing the words "help me."

TITLE: The Paris Review, n+1 and others win 2023 Whiting Literary Magazine Prizes
SUMMARY: The 2023 Whiting Literary Magazine Prize has been awarded to The Los Angeles Review of Books, The Paris Review, Oxford American and n+1

TITLE: Child poverty more than doubles â a year after hitting record low, Census data shows
SUMMARY: Experts point to the expanded child tax credit as key to this poverty yo-yo. When it ended, many lower-income families struggled to pay their bills or buy enough food.

TITLE: Speaker McCarthy says House to start an impeachment inquiry into President Biden
SUMMARY: "I do not make this decision lightly," McCarthy told reporters Tuesday. It's unclear whether the speaker has the votes to pass a resolution formally kicking off the probe.

TITLE: Escaped Pennsylvania inmate is now armed with a rifle, police say
SUMMARY: Danelo Calvalcante "is considered armed and extremely dangerous," police say. "He is now armed with a 22-caliber rifle with a scope and flashlight mounted on it," stolen from a resident's garage.

TITLE: Another spotless giraffe has been discovered â this time, on a reserve in Namibia
SUMMARY: The spotless Angolan giraffe was discovered at the Mount Etjo Safari Lodge, a private game reserve in Namibia. It is one of the two known living spotless giraffes in the world.

TITLE: Cascades of red wine flood a city's streets in Portugal after huge tanks rupture
SUMMARY: A viral video from the scene shows a "river of wine" coursing down a hilly street, sluicing over curbs. The wine escaped from two tanks at a distillery up the hill.

TITLE: How umami overcame discrimination and took its place as the 5th taste

SUMMARY: At least hundreds of people have died and thousands are feared missing in eastern Libya after Storm Daniel swept in, destroying dams and unleashing a torrent of muddy water that carried homes away.

TITLE: Alabama asks Supreme Court to aid a delay after June loss in voting case
SUMMARY: Alabama is once again asking the Supreme Court to let it keep Republican-drawn congressional districts. In essence, the state is fighting a court order that the high court upheld just months ago.

TITLE: Aaron Rodgers' torn Achilles means the Jets QB is likely to miss rest of the season
SUMMARY: An MRI confirmed he has a torn left Achilles tendon, according to a person familiar with the diagnosis, and the 39-year-old quarterback likely will miss the rest of the New York Jets' season.

TITLE: Hurricane Lee, now very large, is raising wind and surf dangers along the East Coast
SUMMARY: As of early Tuesday afternoon, Lee was packing 115 mph winds and moving west-northwest at a virtual crawl of just 6 mph.

TITLE: 5 former Memphis officers are indicted on federal charges for death of Tyre Nichols
SUMMARY: The five former police officers face charges of excessive force, deliberate indifference and witness tampering for the January death of the 29-year-old Nichols.

TITLE: Venice may be put on the endangered list, thanks to human-created climate change
SUMMARY: The impacts of climate change including related disasters, such as wildfires and sea level rise, are increasingly raising a question about how best to save cultural heritage.

SUMMARY: The manhunt for convicted murderer Danelo Cavalcante, who escaped from a prison near Philadelphia last month, is nearing the two-week mark. So how do authorities find him?

SUMMARY: Cindy McCain, the U.N. World Food Programme's executive director, has been tasked with closing the giant hole in the budget.

TITLE: Whatever happened to the project to crack the wealthy world's lock on mRNA vaccines?

SUMMARY: Sorry Jets fans, the hits just keep on coming. The latest came on Monday night, when quarterback Aaron Rodgers tore his Achilles tendon just four plays into his debut with the team.

SUMMARY: A panel of doctors and scientists advising the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention voted to recommend that people 6 months of age and older get new COVID boosters this fall.

SUMMARY: As autoworkers' real wages fall, top executives at the Big Three carmakers continue to earn tens of millions of dollars each year â hundreds of times more than the median employee.

SUMMARY: "We are serving a primal need of all human beings," Birkenstock's CEO writes to prospective shareholders. "We are a footbed company selling the experience of walking as intended by nature."

SUMMARY: It's not the first time Jaime Maussan has claimed to discover "nonhuman" bodily remains, and scientists have previously dismissed them.

SUMMARY: "Mortal Kombat 1" is a complete reboot â but with all the fan favorites back and ready to fight.

SUMMARY: The U.S. district judge agreed with nine states suing to stop the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program. The ruling means the program's fate will likely go to the Supreme Court a third time.

SUMMARY: Schools remain closed after the deadly fires on Maui. Parents say it's important to keep their community from being displaced indefinitely.

TITLE: Rural nursing home operators say new staff rules would cause more closures

SUMMARY: A crop of IPOs are coming, starting with chip designer Arm, which is making its debut on Thursday. It's another sign of confidence in markets â and the U.S. economy.

TITLE: In Georgia, Trump's latest indictment deepens a GOP divide
SUMMARY: Efforts to punish the prosecutor who charged Donald Trump and 18 others with election interference have amplified a divide among his supporters and the rest of the state GOP.

TITLE: A comment shouted from a stranger in a passing car saved her life
SUMMARY: Trieste Belmont says small kindnesses can be more powerful than we realize.

SUMMARY: Senator Mitt Romney says he won't seek reelection. How to prepare for a hurricane. The U.S. immigration population hits a record high.

SUMMARY: Want Adam Scott to walk your dog? What about dinner with Bob Odenkirk? Some of Hollywood's most beloved names are auctioning off unique experiences to help support the writers' strike

TITLE: In Ukraine, the focus is the fighting, but are negotiations possible?
SUMMARY: Ukraine's military offensive is making only limited progress. This is contributing to a debate on whether the U.S. needs to send even more powerful arms, or try to lay the groundwork for peace talks.

TITLE: HBO's 'Real Time with Bill Maher' to return during Writers Guild strike
SUMMARY: Maher posted on X that he won't have any written segments. But since Maher is himself a writer, it will be difficult for the show to go ahead "without a violation of WGA strike rules," says the Guild.

TITLE: Wouldn't it be great if pets could talk? This might be the next best thing
SUMMARY: A voiceover artist adds hilarious voices to pet videos submitted by his fans on social media.

TITLE: New NASA report lays out roadmap for studying UFOs
SUMMARY: NASA is releasing a new report from advisers on what it would take for the agency to study unidentified anomalous phenomena (also known as UFOs) scientifically.

TITLE: Here's where things stand just before the UAW and Big 3 automakers' contract deadline
SUMMARY: The union is prepared to strike. Auto companies say they're still waiting for counteroffers. And so far, there's no deal in sight.

TITLE: A luxury cruise ship is pulled free 3 days after running aground in Greenland
SUMMARY: The luxury cruise ship MV Ocean Explorer was successfully pulled free at high tide after running aground above the Arctic Circle with 206 people on board.

TITLE: Rep. Phillips is concerned that 20 members of the House and Senate are 80 or older
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Rep. Dean Phillips, D-Minn., about former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's reelection bid, and an aging body of lawmakers on Capitol Hill.

TITLE: Hunter Biden indicted on firearms charges
SUMMARY: The charges come weeks after a plea deal struck between Biden and prosecutors fell apart. Attorney General Garland appointed a special counsel in the investigation into the president's son last month.

SUMMARY: The former clerk in Rowan County, Ky., was sued by two same-sex couples to whom she refused to grant marriage licenses, claiming it violated her religious beliefs. Her attorney says she will appeal.

SUMMARY: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., is working to contain a revolt by hard-line members of his party that could threaten his job as speaker and a potential government shutdown.

SUMMARY: Winds on Cape Cod could gust as high as 50-60 mph, forecasters said on Thursday. The area is now under a tropical storm warning.

TITLE: As Congress gets older, one lawmaker makes the case for more 'generational diversity'
SUMMARY: From Rep. Nancy Pelosi to Sens. Mitt Romney and Mitch McConnell, lawmakers' ages are a big subject of discussion and debate. One member of Congress shares ideas for increasing generational diversity.

SUMMARY: Alex Jones' personal spending is frustrating families who are trying to collect on the $1.5 billion in judgments against him for calling the 2012 Sandy Hook elementary school shooting a hoax.

SUMMARY: In a hospital in the frontline city of Taiz, a woman tries to revive her malnourished baby with protein paste. The war-torn country is suffering through one of the world's worst humanitarian crises.

TITLE: Death toll soars to 11,300 from flooding in Libyan coastal city of Derna
SUMMARY: Another 10,100 are reported missing from flooding caused by Mediterranean storm Daniel, the Libyan Red Crescent says.

TITLE: What makes the family kitchen so special? Michele Norris digs into the details
SUMMARY: Journalist and writer Michele Norris is exploring the significance of the family kitchen in her new podcast, <em>Your Mama's Kitchen

TITLE: Exxon minimized climate change internally after conceding that fossil fuels cause it
SUMMARY: <em>The Wall Street Journal

TITLE: In an effort to make rides safer, Lyft launches Women+ Connect
SUMMARY: The new opt-in feature lets women and nonbinary drivers prioritize passengers who fit the same description. But it's not a guarantee and is only available in a handful of cities for now.

TITLE: Autoworkers are on the verge of a historic strike
SUMMARY: Less than two hours before the strike deadline, United Auto Workers revealed the first wave of plants to be targeted if the union and the Big 3 automakers fail to reach a deal just before midnight.

TITLE: Hurricane Lee will bring heavy rain to already saturated areas of New England
SUMMARY: Winds on Cape Cod could gust as high as 50 to 60 mph, forecasters said on Thursday. The area is now under a tropical storm warning.

TITLE: The UAW launches a historic strike against all Big 3 automakers
SUMMARY: For the first time ever, the UAW launched a strike against all Big 3 automakers at once, starting with three locations in the Midwest.

SUMMARY: The death of a young woman in Iranian morality police custody sparked months of protests and a violent crackdown by the government. A year later, a more subdued defiance endures.
