TITLE: A sculptor and a ceramicist who grapple with race win 2023 Heinz Awards for the Arts
SUMMARY: Kevin Beasley and Roberto Lugo are this year's winners of the the Heinz Awards for the Arts, a prestigious prize that comes with a $250,000 cash award.

TITLE: Philly's 'pastor of the hood' Carl Day weighs in on the 2024 election
SUMMARY: Carl Day joined NPR to weigh in on the Biden campaign in 2020. We caught up with him to hear what he's thinking heading into 2024.

TITLE: Maryland apologizes to man wrongly convicted of murder and agrees to pay him $340,000
SUMMARY: Demetrius Smith will be compensated by the state of Maryland after spending years behind bars, including over a year after he had been proven innocent. He was released from prison in 2013.

TITLE: UAW strike latest: GM sends 2,000 workers home in Kansas
SUMMARY: General Motors had previously warned it would need to stop production at its Fairfax, Kansas, assembly plant, because it relied on parts that came from a Missouri plant that is currently on strike.

TITLE: There have been attempts to censor more than 1,900 library book titles so far in 2023
SUMMARY: Most of the scrutinized books were written by or contained subject matter about people of color or members of the LGBTQ+ community, according to research by the American Library Association.

TITLE: Senate bucks Tuberville's blockade to begin approving military promotions
SUMMARY: Senate Democrats began holding votes on military promotions after a months-long blockade by Alabama Republican Sen. Tommy Tuberville.

TITLE: Biden is creating a new White House office focused on gun violence prevention
SUMMARY: Gun safety measures have stalled in Congress. Advocates have long pushed for a White House office to elevate the issue and coordinate administration efforts to reduce gun violence.

TITLE: U.S. will expand Temporary Protected Status to hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans
SUMMARY: Venezuelan migrants in the U.S. as of July 31 can sign up for Temporary Protected Status. Homeland Security officials estimate that roughly 472,000 more people will now be eligible for work permits.

TITLE: These 2020 census results break down people's race and ethnicity into details
SUMMARY: The U.S. census asked for more details about people's race and ethnicity in 2020 than ever before. New results show how many responded with identities such as Irish, Jamaican, Arab and Salvadoran.

TITLE: Kraft is recalling some American cheese slices over potential choking hazard
SUMMARY: The company said one of its wrapping machines developed a temporary issue that makes it possible for a thin strip of film to remain on the slice even after it's been removed from the wrapper.

TITLE: A record number of Australians enroll to vote in referendum on Indigenous Voice
SUMMARY: The referendum would enshrine in Australia's constitution an Indigenous Voice to Parliament. The Voice would advise on policies that impact the nation's most disadvantaged ethnic minority.

TITLE: In the Netherlands, a farmers party taps into widespread discontent with government
SUMMARY: What began as a movement of farmers opposed to environmental rules is now one of the country's dominant political parties. The nation's agricultural exports are second only to the United States.

TITLE: Are you saving enough for college? Here's what to know
SUMMARY: As the cost of college continues to rise, families have new questions about how to save up. For answers, we turned to Ron Lieber, author of <em>The Price You Pay For College

TITLE: The Senate's dress code just got more relaxed. Some insist on staying buttoned-up
SUMMARY: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer's decision not to enforce an unofficial dress code has elicited strong reactions and dominated talk on Capitol Hill, even as a potential government shutdown looms.

TITLE: Biden is telling his donors that Trump is out to destroy democracy
SUMMARY: President Biden isn't doing a lot of campaign events yet. But when he meets donors, he is spending a lot of time talking about the Republican frontrunner, former President Donald Trump.

TITLE: In a time of profound grief, a woman at church acknowledged this mother's pain
SUMMARY: Heather Harper was overwhelmed with grief after the loss of her pregnancy. Then a woman at church said something that made her feel less alone.

TITLE: As Ukraine's war drags on and a D.C. shutdown looms, Zelenskyy makes his case for aid
SUMMARY: The Ukrainian leader will visit Washington Thursday to meet with Congress. Biden has requested $24 billion in new aid to Ukraine, but the funding is in limbo ahead of a possible government shutdown.

TITLE: She has Medicare and Medicaid. So why should it take 18 months to get a wheelchair?
SUMMARY: About 12 million Americans are known as "dual eligibles" because they need both Medicare and Medicaid. A bipartisan bill offers hope to cut through the tangle of red tape that often ensnares them.

TITLE: Still there: Alzheimer's has ravaged his mother's memory, but music brings her back
SUMMARY: After 18 years of living with Alzheimer's disease, Marti Kaye spends most of her time in a wheelchair, expressionless. That changes the minute her son Adam Kaye starts playing his guitar.

TITLE: Up First briefing: House budget dispute; Zelenskyy in D.C.; Simone Biles makes history
SUMMARY: House Republicans can't agree on a spending bill. NPR's Steve Inskeep talks to Volodymyr Zelenskyy ahead of his D.C. visit. Simone Biles qualifies for a record sixth World  Gymnastics Championships.

TITLE: Free covid tests by mail are back, starting Monday
SUMMARY: People will be able to go to COVIDTests.gov and get four free tests per household, starting next week. The Biden administration says it is trying to prepare for the fall and winter COVID season.

TITLE: School book bans show no signs of slowing, new PEN America report finds
SUMMARY: The number of bans and restrictions in the U.S. rose 33% in the last school year, according the the report. Florida had more bans than any other state.

TITLE: Fans of a rising Nigerian music star are protesting after his untimely death
SUMMARY: The sudden death last week of 27-year-old rapper Mohbad has led to an outpouring of grief and anger across Nigeria, and put the treatment of musicians by powerful labels into sharper focus.

TITLE: Free COVID tests by mail are back, starting Monday
SUMMARY: People will be able to go to COVIDTests.gov and get four free tests per household, starting next week. The Biden administration says it is trying to prepare for the fall and winter COVID season.

TITLE: FBI investigates alleged abuse in Baton Rouge police building called the 'Brave Cave'
SUMMARY: The FBI said Friday it has opened a civil rights investigation into allegations in recent lawsuits that police in Baton Rouge, La., assaulted drug suspects they detained in the obscure warehouse.

TITLE: CDC recommends RSV vaccine in late pregnancy to protect newborns
SUMMARY: The shot will help shield newborns from RSV in the early months of life, when they're especially vulnerable to severe illness.

TITLE: Facing death threats, a Colombian mayor makes a daring visit to the town he runs
SUMMARY: Mayor Edilberto Molina relocated to a nearby town last year after drug-trafficking guerrillas threatened to kill him. He's not the only Colombian politician forced away by threats from criminal gangs.

TITLE: A Taylor Swift Instagram post helped drive a surge in voter registration
SUMMARY: More than 35,000 new voters registered at Vote.org after the singer posted a link on her Instagram Stories. "I've heard you raise your voices, and I know how powerful they are," Swift wrote.

TITLE: A BeyoncÃ© fan couldn't fly to a show due to his wheelchair size, so he told TikTok
SUMMARY: Jon Hetherington, 34, couldn't fly to Seattle to see BeyoncÃ© on her Renaissance World Tour because his wheelchair was too tall. However, he was invited to see her Dallas show.

TITLE: Thomas attended fundraisers for conservative political group, ProPublica report says
SUMMARY: A new report from ProPublica claims that Thomas has maintained a close relationship with the Koch network and that on at least two occasions, he spoke at fundraising events for the organization.

TITLE: Michael Harriot's 'Black AF History' could hardly come at a better time
SUMMARY: This engaging, well-researched, and frequently laugh-out-loud funny history places the Black experience at center stage with stories that should have already been part of our collective memory.

TITLE: NAACP signs agreement with FEMA to advance equity in disaster resilience
SUMMARY: As part of the collaborative effort, the NAACP's Emergency Management Task Force will regularly meet with FEMA to advance its progress on equity within disaster preparedness.

TITLE: A source of carbon â a building block of life â is found on Jupiter's moon Europa
SUMMARY: "The discovery signals a potentially habitable environment in the ocean of Europa," according to the Webb Space Telescope's website.

TITLE: 'Cassandro' honors the gay wrestler who revolutionized lucha libre
SUMMARY: The film pays homage to the real story of an unapologetically queer man in a male-dominated sport and society.

TITLE: Amazon Prime Video will start running commercials starting in early 2024
SUMMARY: Amazon Prime Video is the latest streaming service to embrace ads in what it says is an effort to continue investing in content.<strong>

TITLE: Rishi Sunak defends U.K. climate policy U-turn amid international criticism
SUMMARY: The British prime minister watered down key climate policies, and critics including Al Gore are slamming the changes. Analysts say with elections coming up next year, the pivot is politically driven.

TITLE: Democratic Sen. Robert Menendez has been indicted on federal corruption charges
SUMMARY: The indictment accuses Menendez of accepting "hundreds of thousands of dollars of bribes in exchange for using" his power and influence to enrich him, his co-defendants and the government of Egypt.

TITLE: Kentucky's near-total abortion ban takes center stage in gubernatorial election
SUMMARY: Incumbent Gov. Andy Beshear's latest campaign ad features a victim of rape and incest calling out Republican AG Daniel Cameron's support of the current state abortion ban.

TITLE: Up First briefing: UAW strike deadline; East Coast storm; Zelenskyy interview
SUMMARY: The auto workers union gears up to expand its strike. The Mid-Atlantic will be under a tropical storm warning this weekend. Zelenskyy talks to NPR about the state of the war and Ukraine's democracy.

TITLE: How the UAW strikes could impact car shoppers
SUMMARY: Historic as the UAW strikes may be, analysts say the actions are unlikely to impact car prices too much â for now. A new strike on parts distribution centers, however, could sting.

TITLE: 1 in 4 inmate deaths happens in the same federal prison. Why?
SUMMARY: The Butner federal prison complex in North Carolina is where a quarter of federal inmate deaths occur. It includes a medical facility but inmates aren't getting needed care, there or at other prisons.

TITLE: BogotÃ¡ has some of the worst traffic. It's finally getting a metro, with China's help
SUMMARY: Colombia's capital is home to 11 million people â and to some of the worst traffic jams in the world. Now Chinese companies are building its first metro line.

TITLE: House GOP rebels recall a distant era when dissidents rose up against 'Czar Cannon'
SUMMARY: Cannon resisted government regulation of business, supported protective tariffs and frowned upon change in general. It was said that had he been present at the Creation he would have voted against it.

TITLE: A study of this champion's heart helped prove the benefits of exercise
SUMMARY: More than a 100 years ago, doctors thought that too much running or other vigorous activity could harm us. Marathoner Clarence DeMar proved them wrong.

TITLE: She got famous on YouTube. Now it helps fund her research in quantum gravity
SUMMARY: This theoretical physicist and mathematician drops a new video several times a month, dispensing her dry wit and pithy wisdom to a loyal fan base of nerds across the internet.

TITLE: Despite efforts of 3 U.S. administrations, migrant families keep crossing the border
SUMMARY: Immigration authorities arrested more families in August than in any month on record. U.S. officials have long grappled with discouraging families from coming â and found there are no easy solutions.

TITLE: Vaccines are still tested with horseshoe crab blood. The industry is finally changing
SUMMARY: The horseshoe crab bleeding industry is in transition. One biomedical company agreed to more oversight, and a regulatory group is paving the way for drug companies to use animal-free alternatives.

TITLE: Tropical Storm Ophelia barrels across North Carolina with heavy rain and strong winds
SUMMARY: Ophelia was generating 50 mph winds and is expected to produce up to 8 inches of rain in some parts of North Carolina and Virginia on Saturday.

TITLE: National Cathedral unveils racial justice-themed windows, replacing Confederate ones
SUMMARY: The windows, titled "Now and Forever," were created by artist Kerry James Marshall. It showcases a group of protesters holding up large signs that read "Fairness" and "No Foul Play."

TITLE: Florida authorities killed an alligator that was seen with human remains in its mouth
SUMMARY: A 13-foot-8.5-inch male alligator was "humanely killed" and removed from the water, authorities said, after a local resident saw the reptile latching onto human remains in a Tampa Bay area canal.

TITLE: Ophelia weakens to a tropical depression as it churns across Virginia
SUMMARY: Ophelia could bring up to 5 inches of rain across the Mid-Atlantic region into Sunday. Threats of storm surges have dissipated, but flooding risk remains, even as Ophelia is on track to weaken.

TITLE: An Israeli military raid has killed two Palestinians in the West Bank
SUMMARY: Two Palestinians were killed during an Israeli military raid Sunday in the northern West Bank, Palestinian health officials said, in a surge of violence during a sensitive Jewish holiday period.

TITLE: Norovirus in the wilderness? How an outbreak spread on the Pacific Crest Trail
SUMMARY: Having this virus is bad enough at home, where you might spend hours hugging the toilet. Imagine having it out camping. Investigators wanted to find out how backpackers were getting and spreading it.

TITLE: She's currently the only Black woman leading a state military. Here's how it happened
SUMMARY: Brig. Gen. Janeen Birckhead of Maryland only became a soldier to help pay for college. Three decades later, she's risen to the top military position in Maryland, leading a force of 4,600 soldiers.

TITLE: One Kosovo police officer killed and one wounded, raising tensions with Serbia
SUMMARY: Kosovo's prime minister on Sunday said one police officer was killed and another wounded in an attack he blamed on support from neighboring Serbia, increasing tensions between the two former war foes.

TITLE: Watch Live: NASA sends an asteroid sample back to Earth
SUMMARY: NASA's Osiris-REx mission sends a pristine sample of asteroid back to Earth Sunday morning. If it lands successfully, this cupful-or-so of space rock could shed light on the solar system's origins.

TITLE: Usher will headline the 2024 Super Bowl halftime show in Las Vegas
SUMMARY: "It's an honor of a lifetime to finally check a Super Bowl performance off my bucket list," the music megastar said of his appearance at the Feb. 11, 2024 game.

TITLE: Watch Live: To cheers, NASA asteroid sample capsule safely touches down in Utah
SUMMARY: NASA's Osiris-REx mission has successfully returned a pristine sample of asteroid back to Earth. This cupful-or-so of space rock could shed light on the solar system's origins.

TITLE: Ophelia, now a post-tropical cyclone, batters Northeast with heavy rain
SUMMARY: The National Hurricane Center expect some areas in the Mid-Atlantic to southern New England to recieve between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall, posing risk of urban and flash flooding.

TITLE: Tigst Assefa smashes the women's marathon record by more than 2 minutes
SUMMARY: The 26-year-old Ethiopian crossed the finish line at the Brandenburg Gate with a time of 2:11:53.

TITLE: To cheers, NASA asteroid sample capsule safely touches down in Utah
SUMMARY: NASA's Osiris-REx mission has successfully returned a pristine sample of asteroid back to Earth. This cupful-or-so of space rock could shed light on the solar system's origins.

TITLE: Israel strikes Gaza for the third straight day as West Bank violence escalates
SUMMARY: A series of violent escalations on the border between Israel and Gaza over the past week during a sensitive Jewish holiday period raised the specter of an escalation for the first time since May.

TITLE: France will end its military presence in Niger and pull its ambassador, Macron says
SUMMARY: The change comes after Niger's democratically elected president was deposed in a coup. French troops pulled out of neighboring Mali and Burkina Faso in recent years after coups there.

TITLE: Post-tropical cyclone Ophelia unleashes heavy rain across Northeast
SUMMARY: Heavy rain from Ophelia will also pose a risk of flash flooding from Virginia to New Jersey, according to the National Hurricane Center.

TITLE: NASA asteroid sample lands safely in Utah before being whisked away by helicopter
SUMMARY: NASA's Osiris-REx mission has successfully returned a pristine sample of asteroid back to Earth. This cupful-or-so of space rock could shed light on the solar system's origins.

TITLE: Hollywood writers reach a tentative deal with studios, agree to end strike
SUMMARY: Hollywood production has been halted for months as actors and writers have been on strike. Now, the writers are headed back to work. Actors represented by SAG-AFTRA remain on strike.

TITLE: Hollywood writers reach a tentative deal with studios after nearly five month strike
SUMMARY: Hollywood production has been halted for months as actors and writers have been on strike. Now, the writers are headed back to work. Actors represented by SAG-AFTRA remain on strike.

TITLE: Young climate activists challenging 32 governments will get their day in court
SUMMARY: Six young activists are due Wednesday at the European Court of Human Rights, where they're accusing 32 governments of violating their human rights for failing to adequately address climate change.

TITLE: A Mafia boss on the run for decades dies in hospital months after his capture
SUMMARY: Matteo Messina Denaro died on Monday in a hospital prison ward several months after being captured following decades on the run, Italian state radio said.

TITLE: Manila vows to remove barrier placed by China's coast guard at a disputed site
SUMMARY: Philippine officials vowed Monday to remove a floating barrier placed by China's coast guard to prevent Filipino fishing boats from entering a disputed lagoon in the South China Sea.

TITLE: A government shutdown could cut short the National Zoo's panda goodbye celebrations
SUMMARY: Through the rest of the month, the zoo is inviting the public to commemorate the departure of the three giant pandas who will return to China in December. A shutdown could kill the party's finale.

TITLE: Senate pickleball caucus leaves politics off the court
SUMMARY: Some bipartisan senators are picking up paddles and trying out America's fasting growing sport as a way to build relationships. They're trading partisan barbs for friendly competition.

TITLE: 5 things to know about the 14th Amendment effort to block Trump from the presidency
SUMMARY: Some legal scholars and activists say an obscure provision of the Constitution, dating back to just after the Civil War, should disqualify Donald Trump from a second White House term.

TITLE: Scientific dynamic duo aims to stop the next pandemic before it starts
SUMMARY: Two scientists, one Nigerian and one American, created a cutting-edge surveillance network to catch the next emerging disease before it becomes a pandemic.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Hollywood writers deal, NASA asteroid sample, pickleball caucus
SUMMARY: Hollywood writers reached a tentative deal with major studios. NASA scientists are celebrating the successful landing of an asteroid sample. A pickleball caucus is uniting senators across parties.

TITLE: Ride passengers rescued after dangling upside down, 75 feet up, for half an hour
SUMMARY: The oscillating Lumberjack ride at Canada's Wonderland theme park stopped suddenly, in mid-air, on Sunday. Videos posted to social media captured the sounds of passengers crying for help.

TITLE: Thousands of federal firefighters face a looming pay cut. How much is up to Congress
SUMMARY: The bipartisan infrastructure law granted federal firefighters a big pay bump. Amid a looming government shutdown, that wage increase will expire, leaving first responders unsure about their income.

TITLE: Horseless carriages were once a lot like driverless cars. What can history teach us?
SUMMARY: Historians say that a little more than a century ago, when cars first hit the roads, they caused nervous laughter and raised real concerns, much like driverless vehicles today.

TITLE: Haley Van Voorhis makes NCAA football history as the first female non-kicker player
SUMMARY: The safety, a junior at Shenandoah University in Winchester, Va., was tapped to play Saturday against Juniata College during a Division III game â delivering a successful quarterback hurry.

TITLE: Why Iran won't budge on mandatory hijab laws â according to the president's wife
SUMMARY: Jamileh Alamolhoda, the wife of Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi, talks about why Iran's government is unwilling to compromise on compulsory headscarf rules.

TITLE: Iconic female artist's lost painting is found, hundreds of years after it was created
SUMMARY: <em>Susanna and the Elders

TITLE: Perdue Farms and Tyson Foods under federal inquiry over reports of illegal child labor
SUMMARY: The Labor Department launched investigations into the two major poultry producers after reports that migrant children as young as 13 have been working overnight shifts to clean the companies' plants.

TITLE: Usher will soon have Super Bowl halftime validation. But can he top Rihanna?
SUMMARY: In the immortalized-by-meme words of Usher: Watch this.

TITLE: Biden tells Pacific islands leaders he'll act on their warnings about climate change
SUMMARY: Biden said his administration is requesting Congress approve $200 million in new assistance for the region, including financing to help the islands prepare for climate and natural hazards.

TITLE: FDNY deaths from 9/11-related illnesses now equal the number killed on Sept. 11
SUMMARY: Two recent deaths brought the total to 343, matching the death toll from Sept. 11, the FDNY said. Some 11,000 former and current FDNY employees suffer from 9/11-related illnesses, 3,500 with cancer.

TITLE: Megan Rapinoe, an icon bigger than soccer, takes a bow for the U.S. national team
SUMMARY: Taking it all in one last time while wearing the U.S. Soccer crest, Rapinoe reflected on how she and her generation had changed the game during her 17 years on the team.

TITLE: David McCallum, star of TV series 'The Man From U.N.C.L.E.' and 'NCIS,' dies at 90
SUMMARY: The Scottish-born actor's career included roles on stage and in movies, but the 1960s spy series made him a household name and his role as a quirky pathologist 40 years later brought him fame again.

TITLE: A blast in Nagorno-Karabakh injures more than 200, while thousands flee to Armenia
SUMMARY: The explosion at fuel storage facility wounded more than 200 people, the Nagorno-Karabakh human rights ombudsman said. Meanwhile, thousands of Nagorno-Karabakh residents have fled to Armenia.

TITLE: First of thousands of Lahaina residents return to homes destroyed by deadly wildfire
SUMMARY: In the days after the Aug. 8 wildfire, some people were able to return to their properties to evaluate the damage. But since then, the burned area has been off-limits to all but authorized workers.

TITLE: How a DNA test inspired actress-activist Kerry Washington's journey of self-discovery
SUMMARY: Washington was an adult when she learned that she had been conceived via artificial insemination and the man she considered her father was not her biological dad. Her new memoir is <em>Thicker than Water.

TITLE: Ford pauses construction of Michigan battery plant amid contract talks with UAW union
SUMMARY: The move comes as the company is in the midst of national contract talks with the United Auto Workers union, which wants to represent workers at battery factories and win them top wages.

TITLE: At least 20 dead in gas station blast as Nagorno-Karabakh residents flee to Armenia
SUMMARY: Separatist authorities in Nagorno-Karabakh said at least 20 people were killed and nearly 300 others injured by an explosion at a gas station as people seeking to flee to Armenia lined up for fuel.

TITLE: An overdose drug is finally over-the-counter. Is that enough to stop the death toll?
SUMMARY: Narcan is now available in drug stores without a prescription. The nasal spray can save a life by stopping an opioid overdose. But will people pay the price and ask for it by name?

TITLE: Kamila Valieva doping scandal that rocked the Beijing Olympics may finally be settled
SUMMARY: The Court of Arbitration for Sport begins a hearing Tuesday into the doping scandal of Russian figure skater Kamila Valieva. U.S. skaters still haven't received team medals from the 2022 Winter Games.

TITLE: How new borrowers can prepare for their first student loan payment
SUMMARY: When student loan bills begin coming due in October, new borrowers will take their first steps on the long road to paying off their debt. These tools and tips can help ease the journey.

TITLE: She survived a horrific crash. This is why she now keeps a blanket in her trunk
SUMMARY: After Laura Carstensen was badly injured in a car crash, two strangers stopped to help her. Their small act of help made a lasting impression.

TITLE: Why many business owners would love it if you stopped using your credit card
SUMMARY: The fees merchants pay for accepting credit cards are much higher in the U.S. than in Europe. Ice cream shop owner Victor Garcia, for example, paid more than $25,000 in swipe fees last year.

TITLE: In some states, more than half of the local election officials have left since 2020
SUMMARY: Election conspiracies have fundamentally changed the job of local voting officials, and many don't want to take it anymore.

TITLE: Autoworkers will get a historic visitor to the picket line: President Biden
SUMMARY: Biden will join the United Auto Workers in Michigan on Tuesday, an extraordinary step for a sitting president.

TITLE: Washington prepares for the shutdown that was never supposed to happen
SUMMARY: Congress is just days away from a possible government shutdown with few solutions being discussed.

TITLE: Up First briefing: Biden visits UAW; Congress tackles shutdown; Olympic doping hearing
SUMMARY: Biden will make a historic visit to picketing autoworkers. Congress returns four days before a potential government shutdown. A hearing for Kamila Valieva's Olympic doping scandal begins today.

TITLE: How NPR covered the missionary who ran a center for malnourished kids where 105 died
SUMMARY: In 2019, NPR covered the story of Renee Bach, who said she was called by God to serve the children of Uganda. Now HBO is presenting her story in the documentary series 'White Savior.'

TITLE: Senate Democrats to Bob Menendez: Resign
SUMMARY: Democrats are abandoning New Jersey Sen. Bob Menendez in the wake of his federal indictment in a corruption scheme involving his wife and local businessmen.

TITLE: Supreme Court rejects Alabama's defiance in voting case
SUMMARY: In June, the court ruled that Alabama's Republican-drawn congressional map violated the Voting Rights Act.

TITLE: U.S. sues Amazon in a monopoly case that could be existential for the retail giant
SUMMARY: The FTC lawsuit against Amazon could be existential for the company. It accuses Amazon of suffocating rivals and raising costs for both sellers and shoppers.

TITLE: Hunter Biden sues Rudy Giuliani for 'total annihilation' of digital privacy
SUMMARY: The lawsuit alleges that Rudy Giuliani and an associate's actions are unlawful under California law, and it says Giuliani and the associate have refused to return Hunter Biden's data.

TITLE: Hans Niemann pooh-poohs a chess cheating theory that's based on vibrating beads
SUMMARY: Chess prodigy Hans Niemann is competing in the World Junior Chess Championship â but he's also answering questions about an outlandish cheating theory.

TITLE: Cars are a major predator for wildlife. How is nature adapting to our roads?
SUMMARY: Environmental journalist Ben Goldfarb says cars are killing animals, while highways cut off them off from their food sources and migration paths. His new book is <em>Crossings

TITLE: JPMorgan to pay $75 million over claims it enabled Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking
SUMMARY: The Virgin Islands had argued that JPMorgan had been complicit in Epstein's behavior and did not raise any red flags to law enforcement or bank regulators about Epstein being a "high risk" customer.

TITLE: Agriculture secretary says government shutdown would impact department's programs
SUMMARY: NPR's A Martinez talks to Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack about programs â such as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program â which would be affected if the government shuts down.

TITLE: How to watch the second GOP presidential debate
SUMMARY: Seven Republicans vying for the GOP presidential nomination will take the stage in California Wednesday night for the second GOP debate of the 2024 elections. But the front runner is skipping â again.

TITLE: Irish gymnastics group apologizes after a Black girl was skipped at a medal ceremony
SUMMARY: Gymnastics Ireland has apologized for the incident. But the girl's mother says the group hasn't done enough. Video shows an official giving medals to a line of girls except the only Black participant.

TITLE: Ford's Theatre tickets from the night Lincoln was assassinated sell for $262,500
SUMMARY: The two tickets match the marks of what's thought to be the only other used ticket from the night John Wilkes Booth shot Lincoln on April 14, 1865.

TITLE: Millions of Americans will lose food assistance if the government shuts down
SUMMARY: A shutdown would affect the nearly 7 million women and children who rely on WIC for healthy food. Free school lunch and Meals on Wheels are also at risk, and SNAP could be impacted eventually too.

TITLE: 'People Collide' is a 'Freaky Friday'-type exploration of the self and persona
SUMMARY: Isle McElroy's novel covers a deep exploration of marriage, love, and the ways we know one another â while also touching on how so much of how we navigate the world depends on how it sees us.

TITLE: New California law bars schoolbook bans based on racial and LGBTQ topics
SUMMARY: Gov. Gavin Newsom called the new measure "long overdue," saying that the banning binge of diversity materials has to come to an end.

TITLE: Russian appeals court upholds opposition leader Alexei Navalny's 19-year prison term
SUMMARY: Navalny, a fierce critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, says the charges against him are politically motivated.

TITLE: A judge says Trump is liable for fraud in New York civil lawsuit
SUMMARY: Judge Arthur Engoron finds that Trump and his associates exaggerated the former president's net worth in order to complete deals and receive more financing.

TITLE: California is first state to levy a tax on guns and ammo to fund safety programs
SUMMARY: New law will impose an additional 11% in addition to federal tax. It's one of nearly two dozen gun laws signed into law on Tuesday. but Newsom acknowledges some might not survive legal challenges.

TITLE: Barry Manilow just broke Elvis's Las Vegas record
SUMMARY: Barry Manilow has just overtaken The King himself, Elvis Presley, for the most shows at Westgate Las Vegas Resort & Casino.

TITLE: An annular solar eclipse is coming to parts of the U.S. in October
SUMMARY: Residents from Oregon to Texas may be able to glimpse the annular eclipse, when the moon is deep in its orbit and passes in front of the sun, creating a black circle on the star.

TITLE: Brooks Robinson, Hall of Fame Orioles third baseman, dies at 86
SUMMARY: Hall of Fame third baseman Brooks Robinson, whose deft glovework and folksy manner made him one of the most beloved and accomplished athletes in Baltimore history, has died. He was 86.

TITLE: Writers will return to work on Wednesday, after union leadership votes to end strike
SUMMARY: The 148-day Hollywood writers strike will end just after 12:01 a.m. PT on Wednesday, thanks to a new three-year deal the Writers Guild of America made with major Hollywood studios.

TITLE: A fire at a wedding hall in Iraq kills at least 100 people and injures 150 more
SUMMARY: There was no immediate official word on the cause of the blaze but initial reports suggested fireworks at the venue may have sparked the fire.

TITLE: The U.S. has suspended some aid to Gabon after the military takeover
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced a "pause in certain foreign assistance programs" to Gabon pending a review of the circumstances that led to the ouster of the country's former leader.

TITLE: Canada's House speaker has stepped down after inviting a Nazi veteran to Parliament
SUMMARY: Just after Ukrainian President Zelenskyy gave an address in the House of Commons, Canadian lawmakers gave 98-year-old Yaroslav Hunka a standing ovation when the House speaker drew attention to him.

TITLE: They were wrongfully imprisoned 9 years ago. For Yeganeh, the pain is still fresh
SUMMARY: Journalist Yeganeh Rezaian speaks about her time being imprisoned in Iran with her husband, Jason Rezaian, in 2014 and how that experienced has shaped the rest of her life.

TITLE: New Mexico's Republican Party takes the state's congressional map to trial
SUMMARY: A trial begins Wednesday over New Mexico's congressional map. Unlike some other active fights over redistricting, it's the state's Democratic lawmakers who are accused of crafting illegal districts.

TITLE: 8 loving ways to honor a pet's memory: Write an obit, grow a garden, dedicate a day
SUMMARY: How do you deal with the heartbreak of losing a beloved pet? Our audience shares creative and inspiring ways to process grief â and celebrate the lives of our animal companions.

TITLE: Trump bets big on Michigan with rally on GOP debate night as UAW strike continues
SUMMARY: Seven Republicans will join the second GOP debate Wednesday but the front-runner, former President Donald Trump won't be one of them. Instead, Trump will head to Michigan to court autoworkers.

TITLE: On N.Y.'s Staten Island, anti-immigration protests intensify as migrants stream in
SUMMARY: New York City has been housing migrants in makeshift shelters throughout the city. In some areas, it has led to protests and court challenges.

SUMMARY: The military is among the largest buyers of independent power systems known as microgrids. They make tactical sense; and environmentalists hope they can help the transition from fossil fuels.

TITLE: Looks like we picked the wrong week to quit quoting 'Airplane!'
SUMMARY: A new book about the 1980's film "Airplane!" from David Zucker, Jim Abrahams & Jerry Zucker, the writing and directing team responsible for one of the most transformative film comedies in history.

SUMMARY: Catch up on key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

SUMMARY: NPR's A Martinez talks to <em>Washington Post

SUMMARY: Former prime minister Robert Fico campaigned as a left-wing populist, opposing continued military support for Ukraine and aligning with Russia against the United States.

TITLE: 5 years after Khashoggi's murder, advocates say the lack of justice is dangerous
SUMMARY: Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi was murdered in October 2018. Those involved in his killing have largely avoided consequences, and Saudi Arabia continues to crack down on its dissidents.

SUMMARY: The nation's most senior military officer has retired. He talks to <em>All Things Considered

SUMMARY: In her new memoir, Kerry Washington explores how a shocking discovery about her identity changed her relationship with her parents and her own children.

TITLE: The moment when Selma Blair's service dog seemingly made Biden one of his people
SUMMARY: It was a subtle gesture: As actress Selma Blair delivered remarks to an audience at the White House, Scout, her service dog, laid down next to her and then gently flopped over on Biden's shoe.

TITLE: Rep. Matt Gaetz launches effort to oust House Speaker Kevin McCarthy
SUMMARY: Rep. Matt Gaetz, R-Fla., launched the process for holding a vote to remove Kevin McCarthy as House<strong>

SUMMARY: The Armenian government said Monday that over 100,000 of Nagorno-Karabakh's estimated 120,000 residents have crossed into Armenia.

SUMMARY: Experts believe high water temperatures are the most likely cause of the deaths in the lakes in the region. Temperatures since last week have exceeded 102 degrees Fahrenheit in the Tefe Lake region.

SUMMARY: Almost all of China's medium and large cities are susceptible to floods. Some experts are promoting a solution called sponge cities â urban landscapes that are softer and meant to absorb more water.

SUMMARY: Nicks introduced "Stevie Barbie" at a concert on Sunday night, and preorders sold out the next day. The doll resembles Nicks in her <em>Rumours

SUMMARY: Sam Bankman-Fried faces seven criminal charges, including for defrauding investors. His blockbuster trial is set to begin on Tuesday, and he could face an over 100-year prison term if convicted.

SUMMARY: The federal government will test the emergency alert system by sending messages to millions of cellphones, TVs and radios. Prepare for your phone to emit loud sounds and vibrations.

SUMMARY: A long waiting list at Montana's only state-run psychiatric hospital has left inmates untreated and stuck in county jails. To fix it, health officials want changes to involuntary commitment laws.

SUMMARY: The scientists look at electrons in atoms during the tiniest of split seconds, giving "humanity new tools for exploring the world of electrons," according to the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.

SUMMARY: Sam Bankman-Fried heads to court on fraud and money laundering charges. Technology has made us more sedentary. Here's how to fix it.

SUMMARY: Ng made history when she took the top executive job in Miami back in 2020. Now, just three years later, she has steered the Marlins to their best winning percentage since 2009.

SUMMARY: The retailer says it hired an outside firm to look into the claims against Mike Jeffries. It's a major test for a brand that's remaking its image for a socially conscious era.

SUMMARY: The House is expected to vote soon on a motion that could remove Kevin McCarthy as Speaker of the House, Democrats say they will not vote to help him.

SUMMARY: The case before the high court Tuesday examined how the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is funded. A ruling in favor of payday lenders could gut the agency.

SUMMARY: Some "climate jobs" are obvious. Others, not so much. So we talked to three people whose jobs address climate change in unexpected ways.

SUMMARY: Kevin McCarthy's run as speaker was relatively short and anything but sweet.

TITLE: Scientists looked at nearly every known amphibian type. They're not doing great
SUMMARY: A new global assessment of the world's amphibians finds that more than 2 of every 5 known species is at risk of extinction. Habitat loss, disease and climate change are the main drivers.

SUMMARY: The U.S. women won a record seventh consecutive team title at the gymnastics world championships. The team of Biles, Shilese Jones, Skye Blakely and Leanne Wong edged out Brazil and France.

SUMMARY: Sam Bankman-Fried's trial in New York kicked off with lawyers from both sides delivering their opening statements, painting him as a villain or as an innocent nerd.

SUMMARY: The report from the Copernicus Climate Change Service also noted that Earth set a new mark for how far above normal temperatures reached in September.

SUMMARY: A woman was hospitalized after a ride down Typhoon Lagoon's tallest water slide left her with severe vaginal lacerations and internal organ damage, according to the lawsuit.

SUMMARY: Black holes may seem like interstellar enigmas, but they hold some key lessons on how to move through the universe.

SUMMARY: Republicans plan to convene for a candidate forum on Tuesday and hold a speakership vote on Wednesday. While it's not clear who will be running, there's no question they face a tough road ahead.

SUMMARY: Late night TV has seen a recent exodus of non-white stars â from Desus and Mero and Ziwe to Trevor Noah himself.

SUMMARY: Dollar General's primary care experiment could help solve rural America's care shortage. But it's getting a chilly reception in Tennessee.

SUMMARY: The race is on for House Republicans to find a new speaker. How old technology harnesses wind to power cargo ships and reduce emissions.

TITLE: Alabama finally has a new congressional map after a lengthy legal fight

SUMMARY: The Grace Hopper Celebration was designed to celebrate and uplift workers who are traditionally underrepresented in the tech industry. This year, men showed up in droves.

SUMMARY: A woman was hospitalized after a ride down Typhoon Lagoon's tallest water slide left her with severe vaginal lacerations and internal organ damage, according to the lawsuit.

SUMMARY: The United Auto Workers' targeted strike against the Big Three is about gradually ramping up pressure on the automakers while also stretching out the union's strike fund.

SUMMARY: Huge swaths of the country are pivoting from fossil fuels, toward wind, solar and other renewables. <em>New York Times

SUMMARY: For years, the U.S. Army has not been able to meet its annual recruitment goal. The Secretary of the Army, Christine Wormuth, is rolling out a plan to address that.

SUMMARY: Marching bands returned to practice this fall under challenges like extreme heat and irregular weather conditions. They're getting creative to beat the heat of climate change.

SUMMARY: The <em>FIRST

SUMMARY: To discourage migrants, the U.K. wants to deport to Rwanda some who arrive by boat without a visa. Human rights groups have sued, and the Supreme Court will begin hearing arguments on Oct. 9.

SUMMARY: NPR's Student Podcast Challenge yielded stories about how students around the U.S. are thinking about and responding to climate change. Here are some of their ideas.

SUMMARY: In a surprise attack, Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip on Saturday infiltrated southern Israel. Dozens of Israelis and more than 200 Palestinians were killed in the fighting.

SUMMARY: When it comes to the health benefits of cold water dips, the hype is ahead of the science. NPR talked to researchers about what's true, what's not, and the latest on how to get the most out of it.

SUMMARY: Experts refer to "climate grief." Terry Tempest Williams explains what this feels like to someone who has spent their life thinking about our psychic and spiritual connection to the natural world.

SUMMARY: The "15-minute city" is an urban planning concept that aims to increase quality of life and reduce planet-heating pollution. But it faces obstacles, including conspiracy theories.

TITLE: Israel trying to regain full control of its territory day after Hamas attack
SUMMARY: The Israeli military said Sunday that it is still battling Hamas militants in several Israeli communities a day after they broke through the Gaza border to launch an unprecedented wave of attacks.

SUMMARY: Images shared by Afghan journalists showed at least one village reduced to rubble after a series of quakes flattened stone and mudbrick homes in the country's west.

SUMMARY: So you want to do something about climate change, but what? We have ideas. Some require a little planning, while others might mean one less thing on your to-do list. (You can skip raking leaves!)

SUMMARY: In his new book, 97-year-old Robert Jay Lifton shares the "survivor wisdom" he's learned from those who've lived through terrible events â the Holocaust, Hiroshima, POW camps.

TITLE: Israel is trying to regain full control of its territory a day after Hamas attack
SUMMARY: The Israeli military said Sunday that it is still battling Hamas militants in several Israeli communities a day after they broke through the Gaza border to launch an unprecedented wave of attacks.

SUMMARY: Friday night was Megan Rapinoe's last regular season home game in Seattle with the OL Reign, the team she's played with for her entire 11-year NWSL career.

SUMMARY: The jackpot is now the world's fourth-largest lottery prize after rolling over for 34 consecutive drawings, since the last time someone won the top prize on July 19.

SUMMARY: A few years ago, a man who called himself Stephen became a fixture in Manhattan's Riverside Park. After his body was discovered, a woman who knew him made it her mission to bring his story to light.

SUMMARY: There are still a number of unaccounted-for U.S. citizens, U.S. officials said, as the fighting entered its third day.

SUMMARY: Israel's airstrikes continue on Gaza after Hamas militants made a surprise attack along Israel's southern border. Scores of Israeli hostages are being held captive in Gaza.

SUMMARY: Sen. Cory Booker and Rep. Dan Goldman are back in the U.S. after sheltering in place as violence erupted in Israel on Saturday. Flight disruptions have left other U.S. citizens unable to get home.

SUMMARY: Yosi Shnaidel's cousin and her children are among six of his relatives kidnapped by Hamas during the attack inside Israel.

SUMMARY: In her return to short stories, the Interpreter of Maladies author

TITLE: Why Hamas and Israel reached this moment now â and what comes next
SUMMARY: The conflict is expected to escalate even further in the coming days. But for now, Hamas sees itself with the upper hand.

SUMMARY: Many children have likely already heard about the attacks in Israel, whether from school or overhearing the news. Let them ask questions, experts say â it's OK if you don't have all the answers.

SUMMARY: The conflict between Israel and Hamas escalates as anticipation of an Israeli ground invasion grows. Senior voters reflect on possibly electing a president their age next year.

SUMMARY: Many Israelis are frantically looking for clues about loved ones believed to be held in Gaza. Ido Dan keeps watching a video that appears to show Hamas militants kidnapping his 12-year-old nephew.

SUMMARY: The winning photographs star different species from around the world, all highlighting the interplay between animals and humans. The two grand titles went to shots of a horseshoe crab and barn owls.

SUMMARY: What's the easiest way to create a new version of the classic sitcom <em>Frasier

TITLE: An empty-nest mama bear just won Fat Bear Week
SUMMARY: Like an ursine Sarah Connor, Grazer is one tough mother. She preemptively attacks huge males that might threaten her offspring. And she's focused on the future, eating all the salmon she can catch.

SUMMARY: They call themselves Las Amazonas de Yaxunah. They've defeated gender stereotypes to become stars in Mexico. And these women and teens play the game wearing traditional Maya dresses â and no shoes.,

SUMMARY: A rule proposed by the Federal Trade Commission would outlaw hidden and "bogus" fees. Officials estimate that junk fees cost consumers at least $64 billion each year.

TITLE: The sexual assault victims suing Uber notch a legal victory in their long battle
SUMMARY: In a landmark decision, a panel of judges has ruled that dozens of sexual assault cases filed against Uber can be consolidated.

TITLE: She's the star witness against Sam Bankman-Fried. Her testimony was explosive
SUMMARY: Caroline Ellison accused Bankman-Fried of being the mastermind behind illegal activity at FTX. Her words carry weight: She worked with him and also once dated him.

SUMMARY: The alert system will use electronic highway signs and encourage the use of TV, radio, social media and other platforms to spread information about the missing person.

SUMMARY: The jackpot is the world's second-largest lottery prize after rolling over for 36 consecutive drawings, since the last time someone won the top prize on July 19.

TITLE: Social Security recipients will get a smaller increase in benefits as inflation cools

SUMMARY: As Israel intensified its attacks on the militant group Hamas, Gaza remained under a near-total communications blackout. Some aid groups said they were unable to reach their staffs on the ground.

TITLE: 'Breakfast Club' host DJ Envy is being sued for alleged investment fraud
SUMMARY: The popular Power 105. FM radio personality had partnered with investor Cesar Pina to host real estate seminars across the country. The feds now say Pina was running a Ponzi scheme.

TITLE: Why workers are resorting to more strikes this year to put pressure on companies
SUMMARY: This has been a watershed year. So far in 2023, there have been 22 major strikes: 17 at companies, making it the largest number of strikes in the private sector since 2011.

SUMMARY: This has been a watershed year. So far in 2023, there have been 22 major strikes: 17 at companies, making it the largest number of strikes in the private sector since 2011.

TITLE: Maine shooter's body was found near a scene that had been searched by police
SUMMARY: Authorities said the 40-year-old man's body was found inside a trailer close to a recycling center Friday evening. Nearby trailers had previously been cleared twice by police.

TITLE: For some Jewish peace activists, demands for a cease-fire come at a personal cost
SUMMARY: Jewish Americans critical of how Israel and the U.S. are responding to Hamas' attack say they're ostracized by the mainstream U.S. Jewish community. They worry there's no room for dissenting voices.

TITLE: Former Vice President Mike Pence ends his presidential campaign
SUMMARY: Pence becomes the first major candidate to leave a race that has been dominated by his former boss-turned-rival, Donald Trump.
